We used a porcine model of chronic coronary occlusion and collateral development to evaluate the hypothesis that exercise training enhances endothelium-mediated relaxation and increases endothelial nitric oxide synthase (ecNOS) mRNA levels of collateral-dependent microvasculature. 	 BACKGROUND
Adult female miniature swine were subjected to chronic, progressive ameroid occlusion of the proximal left circumflex coronary artery (LCx); after 2 months, animals were randomly exposed to 16-week exercise-training (EX group; treadmill running) or sedentary (SED group; cage confinement) protocols. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
After completion of EX or SED programs, coronary arterioles ( approximately 100 microm in diameter) were isolated from collateral-dependent LCx (distal to occlusion) and nonoccluded left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) regions of each heart. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Arterioles were studied by in vitro videomicroscopy or frozen for ecNOS mRNA analysis (RT-PCR techniques). 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Relaxation to the endothelium-dependent vasodilator bradykinin was decreased (P<0.05) in arterioles isolated from collateral-dependent LCx versus nonoccluded LAD regions of SED animals. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Bradykinin-mediated relaxation, however, was not different in LCx versus LAD arterioles isolated from EX animals. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Nitroprusside-induced relaxation was unaffected by either chronic occlusion or exercise. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Importantly, ecNOS mRNA expression was significantly decreased in arterioles isolated from LCx versus LAD regions of SED animals. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
After training, ecNOS mRNA expression was not different between LAD and LCx arterioles. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
These data indicate that exercise training enhances bradykinin-mediated relaxation of collateral-dependent LCx arterioles isolated after chronic coronary occlusion, most likely because of effects on ecNOS mRNA expression and increased production of NO. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Intraperitoneal placement of polypropylene mesh leads to extensive visceral adhesions and is contraindicated. 	 BACKGROUND
Different coatings are used to improve polypropylene mesh properties. 	 BACKGROUND
Collagen is a protein with unique biocompatibility and cell ingrowth enhancement potential. 	 BACKGROUND
A novel acetic acid extracted collagen coating was developed to allow placement of polypropylene mesh in direct contact with viscera. 	 BACKGROUND
The authors' aim was to evaluate the long-term influence of acetic acid extracted collagen coating on surgical aspects and biomechanical properties of polypropylene mesh implanted in direct contact with viscera, including complications, adhesions with viscera, strength of incorporation, and microscopic inflammatory reaction. 	 BACKGROUND
Forty adult Wistar rats were divided into two groups: experimental (polypropylene mesh/acetic acid extracted collagen coating) and control (polypropylene mesh only). 	 METHODS
Astandardized procedure of mesh implantation was performed. 	 METHODS
Animals were killed 3 months after surgery and analyzed for complications, mesh area covered by adhesions, type of adhesions, strength of incorporation, and intensity of inflammatory response. 	 METHODS
The mean adhesion area was lower for polypropylene mesh/acetic acid extracted collagen coating (14.5 percent versus 69.9 percent, p < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Adhesion severity was decreased in the experimental group: grades 0 and 1 were more frequent (p < 0.04 and p < 0.002, respectively) and grade 3 was less frequent (p < 0.0001). 	 RESULTS
An association between adhesion area and severity was found (p < 0.0001). 	 RESULTS
Complications, strength of incorporation, and intensity of inflammatory response to the mesh were similar. 	 RESULTS
Visceral adhesions to polypropylene mesh are significantly reduced because of acetic acid extracted collagen coating. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The collagen coating does not increase complications or induce alterations of polypropylene mesh incorporation. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The 1987 American College of Rheumatology (ACR; formerly the American Rheumatism Association) classification criteria for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) have been criticised for their lack of sensitivity in early disease. 	 OBJECTIVE
This work was undertaken to develop new classification criteria for RA. 	 OBJECTIVE
A joint working group from the ACR and the European League Against Rheumatism developed, in three phases, a new approach to classifying RA. 	 METHODS
The work focused on identifying, among patients newly presenting with undifferentiated inflammatory synovitis, factors that best discriminated between those who were and those who were not at high risk for persistent and/or erosive disease--this being the appropriate current paradigm underlying the disease construct 'RA'. 	 METHODS
In the new criteria set, classification as 'definite RA' is based on the confirmed presence of synovitis in at least one joint, absence of an alternative diagnosis better explaining the synovitis, and achievement of a total score of 6 or greater (of a possible 10) from the individual scores in four domains: number and site of involved joints (range 0-5), serological abnormality (range 0-3), elevated acute-phase response (range 0-1) and symptom duration (two levels; range 0-1). 	 RESULTS
This new classification system redefines the current paradigm of RA by focusing on features at earlier stages of disease that are associated with persistent and/or erosive disease, rather than defining the disease by its late-stage features. 	 CONCLUSION
This will refocus attention on the important need for earlier diagnosis and institution of effective disease-suppressing therapy to prevent or minimise the occurrence of the undesirable sequelae that currently comprise the paradigm underlying the disease construct 'RA'. 	 CONCLUSION
Neonatal mortality accounts for almost 40 per cent of under-five child mortality, globally. 	 BACKGROUND
An understanding of the factors related to neonatal mortality is important to guide the development of focused and evidence-based health interventions to prevent neonatal deaths. 	 BACKGROUND
This study aimed to identify the determinants of neonatal mortality in Indonesia, for a nationally representative sample of births from 1997 to 2002. 	 BACKGROUND
The data source for the analysis was the 2002-2003 Indonesia Demographic and Health Survey from which survival information of 15,952 singleton live-born infants born between 1997 and 2002 was examined. 	 METHODS
Multilevel logistic regression using a hierarchical approach was performed to analyze the factors associated with neonatal deaths, using community, socio-economic status and proximate determinants. 	 METHODS
At the community level, the odds of neonatal death was significantly higher for infants from East Java (OR = 5.01, p = 0.00), and for North, Central and Southeast Sulawesi and Gorontalo combined (OR = 3.17, p = 0.03) compared to the lowest neonatal mortality regions of Bali, South Sulawesi and Jambi provinces. 	 RESULTS
A progressive reduction in the odds was found as the percentage of deliveries assisted by trained delivery attendants in the cluster increased. 	 RESULTS
The odds of neonatal death were higher for infants born to both mother and father who were employed (OR = 1.84, p = 0.00) and for infants born to father who were unemployed (OR = 2.99, p = 0.02). 	 RESULTS
The odds were also higher for higher rank infants with a short birth interval (OR = 2.82, p = 0.00), male infants (OR = 1.49, p = 0.01), smaller than average-sized infants (OR = 2.80, p = 0.00), and infant's whose mother had a history of delivery complications (OR = 1.81, p = 0.00). 	 RESULTS
Infants receiving any postnatal care were significantly protected from neonatal death (OR = 0.63, p = 0.03). 	 RESULTS
Public health interventions directed at reducing neonatal death should address community, household and individual level factors which significantly influence neonatal mortality in Indonesia. 	 CONCLUSION
Low birth weight and short birth interval infants as well as perinatal health services factors, such as the availability of skilled birth attendance and postnatal care utilization should be taken into account when planning the interventions to reduce neonatal mortality in Indonesia. 	 CONCLUSION
The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) cholesterol treatment guidelines have wide-scale implications for treating adults without history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) with statins. 	 IMPORTANCE
To estimate the cost-effectiveness of various 10-year ASCVD risk thresholds that could be used in the ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guidelines. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Microsimulation model, including lifetime time horizon, US societal perspective, 3% discount rate for costs, and health outcomes. 	 OBJECTIVE
In the model, hypothetical individuals from a representative US population aged 40 to 75 years received statin treatment, experienced ASCVD events, and died from ASCVD-related or non-ASCVD-related causes based on ASCVD natural history and statin treatment parameters. 	 OBJECTIVE
Data sources for model parameters included National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys, large clinical trials and meta-analyses for statin benefits and treatment, and other published sources. 	 OBJECTIVE
Estimated ASCVD events prevented and incremental costs per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. 	 MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES
In the base-case scenario, the current ASCVD threshold of 7.5% or higher, which was estimated to be associated with 48% of adults treated with statins, had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of $37,000/QALY compared with a 10% or higher threshold. 	 RESULTS
More lenient ASCVD thresholds of 4.0% or higher (61% of adults treated) and 3.0% or higher (67% of adults treated) had ICERs of $81,000/QALY and $140,000/QALY, respectively. 	 RESULTS
Shifting from a 7.5% or higher ASCVD risk threshold to a 3.0% or higher ASCVD risk threshold was estimated to be associated with an additional 161,560 cardiovascular disease events averted. 	 RESULTS
Cost-effectiveness results were sensitive to changes in the disutility associated with taking a pill daily, statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes. 	 RESULTS
In probabilistic sensitivity analysis, there was a higher than 93% chance that the optimal ASCVD threshold was 5.0% or lower using a cost-effectiveness threshold of $100,000/QALY. 	 RESULTS
In this microsimulation model of US adults aged 45 to 75 years [corrected], the current 10-year ASCVD risk threshold (≥7.5% risk threshold) used in the ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guidelines has an acceptable cost-effectiveness profile (ICER, $37,000/QALY), but more lenient ASCVD thresholds would be optimal using cost-effectiveness thresholds of $100,000/QALY (≥4.0% risk threshold) or $150,000/QALY (≥3.0% risk threshold). 	 CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE
The optimal ASCVD threshold was sensitive to patient preferences for taking a pill daily, changes to statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes. 	 CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE
RATIONALE, AIMS AND OBJECTIVES Following increased interest in having inter-professional (IP) health care teams engage patients in decision making, we developed a conceptual model for an IP approach to shared decision making (SDM) in primary care. 	 CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE
We assessed the validity of the model with stakeholders in Canada. 	 CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE
In 15 individual interviews and 7 group interviews with 79 stakeholders, we asked them to: (1) propose changes to the IP-SDM model; (2) identify barriers and facilitators to the model's implementation in clinical practice; and (3) assess the model using a theory appraisal questionnaire. 	 METHODS
We performed a thematic analysis of the transcripts and a descriptive analysis of the questionnaires. 	 METHODS
Stakeholders suggested placing the patient at its centre; extending the concept of family to include significant others; clarifying outcomes; highlighting the concept of time; merging the micro, meso and macro levels in one figure; and recognizing the influence of the environment and emotions. 	 RESULTS
The most common barriers identified were time constraints, insufficient resources and an imbalance of power among health professionals. 	 RESULTS
The most common facilitators were education and training in inter-professionalism and SDM, motivation to achieve an IP approach to SDM, and mutual knowledge and understanding of disciplinary roles. 	 RESULTS
Most stakeholders considered that the concepts and relationships between the concepts were clear and rated the model as logical, testable, having clear schematic representation, and being relevant to inter-professional collaboration, SDM and primary care. 	 RESULTS
Stakeholders validated the new IP-SDM model for primary care settings and proposed few modifications. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Future research should assess if the model helps implement SDM in IP clinical practice. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Venous thrombosis is a common complication in patients with cancer, leading to additional morbidity and compromising quality of life. 	 CONTEXT
To identify individuals with cancer with an increased thrombotic risk, evaluating different tumor sites, the presence of distant metastases, and carrier status of prothrombotic mutations. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS A large population-based, case-control (Multiple Environmental and Genetic Assessment [MEGA] of risk factors for venous thrombosis) study of 3220 consecutive patients aged 18 to 70 years, with a first deep venous thrombosis of the leg or pulmonary embolism, between March 1, 1999, and May 31, 2002, at 6 anticoagulation clinics in the Netherlands, and separate 2131 control participants (partners of the patients) reported via a questionnaire on acquired risk factors for venous thrombosis. 	 OBJECTIVE
Three months after discontinuation of the anticoagulant therapy, all patients and controls were interviewed, a blood sample was taken, and DNA was isolated to ascertain the factor V Leiden and prothrombin 20210A mutations. 	 OBJECTIVE
Risk of venous thrombosis. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
The overall risk of venous thrombosis was increased 7-fold in patients with a malignancy (odds ratio [OR], 6.7; 95% confidence interval [CI], 5.2-8.6) vs persons without malignancy. 	 RESULTS
Patients with hematological malignancies had the highest risk of venous thrombosis, adjusted for age and sex (adjusted OR, 28.0; 95% CI, 4.0-199.7), followed by lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer. 	 RESULTS
The risk of venous thrombosis was highest in the first few months after the diagnosis of malignancy (adjusted OR, 53.5; 95% CI, 8.6-334.3). 	 RESULTS
Patients with cancer with distant metastases had a higher risk vs patients without distant metastases (adjusted OR, 19.8; 95% CI, 2.6-149.1). 	 RESULTS
Carriers of the factor V Leiden mutation who also had cancer had a 12-fold increased risk vs individuals without cancer and factor V Leiden (adjusted OR, 12.1; 95% CI, 1.6-88.1). 	 RESULTS
Similar results were indirectly calculated for the prothrombin 20210A mutation in patients with cancer. 	 RESULTS
Patients with cancer have a highly increased risk of venous thrombosis especially in the first few months after diagnosis and in the presence of distant metastases. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Carriers of the factor V Leiden and prothrombin 20210A mutations appear to have an even higher risk. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Familial hiatal hernia has only rarely been documented. 	 BACKGROUND
To describe the pattern of inheritance of familial hiatal hernia within an affected family. 	 AIMS
Thirty eight members of a family pedigree across five generations. 	 SUBJECTS
All family members were interviewed and investigated by barium meal for evidence of a hiatal hernia. 	 METHODS
Twenty three of 38 family members had radiological evidence of a hiatal hernia. 	 RESULTS
No individual with a hiatal hernia was born to unaffected parents. 	 RESULTS
In one case direct male to male transmission was shown. 	 RESULTS
Familial inheritance of hiatal hernia does occur. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Evidence of direct male to male transmission points to an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Traditional T2 weighted MR imaging results are non-specific for the extent of underlying white matter structural abnormalities present in late life depression (LLD). 	 BACKGROUND
Diffusion tensor imaging provides a unique opportunity to investigate the extent and nature of structural injury, but has been limited by examining only a subset of regions of interest (ROI) and by confounds common to the study of an elderly population, including comorbid vascular pathology. 	 BACKGROUND
Furthermore, comprehensive correlation of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) measurements, including axial and radial diffusivity measurements, has not been demonstrated in the late life depression population. 	 BACKGROUND
51 depressed and 16 non-depressed, age- and cerebrovascular risk factor-matched elderly subjects underwent traditional anatomic T1 and T2 weight imaging, as well as DTI. 	 METHODS
The DTI data were skeletonized using tract based spatial statistics (TBSS), and both regional and global analyses were performed. 	 METHODS
Widespread structural abnormalities within white matter were detected in the LLD group, accounting for age, gender and education and matched for cerebrovascular risk factors and global T2 white matter hyperintensities (T2WMH). 	 RESULTS
Regional differences were most prominent in uncinate and cingulate white matter and were generally characterized by an increase in radial diffusivity. 	 RESULTS
Age-related changes particularly in the cingulate bundle were more advanced in individuals with LLD relative to controls. 	 RESULTS
Regression analysis demonstrated significant correlations of regional fractional anisotropy and radial diffusivity with five different neuropsychological factor scores. 	 RESULTS
analysis demonstrated a greater extent of white matter abnormalities in LLD not responsive to treatment, as compared to controls. 	 TBSS
White matter integrity is compromised in late life depression, largely manifested by increased radial diffusivity in specific regions, suggesting underlying myelin injury. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A possible mechanism for underlying myelin injury is chronic white matter ischemia related to intrinsic cerebrovascular disease. 	 CONCLUSIONS
In some regions such as the cingulate bundle, the white matter injury related to late life depression appears to be independent of and compounded by age-related changes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The correlations with neuropsychological testing indicate the essential effects of white matter injury on functional status. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Lastly, response to treatment may depend on the extent of white matter injury, suggesting a need for intact functional networks. 	 CONCLUSIONS
It has been suggested that identified risk factors for endometrial cancer operate through a single etiologic pathway, i.e., exposure to relatively high levels of unopposed estrogen (estrogen in the absence of progestins). 	 BACKGROUND
Only a few studies, however, have addressed this issue directly. 	 BACKGROUND
We assessed the risk of developing endometrial cancer among both premenopausal and postmenopausal women in relation to the circulating levels of steroid hormones and sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG). 	 PURPOSE
The independent effect of hormones was assessed after adjustment for other known risk factors. 	 PURPOSE
The data used in the analysis are from a case-control study conducted in five geographic regions in the United States. 	 METHODS
Incident cases were newly diagnosed during the period from June 1, 1987, through May 15, 1990. 	 METHODS
The case patients, aged 20-74 years, were matched to control subjects by age, race, and geographic region. 	 METHODS
The community control subjects were obtained by random-digit-dialing procedures (for subjects 20-64 years old) and from files of the Health Care Financing Administration (for subjects > or = 65 years old). 	 METHODS
Additional control subjects who were having a hysterectomy performed for benign conditions were obtained from the participating centers. 	 METHODS
Women reporting use of exogenous estrogens or oral contraceptives within 6 months of interview were excluded, resulting in 68 case patients and 107 control subjects among premenopausal women and 208 case patients and 209 control subjects among postmenopausal women. 	 METHODS
The hormone analyses were performed on blood samples obtained from case patients or from hysterectomy control subjects before surgery. 	 METHODS
The odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were estimated by use of an unconditional logistic regression analysis after we controlled for matching variables and potential confounders. 	 METHODS
All P values were two-sided. 	 METHODS
High circulating levels of androstenedione were associated with 3.6-fold and 2.8-fold increased risks among premenopausal and postmenopausal women, respectively, after adjustment for other factors (P for trend = .01 and < .001, respectively). 	 RESULTS
Risks related to other hormone fractions varied by menopausal status. 	 RESULTS
Among postmenopausal women, a reduced risk was associated with high SHBG levels and persisted after adjustment was made for obesity and other factors (OR = 0.51; 95% CI = 0.27-0.95). 	 RESULTS
High estrone levels were associated with increased risk (OR = 3.8; 95% CI = 2.2-6.6), although adjustment for other risk factors (particularly body mass index) diminished the effect (OR = 2.2; 95% CI = 1.2-4.4). 	 RESULTS
Albumin-bound estradiol (E2), a marker of the bioavailable fraction, also remained an important risk factor after adjustment was made for other factors (OR = 2.0; 95% CI = 1.0-3.9). 	 RESULTS
In contrast, high concentrations of total, free, and albumin-bound E2 were unrelated to increased risk in premenopausal women. 	 RESULTS
In both premenopausal and postmenopausal groups, risks associated with obesity and fat distribution were not affected by adjustment for hormones. 	 RESULTS
High endogenous levels of unopposed estrogen are related to increased risk of endometrial cancer, but their independence from other risk factors is inconsistent with being a common underlying biologic pathway through which all risk factors for endometrial cancer operate. 	 CONCLUSION
Further research should focus on alternative endocrinologic mechanisms for risk associated with obesity and body fat distribution and for the biologic relevance of the increased risk associated with androstenedione in both premenopausal and postmenopausal disease. 	 IMPLICATIONS
Although cigarette smoking, excessive alcohol drinking, obesity, and several other well-studied unhealthy lifestyle-related factors each have been linked to the risk of multiple chronic diseases and premature death, little is known about the combined impact on mortality outcomes, in particular among Chinese and other non-Western populations. 	 BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to quantify the overall impact of lifestyle-related factors beyond that of active cigarette smoking and alcohol consumption on all-cause and cause-specific mortality in Chinese women. 	 BACKGROUND
We used data from the Shanghai Women's Health Study, an ongoing population-based prospective cohort study in China. 	 METHODS
Participants included 71,243 women aged 40 to 70 years enrolled during 1996-2000 who never smoked or drank alcohol regularly. 	 METHODS
A healthy lifestyle score was created on the basis of five lifestyle-related factors shown to be independently associated with mortality outcomes (normal weight, lower waist-hip ratio, daily exercise, never exposed to spouse's smoking, higher daily fruit and vegetable intake). 	 METHODS
The score ranged from zero (least healthy) to five (most healthy) points. 	 METHODS
During an average follow-up of 9 years, 2,860 deaths occurred, including 775 from cardiovascular disease (CVD) and 1,351 from cancer. 	 RESULTS
Adjusted hazard ratios for mortality decreased progressively with an increasing number of healthy lifestyle factors. 	 RESULTS
Compared to women with a score of zero, hazard ratios (95% confidence intervals) for women with four to five factors were 0.57 (0.44-0.74) for total mortality, 0.29 (0.16-0.54) for CVD mortality, and 0.76 (0.54-1.06) for cancer mortality. 	 RESULTS
The inverse association between the healthy lifestyle score and mortality was seen consistently regardless of chronic disease status at baseline. 	 RESULTS
The population attributable risks for not having 4-5 healthy lifestyle factors were 33% for total deaths, 59% for CVD deaths, and 19% for cancer deaths. 	 RESULTS
In this first study, to our knowledge, to quantify the combined impact of lifestyle-related factors on mortality outcomes in Chinese women, a healthier lifestyle pattern-including being of normal weight, lower central adiposity, participation in physical activity, nonexposure to spousal smoking, and higher fruit and vegetable intake-was associated with reductions in total and cause-specific mortality among lifetime nonsmoking and nondrinking women, supporting the importance of overall lifestyle modification in disease prevention. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Please see later in the article for the Editors' Summary. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The purpose of our study was to investigate alterations of white matter integrity in adults with major depressive disorder (MDD) using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). 	 OBJECTIVE
We performed diffusion tensor imaging with a 3T MRI scanner on 45 patients with major depression and 45 healthy controls matched for age, sex and education. 	 METHODS
Using a voxel-based analysis, we measured the fractional anisotropy (FA), and we investigated the differences between the patient and control groups. 	 METHODS
We examined the correlations between the microstructure abnormalities of white matter and symptom severity, age of illness onset and cumulative illness duration, respectively. 	 METHODS
We found a significant decrease in FA in the left hemisphere, including the anterior limb of the internal capsule and the inferior parietal portion of the superior longitudinal fasciculus, in patients with MDD compared with healthy controls. 	 RESULTS
Diffusion tensor imaging measures in the left anterior limb of the internal capsule were negatively related to the severity of depressive symptoms, even after we controlled for age and sex. 	 RESULTS
Our findings provide new evidence of microstructural changes of white matter in non-late-onset adult depression. 	 CONCLUSION
Our results complement those observed in late-life depression and support the hypothesis that the disruption of cortical- subcortical circuit integrity may be involved in the etiology of major depressive disorder. 	 CONCLUSION
To observe the therapeutic effect of "Xingnao Kaiqiao Zhenfa" (Acupuncture Technique for Restoring Consciousness) in the treatment of post-stroke depression. 	 OBJECTIVE
A total of 256 stroke patients were divided into acupuncture group (n = 180, male 138, female 42) and medication group (n = 76, male 57 and female 19) according to their visiting sequence to our hospital. 	 METHODS
Acupoints used were Neiguan (PC 6), Renzhong (GV 26), Baihui (GV 20), Yintang (EX-HN 3) and Sanyinjiao (SP 6,the affected side) and the needles were retained for 20 min every time. 	 METHODS
Patients of medication group were asked to take Amitriptyline (50 mg/d at first, 200 mg/d). 	 METHODS
Acupuncture treatment was conducted twice daily, and after one month's treatment the therapeutic effect was evaluated. 	 METHODS
Self-Rating Depression Scale (SDS) and Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HRSD) were used to assess the patient's state of depression. 	 METHODS
After the treatment, of the 180 and 76 cases in acupuncture and medication groups, 31 (17.2%) and 13 (17.1%) were cured, 73 (40.6%) and 18 (23.7%) had a marked improvement in their depression state, 27 (15.0%) and 12 (15.8%) had an improvement, 49 (27.2%) and 33 (43.4%) failed, with the effective rates being 72.8% and 56.6% respectively. 	 RESULTS
The markedly effective rate and the total effective rate of acupuncture group were significantly higher than those of medication group (P < 0.05). 	 RESULTS
After the treatment, the total scores of SDS and HRSD and the severity index of two groups decreased pronouncedly in comparison with those of their individual pre-treatment; and the therapeutic effects of acupuncture group were significantly better than those of medication group in reducing SDS, HRSD and severity index (P < 0 .05). 	 RESULTS
In addition, the decreased values of depression, pessimistic mood and irritability of acupuncture group were all bigger than those of medication group (P < 0.05). 	 RESULTS
No significant difference was found between two groups in the decreased value of insomnia (P > 0.05). 	 RESULTS
"Acupuncture Technique for Restoring Consciousness" can effectively improve depression patients' symptoms and the therapeutic effect of acupuncture is markedly superior to that of medication for post-stroke patients. 	 CONCLUSION
Statins are commonly used against arteriosclerotic disease, but recent retrospective analyses have suggested that statins also prevent cancer. 	 BACKGROUND
The aim of this systematic review is to verify the vitro anti-tumor effects of statins on head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. 	 BACKGROUND
Studies were gathered by searching Cochrane, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, and PubMed, up until May 9, 2015, with no time or language restrictions. 	 METHODS
Only in vitro studies that discuss the effect of statins on head and neck carcinoma were selected. 	 METHODS
Of 153 identified papers, 14 studies met the inclusion criteria. 	 RESULTS
These studies demonstrated that statins had a significant effect on head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cell lines and influenced cell viability, cell cycle, cell death, and protein expression levels involved in pathways of carcinogenesis, which corroborates with the potential in vitro anti-tumor effects. 	 RESULTS
It provides highlights about the biological mechanisms of statins used alone or associated with traditional therapy for cancer. 	 RESULTS
Though there are few studies on the topic, currently available evidence suggests that statins shows that preclinical experiments supports the potentiality of statin as an adjuvant agent in chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy approaches routinely used in the management of HNSCC and should undergo further clinical assessment. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a critical activator of inflammation and the innate immune system. 	 BACKGROUND
However, mtDNA level has not been tested for its role as a biomarker in the intensive care unit (ICU). 	 BACKGROUND
We hypothesized that circulating cell-free mtDNA levels would be associated with mortality and improve risk prediction in ICU patients. 	 BACKGROUND
Analyses of mtDNA levels were performed on blood samples obtained from two prospective observational cohort studies of ICU patients (the Brigham and Women's Hospital Registry of Critical Illness [BWH RoCI, n = 200] and Molecular Epidemiology of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome [ME ARDS, n = 243]). 	 METHODS
mtDNA levels in plasma were assessed by measuring the copy number of the NADH dehydrogenase 1 gene using quantitative real-time PCR. 	 METHODS
Medical ICU patients with an elevated mtDNA level (≥3,200 copies/µl plasma) had increased odds of dying within 28 d of ICU admission in both the BWH RoCI (odds ratio [OR] 7.5, 95% CI 3.6-15.8, p = 1×10(-7)) and ME ARDS (OR 8.4, 95% CI 2.9-24.2, p = 9×10(-5)) cohorts, while no evidence for association was noted in non-medical ICU patients. 	 RESULTS
The addition of an elevated mtDNA level improved the net reclassification index (NRI) of 28-d mortality among medical ICU patients when added to clinical models in both the BWH RoCI (NRI 79%, standard error 14%, p<1×10(-4)) and ME ARDS (NRI 55%, standard error 20%, p = 0.007) cohorts. 	 RESULTS
In the BWH RoCI cohort, those with an elevated mtDNA level had an increased risk of death, even in analyses limited to patients with sepsis or acute respiratory distress syndrome. 	 RESULTS
Study limitations include the lack of data elucidating the concise pathological roles of mtDNA in the patients, and the limited numbers of measurements for some of biomarkers. 	 RESULTS
Increased mtDNA levels are associated with ICU mortality, and inclusion of mtDNA level improves risk prediction in medical ICU patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Our data suggest that mtDNA could serve as a viable plasma biomarker in medical ICU patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Fructosamine is a glycemic biomarker which may be useful for indication and control of diabetes respectively. 	 CONTEXT
The objective of the study was to evaluate fructosamine as an indicator of hyperglycaemia and glucose control in subjects with diabetes. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING & PATIENTS From the AMORIS cohort, subjects with serum glucose, fructosamine and HbA1c from the same examination were studied cross-sectionally and longitudinally (n = 10,987; 5,590 overnight-fasting). 	 OBJECTIVE
The guidelines of the American Diabetes Association were followed for classification of prediabetes and diabetes. 	 OBJECTIVE
Separate analyses were performed in patients with a newly detected or a known diagnosis of type 1 or type 2 diabetes respectively. 	 OBJECTIVE
All three biomarkers were strongly correlated. 	 RESULTS
With regard to the association between fructosamine and HbA1c Pearson linear correlation coefficients in the range of 0.67-0.75 were observed in fasting and non-fasting subjects with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. 	 RESULTS
Analyses of glucose control in fasting patients with type 2 diabetes having all three biomarkers measured at three separate occasions within on average 290 days of the index examination showed similar trends over time for glucose, fructosamine and HbA1c. 	 RESULTS
Discrimination of subjects with and without diabetes across the range of fructosamine levels was good (area under curve (AUC) 0.91-0.95) and a fructosamine level of 2.5 mmol/L classified subjects to diabetes with a sensitivity of 61% and a specificity of 97%. 	 RESULTS
Fructosamine is closely associated with HbA1c and glucose respectively and may be a useful biomarker of hyperglycaemia and glucose control in clinical and epidemiological studies. 	 CONCLUSIONS
One key target of the United Nations Millennium Development goals is to reduce the prevalence of underweight among children younger than 5 years by half between 1990 and 2015. 	 CONTEXT
To estimate trends in childhood underweight by geographic regions of the world. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Time series study of prevalence of underweight, defined as weight 2 SDs below the mean weight for age of the National Center for Health Statistics and World Health Organization (WHO) reference population. 	 OBJECTIVE
National prevalence rates derived from the WHO Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition, which includes data on approximately 31 million children younger than 5 years who participated in 419 national nutritional surveys in 139 countries from 1965 through 2002. 	 OBJECTIVE
Linear mixed-effects modeling was used to estimate prevalence rates and numbers of underweight children by region in 1990 and 2015 and to calculate the changes (ie, increase or decrease) to these values between 1990 and 2015. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Worldwide, underweight prevalence was projected to decline from 26.5% in 1990 to 17.6% in 2015, a change of -34% (95% confidence interval [CI], -43% to -23%). 	 RESULTS
In developed countries, the prevalence was estimated to decrease from 1.6% to 0.9%, a change of -41% (95% CI, -92% to 343%). 	 RESULTS
In developing regions, the prevalence was forecasted to decline from 30.2% to 19.3%, a change of -36% (95% CI, -45% to -26%). 	 RESULTS
In Africa, the prevalence of underweight was forecasted to increase from 24.0% to 26.8%, a change of 12% (95% CI, 8%-16%). 	 RESULTS
In Asia, the prevalence was estimated to decrease from 35.1% to 18.5%, a change of -47% (95% CI, -58% to -34%). 	 RESULTS
Worldwide, the number of underweight children was projected to decline from 163.8 million in 1990 to 113.4 million in 2015, a change of -31% (95% CI, -40% to -20%). 	 RESULTS
Numbers are projected to decrease in all subregions except the subregions of sub-Saharan, Eastern, Middle, and Western Africa, which are expected to experience substantial increases in the number of underweight children. 	 RESULTS
An overall improvement in the global situation is anticipated; however, neither the world as a whole, nor the developing regions, are expected to achieve the Millennium Development goals. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This is largely due to the deteriorating situation in Africa where all subregions, except Northern Africa, are expected to fail to meet the goal. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Many observational studies have shown that physical activity reduces the risk of cognitive decline; however, evidence from randomized trials is lacking. 	 CONTEXT
To determine whether physical activity reduces the rate of cognitive decline among older adults at risk. 	 OBJECTIVE
Randomized controlled trial of a 24-week physical activity intervention conducted between 2004 and 2007 in metropolitan Perth, Western Australia. 	 DESIGN AND SETTING
Assessors of cognitive function were blinded to group membership. 	 DESIGN AND SETTING
We recruited volunteers who reported memory problems but did not meet criteria for dementia. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Three hundred eleven individuals aged 50 years or older were screened for eligibility, 89 were not eligible, and 52 refused to participate. 	 PARTICIPANTS
A total of 170 participants were randomized and 138 participants completed the 18-month assessment. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Participants were randomly allocated to an education and usual care group or to a 24-week home-based program of physical activity. 	 INTERVENTION
Change in Alzheimer Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog) scores (possible range, 0-70) over 18 months. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
In an intent-to-treat analysis, participants in the intervention group improved 0.26 points (95% confidence interval, -0.89 to 0.54) and those in the usual care group deteriorated 1.04 points (95% confidence interval, 0.32 to 1.82) on the ADAS-Cog at the end of the intervention. 	 RESULTS
The absolute difference of the outcome measure between the intervention and control groups was -1.3 points (95% confidence interval,-2.38 to -0.22) at the end of the intervention. 	 RESULTS
At 18 months, participants in the intervention group improved 0.73 points (95% confidence interval, -1.27 to 0.03) on the ADAS-Cog, and those in the usual care group improved 0.04 points (95% confidence interval, -0.46 to 0.88). 	 RESULTS
Word list delayed recall and Clinical Dementia Rating sum of boxes improved modestly as well, whereas word list total immediate recall, digit symbol coding, verbal fluency, Beck depression score, and Medical Outcomes 36-Item Short-Form physical and mental component summaries did not change significantly. 	 RESULTS
In this study of adults with subjective memory impairment, a 6-month program of physical activity provided a modest improvement in cognition over an 18-month follow-up period. 	 CONCLUSIONS
anzctr.org.au Identifier: ACTRN12605000136606. 	 TRIAL REGISTRATION
Production of the GTP-bound form of the Ran GTPase (RanGTP) around chromosomes induces spindle assembly by activating nuclear localization signal (NLS)-containing proteins. 	 BACKGROUND
Several NLS proteins have been identified as spindle assembly factors, but the complexity of the process led us to search for additional proteins with distinct roles in spindle assembly. 	 BACKGROUND
We identify a chromatin-remodeling ATPase, CHD4, as a RanGTP-dependent microtubule (MT)-associated protein (MAP). 	 RESULTS
MT binding occurs via the region containing an NLS and chromatin-binding domains. 	 RESULTS
In Xenopus egg extracts and cultured cells, CHD4 largely dissociates from mitotic chromosomes and partially localizes to the spindle. 	 RESULTS
Immunodepletion of CHD4 from egg extracts significantly reduces the quantity of MTs produced around chromatin and prevents spindle assembly. 	 RESULTS
CHD4 RNAi in both HeLa and Drosophila S2 cells induces defects in spindle assembly and chromosome alignment in early mitosis, leading to chromosome missegregation. 	 RESULTS
Further analysis in egg extracts and in HeLa cells reveals that CHD4 is a RanGTP-dependent MT stabilizer. 	 RESULTS
Moreover, the CHD4-containing NuRD complex promotes organization of MTs into bipolar spindles in egg extracts. 	 RESULTS
Importantly, this function of CHD4 is independent of chromatin remodeling. 	 RESULTS
Our results uncover a new role for CHD4 as a MAP required for MT stabilization and involved in generating spindle bipolarity. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Patients with familial amyloid polyneuropathy, a rare hereditary form of amyloidosis, have progressive autonomic neuropathy. 	 BACKGROUND
The disease usually does not induce heart failure but is associated with sudden death, conduction disturbances, and an increased risk of complications during anesthesia. 	 BACKGROUND
Although cardiac sympathetic denervation has been clearly demonstrated, the postsynaptic status of the cardiac autonomic nervous system remains unelucidated. 	 BACKGROUND
Twenty-one patients were studied (age, 39+/-11 years; normal coronary arteries; left ventricular ejection fraction 68+/-9%). 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
To evaluate the density and affinity constants of myocardial muscarinic receptors, PET with (11)C-MQNB (methylquinuclidinyl benzilate), a specific hydrophilic antagonist, was used. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Cardiac beta-receptor functional efficiency was studied by the heart rate (HR) response to intravenous infusion of isoproterenol (5 minutes after 2 mg of atropine, 5, 10, and 15 ng/kg per minute during 5 minutes per step). 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
The mean muscarinic receptor density was higher in patients than in control subjects (B'(max), 35.5+/-8.9 versus 26.1+/-6.7 pmol/mL, P=0.003), without change in receptor affinity. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
The increase in HR after injection of atropine as well as of MQNB was lower in patients compared with control subjects despite a similar basal HR (DeltaHR after atropine, 11+/-21% versus 62+/-17%; P<0.001), consistent with parasympathetic denervation. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Incremental infusion of isoproterenol induced a similar increase in HR in patients and control subjects. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Cardiac autonomic denervation in familial amyloid polyneuropathy results in an upregulation of myocardial muscarinic receptors but without change in cardiac beta-receptor responsiveness to catecholamines. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) have an increased fracture risk despite having higher areal bone mineral density (aBMD). 	 PURPOSE
This study aimed to clarify the association between glycemic and insulin resistance status and bone microarchitecture, and whether pentosidine and bone turnover markers play any roles in the association. 	 PURPOSE
A total of 2012 community-dwelling men aged ≥65years completed baseline measurements of spine aBMD, fasting plasma glucose (FPG) and serum insulin, hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), osteocalcin, type I procollagen N-terminal propeptide, type I collagen C-terminal crosslinking telopeptide, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase isoenzyme 5b, pentosidine, height and weight and an interview regarding past disease history. 	 METHODS
Homeostasis model assessment-insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) was also calculated. 	 METHODS
T2DM was defined as physician-diagnosed middle age or elderly-onset diabetes mellitus, or according to biochemical test results. 	 METHODS
To evaluate bone microarchitecture, trabecular bone score (TBS) was calculated at the same vertebrae as those used for aBMD measurement. 	 METHODS
After excluding participants who had a disease history and/or were taking medications affecting bone metabolism, 1683 men (age, 72.9±5.2years) were analyzed. 	 RESULTS
Men with T2DM had significantly higher aBMD compared to those without T2DM. 	 RESULTS
There was no significant difference in TBS. 	 RESULTS
However, FPG, HbA1c and HOMA-IR levels were significantly inversely correlated with TBS after adjusting for age, BMI and aBMD. 	 RESULTS
Multivariate linear regression analyses revealed that glycemic indices (FPG and HbA1c) were significantly associated with increased aBMD and decreased TBS, and that HOMA-IR was associated only with TBS. 	 RESULTS
These associations did not change after further adjusting for bone turnover makers and pentosidine levels. 	 RESULTS
Hyperglycemia and elevated insulin-resistance were associated with low TBS independently of bone turnover and pentosidine levels. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To examine the safety of using aliskiren combined with agents used to block the renin-angiotensin system. 	 OBJECTIVE
Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials. 	 DESIGN
Medline, Embase, the Cochrane Library, and two trial registries, published up to 7 May 2011. 	 DATA SOURCES
Published and unpublished randomised controlled trials that compared combined treatment using aliskiren and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers with monotherapy using these agents for at least four weeks and that provided numerical data on the adverse event outcomes of hyperkalaemia and acute kidney injury. 	 STUDY SELECTION
A random effects model was used to calculate pooled risk ratios and 95% confidence intervals for these outcomes. 	 STUDY SELECTION
10 randomised controlled studies (4814 participants) were included in the analysis. 	 RESULTS
Combination therapy with aliskiren and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers significantly increased the risk of hyperkalaemia compared with monotherapy using angiotensin converting enzymes or angiotensin receptor blockers (relative risk 1.58, 95% confidence interval 1.24 to 2.02) or aliskiren alone (1.67, 1.01 to 2.79). 	 RESULTS
The risk of acute kidney injury did not differ significantly between the combined therapy and monotherapy groups (1.14, 0.68 to 1.89). 	 RESULTS
Use of aliskerin in combination with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers is associated with an increased risk for hyperkalaemia. 	 CONCLUSION
The combined use of these agents warrants careful monitoring of serum potassium levels. 	 CONCLUSION
Endometrial cancer incidence is continuing to rise in the wake of the current ageing and obesity epidemics. 	 BACKGROUND
Much of the risk for endometrial cancer development is influenced by the environment and lifestyle. 	 BACKGROUND
Accumulating evidence suggests that the epigenome serves as the interface between the genome and the environment and that hypermethylation of stem cell polycomb group target genes is an epigenetic hallmark of cancer. 	 BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to determine the functional role of epigenetic factors in endometrial cancer development. 	 BACKGROUND
Epigenome-wide methylation analysis of >27,000 CpG sites in endometrial cancer tissue samples (n = 64) and control samples (n = 23) revealed that HAND2 (a gene encoding a transcription factor expressed in the endometrial stroma) is one of the most commonly hypermethylated and silenced genes in endometrial cancer. 	 RESULTS
A novel integrative epigenome-transcriptome-interactome analysis further revealed that HAND2 is the hub of the most highly ranked differential methylation hotspot in endometrial cancer. 	 RESULTS
These findings were validated using candidate gene methylation analysis in multiple clinical sample sets of tissue samples from a total of 272 additional women. 	 RESULTS
Increased HAND2 methylation was a feature of premalignant endometrial lesions and was seen to parallel a decrease in RNA and protein levels. 	 RESULTS
Furthermore, women with high endometrial HAND2 methylation in their premalignant lesions were less likely to respond to progesterone treatment. 	 RESULTS
HAND2 methylation analysis of endometrial secretions collected using high vaginal swabs taken from women with postmenopausal bleeding specifically identified those patients with early stage endometrial cancer with both high sensitivity and high specificity (receiver operating characteristics area under the curve = 0.91 for stage 1A and 0.97 for higher than stage 1A). 	 RESULTS
Finally, mice harbouring a Hand2 knock-out specifically in their endometrium were shown to develop precancerous endometrial lesions with increasing age, and these lesions also demonstrated a lack of PTEN expression. 	 RESULTS
HAND2 methylation is a common and crucial molecular alteration in endometrial cancer that could potentially be employed as a biomarker for early detection of endometrial cancer and as a predictor of treatment response. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The true clinical utility of HAND2 DNA methylation, however, requires further validation in prospective studies. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Please see later in the article for the Editors' Summary. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Artemisinin derivatives used in recently introduced combination therapies (ACTs) for Plasmodium falciparum malaria significantly lower patient infectiousness and have the potential to reduce population-level transmission of the parasite. 	 BACKGROUND
With the increased interest in malaria elimination, understanding the impact on transmission of ACT and other antimalarial drugs with different pharmacodynamics becomes a key issue. 	 BACKGROUND
This study estimates the reduction in transmission that may be achieved by introducing different types of treatment for symptomatic P. falciparum malaria in endemic areas. 	 BACKGROUND
We developed a mathematical model to predict the potential impact on transmission outcomes of introducing ACT as first-line treatment for uncomplicated malaria in six areas of varying transmission intensity in Tanzania. 	 METHODS
We also estimated the impact that could be achieved by antimalarials with different efficacy, prophylactic time, and gametocytocidal effects. 	 METHODS
Rates of treatment, asymptomatic infection, and symptomatic infection in the six study areas were estimated using the model together with data from a cross-sectional survey of 5,667 individuals conducted prior to policy change from sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine to ACT. 	 METHODS
The effects of ACT and other drug types on gametocytaemia and infectiousness to mosquitoes were independently estimated from clinical trial data. 	 RESULTS
Predicted percentage reductions in prevalence of infection and incidence of clinical episodes achieved by ACT were highest in the areas with low initial transmission. 	 RESULTS
A 53% reduction in prevalence of infection was seen if 100% of current treatment was switched to ACT in the area where baseline slide-prevalence of parasitaemia was lowest (3.7%), compared to an 11% reduction in the highest-transmission setting (baseline slide prevalence = 57.1%). 	 RESULTS
Estimated percentage reductions in incidence of clinical episodes were similar. 	 RESULTS
The absolute size of the public health impact, however, was greater in the highest-transmission area, with 54 clinical episodes per 100 persons per year averted compared to five per 100 persons per year in the lowest-transmission area. 	 RESULTS
High coverage was important. 	 RESULTS
Reducing presumptive treatment through improved diagnosis substantially reduced the number of treatment courses required per clinical episode averted in the lower-transmission settings although there was some loss of overall impact on transmission. 	 RESULTS
An efficacious antimalarial regimen with no specific gametocytocidal properties but a long prophylactic time was estimated to be more effective at reducing transmission than a short-acting ACT in the highest-transmission setting. 	 RESULTS
Our results suggest that ACTs have the potential for transmission reductions approaching those achieved by insecticide-treated nets in lower-transmission settings. 	 CONCLUSIONS
partner drugs and nonartemisinin regimens with longer prophylactic times could result in a larger impact in higher-transmission settings, although their long term benefit must be evaluated in relation to the risk of development of parasite resistance. 	 ACT
Impulsivity and inattention related to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) may increase food intake and, consequently, weight gain. 	 OBJECTIVE
However, findings on the association between obesity/overweight and ADHD are mixed. 	 OBJECTIVE
The authors conducted a meta-analysis to estimate this association. 	 OBJECTIVE
A broad range of databases was searched through Aug. 31, 2014. 	 METHOD
Unpublished studies were also obtained. 	 METHOD
Study quality was rated with the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale. 	 METHOD
Random-effects models were used. 	 METHOD
Forty-two studies that included a total of 728,136 individuals (48,161 ADHD subjects; 679,975 comparison subjects) were retained. 	 RESULTS
A significant association between obesity and ADHD was found for both children (odds ratio=1.20, 95% CI=1.05-1.37) and adults (odds ratio=1.55, 95% CI=1.32-1.81). 	 RESULTS
The pooled prevalence of obesity was increased by about 70% in adults with ADHD (28.2%, 95% CI=22.8-34.4) compared with those without ADHD (16.4%, 95% CI=13.4-19.9), and by about 40% in children with ADHD (10.3%, 95% CI=7.9-13.3) compared with those without ADHD (7.4%, 95% CI=5.4-10.1). 	 RESULTS
The significant association between ADHD and obesity remained when limited to studies 1) reporting odds ratios adjusted for possible confounding factors; 2) diagnosing ADHD by direct interview; and 3) using directly measured height and weight. 	 RESULTS
Gender, study setting, study country, and study quality did not moderate the association between obesity and ADHD. 	 RESULTS
was also significantly associated with overweight. 	 ADHD
Individuals medicated for ADHD were not at higher risk of obesity. 	 ADHD
This study provides meta-analytic evidence for a significant association between ADHD and obesity/overweight. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Further research should address possible underlying mechanisms and the long-term effects of ADHD treatments on weight in individuals with both ADHD and obesity. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The authors sought to determine innate immune system activation following psychosocial stress in patients with major depression and increased early life stress. 	 OBJECTIVE
Plasma interleukin (IL)-6, lymphocyte subsets, and DNA binding of nuclear factor (NF)-kB in peripheral blood mononuclear cells were compared in medically healthy male subjects with current major depression and increased early life stress (N=14) versus nondepressed male comparison subjects (N=14) before and after completion of the Trier Social Stress Test. 	 METHOD
Trier Social Stress Test-induced increases in IL-6 and NF-kappaB DNA-binding were greater in major depression patients with increased early life stress and independently correlated with depression severity, but not early life stress. 	 RESULTS
Natural killer (NK) cell percentages also increased following stress. 	 RESULTS
However, there were no differences between groups and no correlation between NK cell percentage and stress-induced NF-kappaB DNA-binding or IL-6. 	 RESULTS
Male major depression patients with increased early life stress exhibit enhanced inflammatory responsiveness to psychosocial stress, providing preliminary indication of a link between major depression, early life stress and adverse health outcomes in diseases associated with inflammation. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Recent evidence suggests that cardiac progenitor cells (CPCs) may improve cardiac function after injury. 	 AIMS
The underlying mechanisms are indirect, but their mediators remain unidentified. 	 AIMS
Exosomes and other secreted membrane vesicles, hereafter collectively referred to as extracellular vesicles (EVs), act as paracrine signalling mediators. 	 AIMS
Here, we report that EVs secreted by human CPCs are crucial cardioprotective agents. 	 AIMS
CPCs were derived from atrial appendage explants from patients who underwent heart valve surgery. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
CPC-conditioned medium (CM) inhibited apoptosis in mouse HL-1 cardiomyocytic cells, while enhancing tube formation in human umbilical vein endothelial cells. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
These effects were abrogated by depleting CM of EVs. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
They were reproduced by EVs secreted by CPCs, but not by those secreted by human dermal fibroblasts. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Transmission electron microscopy and nanoparticle tracking analysis showed most EVs to be 30-90 nm in diameter, the size of exosomes, although smaller and larger vesicles were also present. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
MicroRNAs most highly enriched in EVs secreted by CPCs compared with fibroblasts included miR-210, miR-132, and miR-146a-3p. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
miR-210 down-regulated its known targets, ephrin A3 and PTP1b, inhibiting apoptosis in cardiomyocytic cells. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
miR-132 down-regulated its target, RasGAP-p120, enhancing tube formation in endothelial cells. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Infarcted hearts injected with EVs from CPCs, but not from fibroblasts, exhibited less cardiomyocyte apoptosis, enhanced angiogenesis, and improved LV ejection fraction (0.8 ± 6.8 vs. -21.3 ± 4.5%; P < 0.05) compared with those injected with control medium. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
EVs are the active component of the paracrine secretion by human CPCs. 	 CONCLUSION
As a cell-free approach, EVs could circumvent many of the limitations of cell transplantation. 	 CONCLUSION
OF REVIEW Recent preclinical and clinical studies revealed that the semirandom insertion of transgenes into chromosomal DNA of hematopoietic cells may induce clonal competition, which potentially may even trigger leukemia or sarcoma. 	 PURPOSE
Insertional mutagenesis caused by gene vectors has thus led to major uncertainty among those developing advanced hematopoietic cell therapies. 	 PURPOSE
This review summarizes novel studies of underlying mechanisms; these studies have demonstrated the possibility of improved gene vector biosafety and generated new insights into stem cell biology. 	 PURPOSE
The characteristic insertion pattern of various retroviral gene vector systems may be explained by properties of the viral integrase and associated cellular cofactors. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Cell culture assays and animal models, including disease-specific and cancer-prone mouse models, are emerging that reveal the contributions of vector features and systemic factors to induction of clonal imbalance. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Databases summarizing vector insertion sites in dominant hematopoietic clones are evolving as new tools to identify genes that regulate clonal homeostasis. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Mechanistic studies of insertional mutagenesis by random gene vector insertion will lead to improved tools for advanced hematopoietic cell therapy. 	 SUMMARY
Simultaneously, fascinating insights into gene networks that regulate cell fitness will be generated, with important consequences for the fields of hematology, oncology and regenerative medicine. 	 SUMMARY
Tanzania has a well-developed network of commercial ITN retailers. 	 BACKGROUND
In 2004, the government introduced a voucher subsidy for pregnant women and, in mid 2005, helped distribute free nets to under-fives in small number of districts, including Rufiji on the southern coast, during a child health campaign. 	 BACKGROUND
Contributions of these multiple insecticide-treated net delivery strategies existing at the same time and place to coverage in a poor rural community were assessed. 	 BACKGROUND
Cross-sectional household survey in 6,331 members of randomly selected 1,752 households of 31 rural villages of Demographic Surveillance System in Rufiji district, Southern Tanzania was conducted in 2006. 	 METHODS
A questionnaire was administered to every consenting respondent about net use, treatment status and delivery mechanism. 	 METHODS
Net use was 62.7% overall, 87.2% amongst infants (0 to 1 year), 81.8% amongst young children (>1 to 5 years), 54.5% amongst older children (6 to 15 years) and 59.6% amongst adults (>15 years). 	 FINDINGS
30.2% of all nets had been treated six months prior to interview. 	 FINDINGS
The biggest source of nets used by infants was purchase from the private sector with a voucher subsidy (41.8%). 	 FINDINGS
Half of nets used by young children (50.0%) and over a third of those used by older children (37.2%) were obtained free of charge through the vaccination campaign. 	 FINDINGS
The largest source of nets amongst the population overall was commercial purchase (45.1% use) and was the primary means for protecting adults (60.2% use). 	 FINDINGS
All delivery mechanisms, especially sale of nets at full market price, under-served the poorest but no difference in equity was observed between voucher-subsidized and freely distributed nets. 	 FINDINGS
All three delivery strategies enabled a poor rural community to achieve net coverage high enough to yield both personal and community level protection for the entire population. 	 CONCLUSION
Each of them reached their relevant target group and free nets only temporarily suppressed the net market, illustrating that in this setting that these are complementary rather than mutually exclusive approaches. 	 CONCLUSION
To determine whether individual fruits are differentially associated with risk of type 2 diabetes. 	 OBJECTIVE
Prospective longitudinal cohort study. 	 DESIGN
Health professionals in the United States. 	 SETTING
66,105 women from the Nurses' Health Study (1984-2008), 85,104 women from the Nurses' Health Study II (1991-2009), and 36,173 men from the Health Professionals Follow-up Study (1986-2008) who were free of major chronic diseases at baseline in these studies. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Incident cases of type 2 diabetes, identified through self report and confirmed by supplementary questionnaires. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
During 3,464,641 person years of follow-up, 12,198 participants developed type 2 diabetes. 	 RESULTS
After adjustment for personal, lifestyle, and dietary risk factors of diabetes, the pooled hazard ratio of type 2 diabetes for every three servings/week of total whole fruit consumption was 0.98 (95% confidence interval 0.97 [corrected] to 0.99). 	 RESULTS
With mutual adjustment of individual fruits, the pooled hazard ratios of type 2 diabetes for every three servings/week were 0.74 (0.66 to 0.83) for blueberries, 0.88 (0.83 to 0.93) for grapes and raisins, 0.89 (0.79 to 1.01) for prunes, 0.93 (0.90 to 0.96) for apples and pears, 0.95 (0.91 to 0.98) for bananas, 0.95 (0.91 to 0.99) for grapefruit, 0.97 (0.92 to 1.02) for peaches, plums, and apricots, 0.99 (0.95 to 1.03) for oranges, 1.03 (0.96 to 1.10) for strawberries, and 1.10 (1.02 to 1.18) for cantaloupe. 	 RESULTS
The pooled hazard ratio for the same increment in fruit juice consumption was 1.08 (1.05 to 1.11). 	 RESULTS
The associations with risk of type 2 diabetes differed significantly among individual fruits (P<0.001 in all cohorts). 	 RESULTS
Our findings suggest the presence of heterogeneity in the associations between individual fruit consumption and risk of type 2 diabetes. 	 CONCLUSION
Greater consumption of specific whole fruits, particularly blueberries, grapes, and apples, is significantly associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes, whereas greater consumption of fruit juice is associated with a higher risk. 	 CONCLUSION
MicroRNA-196 (miR-196), which is highly up-regulated in oral cancer cells, has been reported to be aberrantly expressed in several cancers; however, the significance of miR-196 in oral cancer has not yet been addressed. 	 BACKGROUND
Cellular functions in response to miR-196 modulation were examined, including cell growth, migration, invasion and radio/chemosensitivity. 	 METHODS
Algorithm-based studies were used to identify the regulatory target of miR-196. 	 METHODS
The miR-196 target gene and downstream molecular mechanisms were confirmed by RT-qPCR, western blot, luciferase reporter and confocal microscopy analyses. 	 METHODS
miR-196 expression was determined in paired cancer and adjacent normal tissues from oral cancer patients. 	 METHODS
Both miR-196a and miR-196b were highly over-expressed in the cancer tissue and correlated with lymph node metastasis (P = 0.001 and P = 0.006, respectively). 	 RESULTS
Functionally, miR-196 actively promoted cell migration and invasion without affecting cell growth. 	 RESULTS
Mechanistically, miR-196 performed it's their function by inhibiting NME4 expression and further activating p-JNK, suppressing TIMP1, and augmenting MMP1/9. 	 RESULTS
miR-196 contributes to oral cancer by promoting cell migration and invasion. 	 CONCLUSION
Clinically, miR-196a/b was significantly over-expressed in the cancer tissues and correlated with lymph node metastasis. 	 CONCLUSION
Thus, our findings provide new knowledge of the underlying mechanism of cancer metastasis. 	 CONCLUSION
miR-196 may serve as a promising marker for better oral cancer management. 	 CONCLUSION
Since November 2009, WHO recommends that adults infected with HIV should initiate antiretroviral therapy (ART) at CD4+ cell counts of ≤350 cells/µl rather than ≤200 cells/µl. 	 BACKGROUND
South Africa decided to adopt this strategy for pregnant and TB co-infected patients only. 	 BACKGROUND
We estimated the impact of fully adopting the new WHO guidelines on HIV epidemic dynamics and associated costs. 	 BACKGROUND
We used an established model of the transmission and control of HIV in specified sexual networks and healthcare settings. 	 METHODS
We quantified the model to represent Hlabisa subdistrict, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. 	 METHODS
We predicted the HIV epidemic dynamics, number on ART and program costs under the new guidelines relative to treating patients at ≤200 cells/µl for the next 30 years. 	 METHODS
During the first five years, the new WHO treatment guidelines require about 7% extra annual investments, whereas 28% more patients receive treatment. 	 RESULTS
Furthermore, there will be a more profound impact on HIV incidence, leading to relatively less annual costs after seven years. 	 RESULTS
The resulting cumulative net costs reach a break-even point after on average 16 years. 	 RESULTS
Our study strengthens the WHO recommendation of starting ART at ≤350 cells/µl for all HIV-infected patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Apart from the benefits associated with many life-years saved, a modest frontloading appears to lead to net savings within a limited time-horizon. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This finding is robust to alternative assumptions and foreseeable changes in ART prices and effectiveness. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Therefore, South Africa should aim at rapidly expanding its healthcare infrastructure to fully embrace the new WHO guidelines. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To identify factors affecting the short-term prognosis of patients with acutely exacerbated chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). 	 PURPOSE
The 590 patients having COPD as primary disease who were hospitalized in the pneumology unit of a university hospital from 1981 to 1990 were studied. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
A standardized protocol for the treatment of acutely exacerbated COPD was adopted for all the patients. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
The patient records were retrospectively analyzed by two observers, and 23 clinical and laboratory variables defining the patient status on admission were collected. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Age and arterial gas data were also taken into account, and the outcome mortality was recorded. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Interobserver reproducibility was tested by computing the kappa coefficient and Spearman's rho for dichotomous and continuous variables, respectively. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
The relationship of clinical and laboratory factors to the outcome was assessed first by univariate analysis and then by a logistic regression analysis assessing the independent predictive role of variables previously shown to be univariately correlated with mortality. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
The mortality rate was 14.4%. 	 RESULTS
The logistic regression analysis identified four independent predictors of death: age (odds ratio [OR] 1.07; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.04 to 1.11), alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient greater than 41 mm Hg (OR 2.33; 95% CI 1.39 to 3.90), ventricular arrhythmias (OR 1.91; 95% CI 1.10 to 3.31), and atrial fibrillation (OR 2.27; 95% CI 1.14 to 4.51). 	 RESULTS
Patients with acutely exacerbated COPD having a high risk of death can be identified at the time of admission. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Variables reflecting heart dysfunction are important determinants of this risk. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Among pulmonary function data, only alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient contributes to the predictive model. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To investigate the association between gastric cancer and prior infection with Helicobacter pylori. 	 OBJECTIVE
Case-control comparison of prevalence of IgG antibodies to H pylori in blood samples collected prospectively, before diagnosis of gastric cancer in the cases. 	 DESIGN
Presence of H pylori antibody (greater than 10 micrograms IgG/ml) determined by enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 	 DESIGN
29 men with a subsequent diagnosis of gastric cancer and 116 aged matched controls selected from over 22,000 middle aged men participating in two ongoing cohort studies (the British United Provident Association study and the Caerphilly collaborative heart disease study), who had provided blood samples during 1975-1982. 	 SUBJECTS
20 of the 29 cases (69%) and 54 of the 116 controls (47%) were positive for H pylori specific antibody. 	 RESULTS
The median specific IgG concentration was significantly higher in the cases than controls (90 micrograms/ml v 3.6 micrograms/ml, p less than 0.01). 	 RESULTS
The estimated odds ratio for the risk of gastric cancer in those with a history of infection with H pylori was 2.77 (95% confidence interval 1.04 to 7.97, 2p = 0.039). 	 RESULTS
H pylori infection may be an important cause of gastric cancer; between 35% and 55% of all cases may be associated with such an infection. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The objective of this study was to examine differences in cancer survival between socioeconomic groups in England, with particular attention to survival in the short term of follow-up. 	 UNLABELLED
Individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer between 1996 and 2004 in England were identified from cancer registry records. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Five-year cumulative relative survival and excess death rates were computed. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
For colon cancer there was a very high excess death rate in the first month of follow-up, and the excess death rate was highest in the socioeconomically deprived groups. 	 RESULTS
In subsequent periods, excess mortality rates were much lower and there was less socioeconomic variation. 	 RESULTS
The pattern of variation in excess death rates was generally similar in rectal cancer but the socioeconomic difference in death rates persisted several years longer. 	 RESULTS
If the excess death rates in the entire colorectal cancer patient population were the same as those observed in the most affluent socioeconomic quintile, the annual reduction would be 360 deaths in colon cancer and 336 deaths in rectal cancer patients. 	 RESULTS
These deaths occurred almost entirely in the first month and the first year after diagnosis. 	 RESULTS
Recent developments in the national cancer control agenda have included an increasing emphasis on outcome measures, with short-term cancer survival an operational measure of variation and progress in cancer control. 	 CONCLUSION
In providing clues to the nature of the survival differences between socioeconomic groups, the results presented here give strong support for this strategy. 	 CONCLUSION
cholesterol has a causal role in the development of cardiovascular disease. 	 BACKGROUND LDL
Improved understanding of the biological mechanisms that underlie the metabolism and regulation of LDL cholesterol might help to identify novel therapeutic targets. 	 BACKGROUND LDL
We therefore did a genome-wide association study of LDL-cholesterol concentrations. 	 BACKGROUND LDL
We used genome-wide association data from up to 11,685 participants with measures of circulating LDL-cholesterol concentrations across five studies, including data for 293 461 autosomal single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with a minor allele frequency of 5% or more that passed our quality control criteria. 	 METHODS
We also used data from a second genome-wide array in up to 4337 participants from three of these five studies, with data for 290,140 SNPs. 	 METHODS
We did replication studies in two independent populations consisting of up to 4979 participants. 	 METHODS
Statistical approaches, including meta-analysis and linkage disequilibrium plots, were used to refine association signals; we analysed pooled data from all seven populations to determine the effect of each SNP on variations in circulating LDL-cholesterol concentrations. 	 METHODS
In our initial scan, we found two SNPs (rs599839 [p=1.7x10(-15)] and rs4970834 [p=3.0x10(-11)]) that showed genome-wide statistical association with LDL cholesterol at chromosomal locus 1p13.3. 	 FINDINGS
The second genome screen found a third statistically associated SNP at the same locus (rs646776 [p=4.3x10(-9)]). 	 FINDINGS
Meta-analysis of data from all studies showed an association of SNPs rs599839 (combined p=1.2x10(-33)) and rs646776 (p=4.8x10(-20)) with LDL-cholesterol concentrations. 	 FINDINGS
SNPs rs599839 and rs646776 both explained around 1% of the variation in circulating LDL-cholesterol concentrations and were associated with about 15% of an SD change in LDL cholesterol per allele, assuming an SD of 1 mmol/L.   INTERPRETATION We found evidence for a novel locus for LDL cholesterol on chromosome 1p13.3. 	 FINDINGS
These results potentially provide insight into the biological mechanisms that underlie the regulation of LDL cholesterol and might help in the discovery of novel therapeutic targets for cardiovascular disease. 	 FINDINGS
Aedes aegypti, the major vector of dengue viruses, often breeds in water storage containers used by households without tap water supply, and occurs in high numbers even in dense urban areas. 	 BACKGROUND
We analysed the interaction between human population density and lack of tap water as a cause of dengue fever outbreaks with the aim of identifying geographic areas at highest risk. 	 BACKGROUND
We conducted an individual-level cohort study in a population of 75,000 geo-referenced households in Vietnam over the course of two epidemics, on the basis of dengue hospital admissions (n = 3,013). 	 METHODS
We applied space-time scan statistics and mathematical models to confirm the findings. 	 METHODS
We identified a surprisingly narrow range of critical human population densities between around 3,000 to 7,000 people/km² prone to dengue outbreaks. 	 RESULTS
In the study area, this population density was typical of villages and some peri-urban areas. 	 RESULTS
Scan statistics showed that areas with a high population density or adequate water supply did not experience severe outbreaks. 	 RESULTS
The risk of dengue was higher in rural than in urban areas, largely explained by lack of piped water supply, and in human population densities more often falling within the critical range. 	 RESULTS
Mathematical modeling suggests that simple assumptions regarding area-level vector/host ratios may explain the occurrence of outbreaks. 	 RESULTS
Rural areas may contribute at least as much to the dissemination of dengue fever as cities. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Improving water supply and vector control in areas with a human population density critical for dengue transmission could increase the efficiency of control efforts. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Please see later in the article for the Editors' Summary. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is now the most prevalent and debilitating disease affecting the Chinese population. 	 AIMS
The goal of the present manuscript was to analyse cardiovascular risk factors and the prevalence of non-fatal CVDs from data gathered from the 2007-2008 China National Diabetes and Metabolic Disorders Study. 	 AIMS
A nationally representative sample of 46 239 adults, 20 years of age or older, was randomly recruited using a multistage stratified design method. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Lifestyle factors, diagnosis of CVD, stroke, diabetes, and family history of each subject were collected, and an oral glucose tolerance test or a standard meal test was performed. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Various non-fatal CVDs were reported by the subjects. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
software was used to perform all weighted statistical analyses, with P < 0.05 considered statistically significant. 	 SUDAAN
The prevalence of coronary heart disease, stroke, and CVDs was 0.74, 1.07, and 1.78% in males; and 0.51, 0.60, and 1.10% in females, respectively. 	 SUDAAN
The presence of CVDs increased with age in both males and females. 	 SUDAAN
The prevalence of being overweight or obese, hypertension, dyslipidaemia, or hyperglycaemia was 36.67, 30.09, 67.43, and 26.69% in males; and 29.77, 24.79, 63.98, and 23.62% in females, respectively. 	 SUDAAN
In the total sample of 46 239 patients, the prevalence of one subject having 1, 2, 3, or ≥4 of the 5 defined risk factors (i.e. smoking, overweight or obese, hypertension, dyslipidaemia, or hyperglycaemia) was 31.17, 27.38, 17.76, and 10.19%, respectively. 	 SUDAAN
Following adjustment for gender and age, the odds ratio of CVDs for those who had 1, 2, 3, or ≥4 risk factors was 2.36, 4.24, 4.88, and 7.22, respectively, when compared with patients with no risk factors. 	 SUDAAN
Morbidity attributed to the five defined cardiovascular risk factors was high in the Chinese population, with multiple risk factors present in the same individual. 	 CONCLUSION
Therefore, reasonable prevention strategies should be designed to attenuate the rapid rise in cardiovascular morbidity. 	 CONCLUSION
The role of the diffusible messenger nitric oxide (NO) in the regulation of pain transmission is still a debate of matter, pro-nociceptive and/or anti-nociceptive. 	 BACKGROUND
S-Nitrosylation, the reversible post-translational modification of selective cysteine residues in proteins, has emerged as an important mechanism by which NO acts as a signaling molecule. 	 BACKGROUND
The occurrence of S-nitrosylation in the spinal cord and its targets that may modulate pain transmission remain unclarified. 	 BACKGROUND
The "biotin-switch" method and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry were employed for identifying S-nitrosylated proteins. 	 BACKGROUND
Here we show that actin was a major protein S-nitrosylated in the spinal cord by the NO donor, S-nitroso-N-acetyl-DL-penicillamine (SNAP). 	 RESULTS
Interestingly, actin was S-nitrosylated, more in the S2 fraction than in the P2 fraction of the spinal homogenate. 	 RESULTS
Treatment of PC12 cells with SNAP caused rapid S-nitrosylation of actin and inhibited dopamine release from the cells. 	 RESULTS
Just like cytochalasin B, which depolymerizes actin, SNAP decreased the amount of filamentous actin cytoskeleton just beneath the membrane. 	 RESULTS
The inhibition of dopamine release was not attenuated by inhibitors of soluble guanylyl cyclase and cGMP-dependent protein kinase. 	 RESULTS
