Therefore, we aimed to study the association of serum soluble corin with risk of poor outcomes within 3 months after stroke. 	 OBJECTIVE
We followed 522 stroke patients for 3 months to identify major disability, death and vascular events. 	 METHODS
Serum soluble corin was measured at baseline for all participants. 	 METHODS
Logistic regression was used to examine the associations of baseline serum soluble corin with outcomes of stroke, adjusting for age, sex, baseline NIHSS score, hours from onset to hospitalization, smoking, drinking, hypertension, diabetes, coronary heart disease, atrial fibrillation, family history of stroke, and stroke subtype. 	 METHODS
Patients with high corin had a significantly lower crude risk for the composite outcome of major disability or death (OR = 0.64, 95%CI: 0.43-0.96) than patients with low corin (the lowest tertile). 	 RESULTS
After adjustment for age and baseline NIHSS score, patients with high corin still had a significantly lower risk for the composite outcome of major disability or death (OR = 0.60, 95%CI: 0.36-0.99). 	 RESULTS
This association became bottom line significant after additionally adjusting for other conventional factors (OR = 0.61, P = 0.058). 	 RESULTS
No association was found between serum soluble corin and other composite outcomes. 	 RESULTS
Serum soluble corin deficiency predicted risk for major disability within 3 months after stroke, independent of baseline neurological deficient. 	 CONCLUSION
Our results may indicate a probable role of corin in stroke prognosis. 	 CONCLUSION
Different molecular alterations have been described in endometrioid endometrial carcinoma (EECA). 	 BACKGROUND
Among them the most frequently altered is loss of the PTEN protein, a tumor suppressor gene. 	 BACKGROUND
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the expression pattern of PTEN gene in normal, hyperplastic and neoplastic endometrium. 	 BACKGROUND
In a study in a referral gynecologic hospital in Tehran, Iran, immunohistochemical (IHC) evaluation of PTEN was performed on 87 consecutive specimens to the following three groups; group A- normal proliferative endometrium(n = 29); group B- hyperplastic endometrium [including simple hyperplasia without atypia(n = 21) and complex hyperplasia with atypia (n = 8)] and group C- EECA(n = 29). 	 METHODS
Immunostaining of cells was analyzed by arbitrary quantitative methods according to both slide's area staining and intensity of color reaction. 	 METHODS
immunoreactivity was present in all normal proliferative endometrium, all simple hyperplasia, 75% of atypical complex hyperplasia and in 48% of EECA (P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS PTEN
The intensity of PTEN reaction was significantly higher in group with proliferative endometrium than hyperplastic endometrium and EECA (P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS PTEN
expression was significantly higher in cyclical endometrium than in atypical hyperplasia and endometrioid carcinoma. 	 CONCLUSION PTEN
Despite recent achievements to reduce child mortality, neonatal deaths continue to remain high, accounting for 41% of all deaths in children under five years of age worldwide, of which over 90% occur in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). 	 BACKGROUND
Infections are a leading cause of death and limitations in care seeking for ill neonates contribute to high mortality rates. 	 BACKGROUND
As estimates for care-seeking behaviors in LMICs have not been studied, this review describes care seeking for neonatal illnesses in LMICs, with particular attention to type of care sought. 	 BACKGROUND
We conducted a systematic literature review of studies that reported the proportion of caregivers that sought care for ill or suspected ill neonates in LMICs. 	 METHODS
The initial search yielded 784 studies, of which 22 studies described relevant data from community household surveys, facility-based surveys, and intervention trials. 	 METHODS
The majority of studies were from South Asia (n = 17/22), set in rural areas (n = 17/22), and published within the last 4 years (n = 18/22). 	 METHODS
Of the 9,098 neonates who were ill or suspected to be ill, 4,320 caregivers sought some type of care, including care from a health facility (n = 370) or provider (n = 1,813). 	 RESULTS
Care seeking ranged between 10% and 100% among caregivers with a median of 59%. 	 RESULTS
Care seeking from a health care provider yielded a similar range and median, while care seeking at a health care facility ranged between 1% and 100%, with a median of 20%. 	 RESULTS
Care-seeking estimates were limited by the few studies conducted in urban settings and regions other than South Asia. 	 RESULTS
There was a lack of consistency regarding illness, care-seeking, and care provider definitions. 	 RESULTS
There is a paucity of data regarding newborn care-seeking behaviors; in South Asia, care seeking is low for newborn illness, especially in terms of care sought from health care facilities and medically trained providers. 	 CONCLUSIONS
There is a need for representative data to describe care-seeking patterns in different geographic regions and better understand mechanisms to enhance care seeking during this vulnerable time period. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Adequate vitamin D status for optimum bone health has received increased recognition in recent years; however, the ideal intake is not known. 	 CONTEXT
Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D is the generally accepted indicator of vitamin D status, but no universal reference level has been reached. 	 CONTEXT
To investigate the relative importance of high calcium intake and serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D for calcium homeostasis, as determined by serum intact parathyroid hormone (PTH). 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Cross-sectional study of 2310 healthy Icelandic adults who were divided equally into 3 age groups (30-45 years, 50-65 years, or 70-85 years) and recruited from February 2001 to January 2003. 	 OBJECTIVE
They were administered a semi-quantitative food frequency questionnaire, which assessed vitamin D and calcium intake. 	 OBJECTIVE
Participants were further divided into groups according to calcium intake (<800 mg/d, 800-1200 mg/d, and >1200 mg/d) and serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level (<10 ng/mL, 10-18 ng/mL, and >18 ng/mL). 	 OBJECTIVE
Serum intact PTH as determined by calcium intake and vitamin D.   RESULTS A total of 944 healthy participants completed all parts of the study. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
After adjusting for relevant factors, serum PTH was lowest in the group with a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level of more than 18 ng/mL but highest in the group with a serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level of less than 10 ng/mL. At the low serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level (<10 ng/mL), calcium intake of less than 800 mg/d vs more than 1200 mg/d was significantly associated with higher serum PTH (P = .04); and at a calcium intake of more than 1200 mg/d, there was a significant difference between the lowest and highest vitamin D groups (P = .04). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
As long as vitamin D status is ensured, calcium intake levels of more than 800 mg/d may be unnecessary for maintaining calcium metabolism. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Vitamin D supplements are necessary for adequate vitamin D status in northern climates. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Birth size, perhaps a proxy for prenatal environment, might be a correlate of subsequent breast cancer risk, but findings from epidemiological studies have been inconsistent. 	 BACKGROUND
We re-analysed individual participant data from published and unpublished studies to obtain more precise estimates of the magnitude and shape of the birth size-breast cancer association. 	 BACKGROUND
Studies were identified through computer-assisted and manual searches, and personal communication with investigators. 	 METHODS
Individual participant data from 32 studies, comprising 22,058 breast cancer cases, were obtained. 	 METHODS
Random effect models were used, if appropriate, to combine study-specific estimates of effect. 	 METHODS
Birth weight was positively associated with breast cancer risk in studies based on birth records (pooled relative risk [RR] per one standard deviation [SD] [= 0.5 kg] increment in birth weight: 1.06; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.02-1.09) and parental recall when the participants were children (1.02; 95% CI 0.99-1.05), but not in those based on adult self-reports, or maternal recall during the woman's adulthood (0.98; 95% CI 0.95-1.01) (p for heterogeneity between data sources = 0.003). 	 RESULTS
Relative to women who weighed 3.000-3.499 kg, the risk was 0.96 (CI 0.80-1.16) in those who weighed < 2.500 kg, and 1.12 (95% CI 1.00-1.25) in those who weighed > or = 4.000 kg (p for linear trend = 0.001) in birth record data. 	 RESULTS
Birth length and head circumference from birth records were also positively associated with breast cancer risk (pooled RR per one SD increment: 1.06 [95% CI 1.03-1.10] and 1.09 [95% CI 1.03-1.15], respectively). 	 RESULTS
Simultaneous adjustment for these three birth size variables showed that length was the strongest independent predictor of risk. 	 RESULTS
The birth size effects did not appear to be confounded or mediated by established breast cancer risk factors and were not modified by age or menopausal status. 	 RESULTS
The cumulative incidence of breast cancer per 100 women by age 80 y in the study populations was estimated to be 10.0, 10.0, 10.4, and 11.5 in those who were, respectively, in the bottom, second, third, and top fourths of the birth length distribution. 	 RESULTS
This pooled analysis of individual participant data is consistent with birth size, and in particular birth length, being an independent correlate of breast cancer risk in adulthood. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Growth arrest-specific 5 (GAS5) was reported to be implicated and aberrantly express in multiple cancers. 	 BACKGROUND
However, the expression and mechanism of action of GAS5 were largely poor understood in endometrial carcinoma. 	 BACKGROUND
According to the result of real-time reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and flow cytometry analysis, we identified that GAS5 was down-regulated in endometrial cancer cells and stimulated the apoptosis of endometrial cancer cells. 	 RESULTS
To investigate the expression of GAS5, PTEN and miR-103, RT-PCR was performed. 	 RESULTS
And we found that the expression of PTEN was up-regulated when endometrial cancer cells overexpressed GAS5. 	 RESULTS
The prediction of bioinformatics online revealed that GAS5 could bind to miR-103, which was further found to be regulated by GAS5. 	 RESULTS
Finally, we found that miR-103 mimic could decrease the mRNA and protein levels of PTEN through luciferase reporter assay and western blotting, and GAS5 plasmid may reverse this regulation effect in endometrial cancer cells. 	 RESULTS
In summary, we demonstrate that GAS5 acts as an tumor suppressor lncRNA in endometrial cancer. 	 CONCLUSION
Through inhibiting the expression of miR-103, GAS5 significantly enhanced the expression of PTEN to promote cancer cell apoptosis, and, thus, could be an important mediator in the pathogenesis of endometrial cancer. 	 CONCLUSION
To determine the extent to which type of hospital admission (emergency compared with elective) and surgical procedure varied by socioeconomic circumstances, age, sex, and year of admission for colorectal, breast, and lung cancer. 	 OBJECTIVES
Repeated cross sectional study with data from individual patients, 1 April 1999 to 31 March 2006. 	 DESIGN
Hospital episode statistics (HES) dataset. 	 SETTING
564 821 patients aged 50 and over admitted with a diagnosis of colorectal, breast, or lung cancer. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Proportion of patients admitted as emergencies, and the proportion receiving the recommended surgical treatment. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Patients from deprived areas, older people, and women were more likely to be admitted as emergencies. 	 RESULTS
For example, the adjusted odds ratio for patients with breast cancer in the least compared with most deprived fifth of deprivation was 0.63 (95% confidence interval 0.60 to 0.66) and the adjusted odds ratio for patients with lung cancer aged 80-89 compared with those aged 50-59 was 3.13 (2.93 to 3.34). 	 RESULTS
There were some improvements in disparities between age groups but not for patients living in deprived areas over time. 	 RESULTS
Patients from deprived areas were less likely to receive preferred procedures for rectal, breast, and lung cancer. 	 RESULTS
These findings did not improve with time. 	 RESULTS
For example, 67.4% (3529/5237) of patients in the most deprived fifth of deprivation had anterior resection for rectal cancer compared with 75.5% (4497/5959) of patients in the least deprived fifth (1.34, 1.22 to 1.47). 	 RESULTS
Over half (54.0%, 11 256/20 849) of patients in the most deprived fifth of deprivation had breast conserving surgery compared with 63.7% (18 445/28 960) of patients in the least deprived fifth (1.21, 1.16 to 1.26). 	 RESULTS
Men were less likely than women to undergo anterior resection and lung cancer resection and older people were less likely to receive breast conserving surgery and lung cancer resection. 	 RESULTS
For example, the adjusted odds ratio for lung cancer patients aged 80-89 compared with those aged 50-59 was 0.52 (0.46 to 0.59). 	 RESULTS
Conclusions Despite the implementation of the NHS Cancer Plan, social factors still strongly influence access to and the provision of care. 	 RESULTS
Many smokers are unable or unwilling to completely quit smoking. 	 CONTEXT
A proposed means of harm reduction is to reduce the number of cigarettes smoked per day. 	 CONTEXT
However, it is not clear whether this strategy decreases the risk for tobacco-related diseases. 	 CONTEXT
To assess the effects of smoking reduction on lung cancer incidence. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Observational population-based cohort study with up to 31 years of follow-up from the Copenhagen Centre for Prospective Population Studies, which administrates data from 3 longitudinal studies conducted in Copenhagen and suburbs, the Copenhagen City Heart Study, the Copenhagen Male Study, and the Glostrup Population Studies, Denmark. 	 OBJECTIVE
Participants were 11,151 men and 8563 women (N = 19,714) aged 20 to 93 years, who attended 2 consecutive examinations with a 5- to 10-year interval between 1964 and 1988. 	 OBJECTIVE
Participants underwent a physical examination and completed self-filled questionnaires about lifestyle habits. 	 OBJECTIVE
The study population was divided into 6 groups according to smoking habits: continued heavy smokers (> or =15 cigarettes/d), reducers (reduced from > or =15 cigarettes/d by minimum of 50% without quitting), continued light smokers (1-14 cigarettes/d), quitters (stopped between first and second examination), stable ex-smokers, and never smokers. 	 OBJECTIVE
Incident primary lung cancer cases assessed by record linkage with the National Cancer Registry until December 31, 2003. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
There were 864 incident lung cancers during follow-up. 	 RESULTS
Using Cox regression, the adjusted hazard ratio (HR) for lung cancer in reducers was 0.73 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.54-0.98) compared with persistent heavy smokers. 	 RESULTS
The HR for light smokers was 0.44 (95% CI, 0.35-0.56); for quitters, HR 0.50 (95% CI, 0.36-0.69), for stable ex-smokers, HR 0.17 (95% CI, 0.13-0.23), and for never smokers, HR 0.09 (95% CI, 0.06-0.13). 	 RESULTS
Among individuals who smoke 15 or more cigarettes per day, smoking reduction by 50% significantly reduces the risk of lung cancer. 	 CONCLUSION
To determine the incidence and clinical importance of errors in the preparation and administration of intravenous drugs and the stages of the process in which errors occur. 	 OBJECTIVES
Prospective ethnographic study using disguised observation. 	 DESIGN
Nurses who prepared and administered intravenous drugs. 	 PARTICIPANTS
10 wards in a teaching and non-teaching hospital in the United Kingdom. 	 SETTING
Number, type, and clinical importance of errors. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
249 errors were identified. 	 RESULTS
At least one error occurred in 212 out of 430 intravenous drug doses (49%, 95% confidence interval 45% to 54%). 	 RESULTS
Three doses (1%) had potentially severe errors, 126 (29%) potentially moderate errors, and 83 (19%) potentially minor errors. 	 RESULTS
Most errors occurred when giving bolus doses or making up drugs that required multiple step preparation. 	 RESULTS
The rate of intravenous drug errors was high. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Although most errors would cause only short term adverse effects, a few could have been serious. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A combination of reducing the amount of preparation on the ward, training, and technology to administer slow bolus doses would probably have the greatest effect on error rates. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Although numerous signaling pathways are known to be activated in experimental cardiac hypertrophy, the molecular basis of the hypertrophic response inherent in human heart diseases remains largely unknown. 	 BACKGROUND
Integrin-linked kinase (ILK) is a multifunctional protein kinase that physically links beta-integrins with the actin cytoskeleton, suggesting a potential mechanoreceptor role. 	 BACKGROUND
Here, we show a marked increase in ILK protein levels in hypertrophic ventricles of patients with congenital and acquired outflow tract obstruction. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
This increase in ILK was associated with activation of the Rho family guanine triphosphatases, Rac1 and Cdc42, and known hypertrophic signaling kinases, including extracellular signal-related kinases (ERK1/2) and p70 S6 kinase. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Transgenic mice with cardiac-specific expression of a constitutively active ILK (ILK(S343D)) or wild-type ILK (ILK(WT)) exhibited a compensated ventricular hypertrophic phenotype and displayed an activation profile of guanine triphosphatases and downstream protein kinases concordant with that seen in human hypertrophy. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
In contrast, transgenic mice with cardiomyocyte-restricted expression of a kinase-inactive ILK (ILK(R211A)) were unable to mount a compensatory hypertrophic response to angiotensin II in vivo. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Taken together, these results identify ILK-regulated signaling as a broadly adaptive hypertrophic response mechanism relevant to a wide range of clinical heart disease. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Carbon nanotubes (CNT) hold great promise to create new and better products for commercial and biomedical applications, but their long-term adverse health effects are a major concern. 	 BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to address human lung cancer risks associated with chronic pulmonary exposure to single-walled (SW) CNT through the fundamental understanding of cellular and molecular processes leading to carcinogenesis. 	 BACKGROUND
We hypothesized that the acquisition of cancer stem cells (CSC), a subpopulation that drive tumor initiation and progression, may contribute to CNT carcinogenesis. 	 BACKGROUND
Non-tumorigenic human lung epithelial cells were chronically exposed to well-dispersed SWCNT for a period of 6 months at the physiologically relevant concentration of 0.02 μg/cm2 surface area dose. 	 METHODS
Chronic SWCNT-exposed cells were evaluated for the presence of CSC-like cells under CSC-selective conditions of tumor spheres and side population (SP). 	 METHODS
CSC-like cells were isolated using fluorescence-activated cell sorting and were assessed for aggressive behaviors, including acquired apoptosis resistance and increased cell migration and invasion in vitro, and tumor-initiating capability in vivo. 	 METHODS
Non-small cell lung cancer cells served as a positive control. 	 METHODS
We demonstrated for the first time the existence of CSC-like cells in all clones of chronic SWCNT-exposed lung epithelial cells. 	 RESULTS
These CSC-like cells, in contrary to their non-CSC counterpart, possessed all biological features of lung CSC that are central to irreversible malignant transformation, self-renewal, aggressive cancer behaviors, and in vivo tumorigenesis. 	 RESULTS
These cells also displayed aberrant stem cell markers, notably Nanog, SOX-2, SOX-17 and E-cadherin. 	 RESULTS
Restored expression of tumor suppressor p53 abrogated CSC properties of CSC-like cells. 	 RESULTS
Furthermore, we identified specific stem cell surface markers CD24low and CD133high that are associated with SWCNT-induced CSC formation and tumorigenesis. 	 RESULTS
Our findings provide new and compelling evidence for the acquisition of CSC-like cells induced by chronic SWCNT exposure, which are likely to be a major driving force for SWCNT tumorigenesis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Thus, our study supports prudent adoption of prevention strategies and implementation of exposure control for SWCNT. 	 CONCLUSIONS
We also suggest that the detection of CSC and associated surface markers may provide an effective screening tool for prediction of the carcinogenic potential of SWCNT and related nanoparticles. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Whereas many causes and mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases have been identified, very few therapeutic strategies have emerged in parallel. 	 BACKGROUND
One possible explanation is that successful treatment strategy may require simultaneous targeting of more than one molecule of pathway. 	 BACKGROUND
A new therapeutic approach to have emerged recently is the engagement of microRNAs (miRNAs), which affords the opportunity to target multiple cellular pathways simultaneously using a single sequence. 	 BACKGROUND
METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS We identified miR-22 as a potentially neuroprotective miRNA based on its predicted regulation of several targets implicated in Huntington's disease (histone deacetylase 4 (HDAC4), REST corepresor 1 (Rcor1) and regulator of G-protein signaling 2 (Rgs2)) and its diminished expression in Huntington's and Alzheimer's disease brains. 	 BACKGROUND
We then tested the hypothesis that increasing cellular levels of miRNA-22 would achieve neuroprotection in in vitro models of neurodegeneration. 	 BACKGROUND
As predicted, overexpression of miR-22 inhibited neurodegeneration in primary striatal and cortical cultures exposed to a mutated human huntingtin fragment (Htt171-82Q). 	 BACKGROUND
Overexpression of miR-22 also decreased neurodegeneration in primary neuronal cultures exposed to 3-nitropropionic acid (3-NP), a mitochondrial complex II/III inhibitor. 	 BACKGROUND
In addition, miR-22 improved neuronal viability in an in vitro model of brain aging. 	 BACKGROUND
The mechanisms underlying the effects of miR-22 included a reduction in caspase activation, consistent with miR-22's targeting the pro-apoptotic activities of mitogen-activated protein kinase 14/p38 (MAPK14/p38) and tumor protein p53-inducible nuclear protein 1 (Tp53inp1). 	 BACKGROUND
Moreover, HD-specific effects comprised not only targeting HDAC4, Rcor1 and Rgs2 mRNAs, but also decreasing focal accumulation of mutant Htt-positive foci, which occurred via an unknown mechanism. 	 BACKGROUND
These data show that miR-22 has multipartite anti-neurodegenerative activities including the inhibition of apoptosis and the targeting of mRNAs implicated in the etiology of HD. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These results motivate additional studies to evaluate the feasibility and therapeutic efficacy of manipulating miR-22 in vivo. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The prevalence of metabolic syndrome (obesity, glucose intolerance, low serum high-density lipoprotein cholesterol [HDL-C], high serum triglycerides, hypertension) is high and increasing in parallel with an increasing breast cancer incidence worldwide. 	 BACKGROUND
HDL-C represents an important aspect of the syndrome, yet its role in breast cancer is still undefined. 	 BACKGROUND
In two population-based screening surveys during 1977-1983 and 1985-1987, serum HDL-C was assayed enzymatically among 38,823 Norwegian women aged 17-54 years at entry. 	 METHODS
Height, weight, blood pressure, serum lipids, fat and energy intake, physical activity, parity, oral contraceptive use, hormone therapy use, alcohol intake, and tobacco use were also assessed. 	 METHODS
We used Cox proportional hazards modeling to estimate the relative risk (RR) of breast cancer associated with serum HDL-C levels and to adjust for potential confounding variables. 	 METHODS
We performed stratified analyses to evaluate effect modification by body mass index (BMI) and menopausal status. 	 METHODS
All statistical tests were two-sided. 	 METHODS
During a median follow-up of 17.2 years, we identified 708 cases of invasive breast cancer. 	 RESULTS
In multivariable analysis, the risk of postmenopausal breast cancer was inversely related to quartile of HDL-C (P(trend) =.02). 	 RESULTS
Among women with HDL-C above 1.64 mmol/L (highest quartile) versus below 1.20 mmol/L (lowest quartile), the relative risk was 0.75 (95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.58 to 0.97). 	 RESULTS
The HDL-C association was confined to women in the heavier subgroup (BMI > or =25 kg/m2), for whom the relative risk of postmenopausal breast cancer in those with HDL-C above 1.64 mmol/L versus below 1.20 mmol/L was 0.43 (95% CI = 0.28 to 0.67; P(trend)<.001; P(interaction) =.001). 	 RESULTS
Low HDL-C, as part of the metabolic syndrome, is associated with increased postmenopausal breast cancer risk. 	 CONCLUSION
Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women. 	 BACKGROUND
There is increasing evidence suggesting that ORAI1, components of store-operated calcium channel, play a pivotal role in breast cancer progression and metastasis. 	 BACKGROUND
A total of 384 female patients with breast cancer were included in this study. 	 METHODS
We selected five representative tagging ORAI1 SNPs from HapMap database with minimum allele frequency (MAF) >10%. 	 METHODS
Genotyping was performed using TaqMan allelic discrimination assay. 	 METHODS
Chi-square (χ²) test was used to analyze statistical differences among control and patient groups in genotype and allelic frequencies. 	 METHODS
Two of the ORAI1 SNPs (rs12320939 and rs12313273) were associated with estrogen receptors positive in breast cancer patients under the recessive model. 	 RESULTS
When the Bonferroni correction was performed, the significance still existed. 	 RESULTS
In addition, rs12320939 also associated with the lymph nodal involvement. 	 RESULTS
We showed that genetic polymorphisms of ORAI1 associated strongly with lymph nodal involvement and estrogen receptors (ERs) positive breast cancer patients in a Taiwanese population. 	 CONCLUSION
To determine whether myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibodies (MOG-Abs) were predictive of a demyelination phenotype in children presenting with acquired demyelinating syndrome (ADS). 	 OBJECTIVE
Sixty-five children with a first episode of ADS (12 acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, 24 optic neuritis, 18 transverse myelitis, 11 other clinically isolated syndrome) were identified from 2 national demyelination programs in the United Kingdom and France. 	 METHOD
Acute serum samples were tested for MOG-Abs by cell-based assay. 	 METHOD
Antibodies were used to predict diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS) at 1 year. 	 METHOD
Twenty-three of 65 (35%) children had MOG-Abs. 	 RESULTS
Antibody-positive and antibody-negative patients were not clinically different at presentation, but identification of MOG-Abs predicted a non-MS course at 1-year follow-up: only 2/23 (9%) MOG-Ab-positive patients were diagnosed with MS compared to 16/42 (38%) MOG-Ab-negative patients (p = 0.019, Fisher exact test). 	 RESULTS
Antibody positivity at outset was a useful predictor for a non-MS disease course, with a positive predictive value of 91% (95% confidence interval [CI] 72-99), negative predictive value of 38% (95% CI 24-54), positive likelihood ratio of 4.02 (CI 1.0-15.4), and odds ratio of 6.5 (CI 1.3-31.3). 	 RESULTS
MOG-Abs are found at presentation in 35% of patients with childhood ADS, across a range of demyelinating disorders. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Antibody positivity can be useful in predicting a non-MS disease course at onset. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Blood type and crossmatch incompatibility will exclude at least one third of patients in need from receiving a live donor kidney transplant. 	 CONTEXT
Kidney paired donation (KPD) offers incompatible donor/recipient pairs the opportunity to match for compatible transplants. 	 CONTEXT
Despite its increasing popularity, very few transplants have resulted from KPD. 	 CONTEXT
To determine the potential impact of improved matching schemes on the number and quality of transplants achievable with KPD. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND POPULATION We developed a model that simulates pools of incompatible donor/recipient pairs. 	 OBJECTIVE
We designed a mathematically verifiable optimized matching algorithm and compared it with the scheme currently used in some centers and regions. 	 OBJECTIVE
Simulated patients from the general community with characteristics drawn from distributions describing end-stage renal disease patients eligible for renal transplantation and their willing and eligible live donors. 	 OBJECTIVE
Number of kidneys matched, HLA mismatch of matched kidneys, and number of grafts surviving 5 years after transplantation. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
A national optimized matching algorithm would result in more transplants (47.7% vs 42.0%, P<.001), better HLA concordance (3.0 vs 4.5 mismatched antigens; P<.001), more grafts surviving at 5 years (34.9% vs 28.7%; P<.001), and a reduction in the number of pairs required to travel (2.9% vs 18.4%; P<.001) when compared with an extension of the currently used first-accept scheme to a national level. 	 RESULTS
Furthermore, highly sensitized patients would benefit 6-fold from a national optimized scheme (2.3% vs 14.1% successfully matched; P<.001). 	 RESULTS
Even if only 7% of patients awaiting kidney transplantation participated in an optimized national KPD program, the health care system could save as much as $750 million. 	 RESULTS
The combination of a national KPD program and a mathematically optimized matching algorithm yields more matches with lower HLA disparity. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Optimized matching affords patients the flexibility of customizing their matching priorities and the security of knowing that the greatest number of high-quality matches will be found and distributed equitably. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Clinicians and trialists have difficulty with identifying which patients are highest risk for cardiovascular events. 	 CONTEXT
Prior ischemic events, polyvascular disease, and diabetes mellitus have all been identified as predictors of ischemic events, but their comparative contributions to future risk remain unclear. 	 CONTEXT
To categorize the risk of cardiovascular events in stable outpatients with various initial manifestations of atherothrombosis using simple clinical descriptors. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Outpatients with coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral arterial disease or with multiple risk factors for atherothrombosis were enrolled in the global Reduction of Atherothrombosis for Continued Health (REACH) Registry and were followed up for as long as 4 years. 	 OBJECTIVE
Patients from 3647 centers in 29 countries were enrolled between 2003 and 2004 and followed up until 2008. 	 OBJECTIVE
Final database lock was in April 2009. 	 OBJECTIVE
Rates of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, and stroke. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
A total of 45,227 patients with baseline data were included in this 4-year analysis. 	 RESULTS
During the follow-up period, a total of 5481 patients experienced at least 1 event, including 2315 with cardiovascular death, 1228 with myocardial infarction, 1898 with stroke, and 40 with both a myocardial infarction and stroke on the same day. 	 RESULTS
Among patients with atherothrombosis, those with a prior history of ischemic events at baseline (n = 21,890) had the highest rate of subsequent ischemic events (18.3%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 17.4%-19.1%); patients with stable coronary, cerebrovascular, or peripheral artery disease (n = 15,264) had a lower risk (12.2%; 95% CI, 11.4%-12.9%); and patients without established atherothrombosis but with risk factors only (n = 8073) had the lowest risk (9.1%; 95% CI, 8.3%-9.9%) (P < .001 for all comparisons). 	 RESULTS
In addition, in multivariable modeling, the presence of diabetes (hazard ratio [HR], 1.44; 95% CI, 1.36-1.53; P < .001), an ischemic event in the previous year (HR, 1.71; 95% CI, 1.57-1.85; P < .001), and polyvascular disease (HR, 1.99; 95% CI, 1.78-2.24; P < .001) each were associated with a significantly higher risk of the primary end point. 	 RESULTS
Clinical descriptors can assist clinicians in identifying high-risk patients within the broad range of risk for outpatients with atherothrombosis. 	 CONCLUSION
Osteoporosis causes substantial morbidity and costs $13.8 billion annually in the United States. 	 CONTEXT
Measurement of bone mass by densitometry is a primary part of diagnosing osteoporosis and deciding a preventive treatment course. 	 CONTEXT
Bone mineral densitometry has become more widely available and commonly used in practice. 	 CONTEXT
To review evidence about the value of various clinical applications of bone densitometry. 	 OBJECTIVE
A MEDLINE search was performed to update previous meta-analyses of the relationship between various measurements of bone density and risk of vertebral and hip fracture. 	 DATA SOURCES
We used data from the prospective Study of Osteoporotic Fractures to estimate risk of fracture from bone density and age in postmenopausal women. 	 DATA SOURCES
When available, meta-analyses and systematic reviews are emphasized in the review. 	 STUDY SELECTION AND DATA EXTRACTION
Bone mineral density (BMD) predicts fracture and can be used in combination with age to estimate absolute risk of fractures in postmenopausal white women. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
Hip BMD predicts hip fracture more strongly than other measurements of BMD. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
There are insufficient data to translate BMD results into risk of fracture for men and nonwhite women. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
The benefits of treatments to prevent fractures depend on BMD: women with osteoporosis have a greater risk of fractures and greater benefit from treatments than women without osteoporosis. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
Guidelines based on systematic reviews and a cost-effectiveness analysis have suggested that it is worthwhile to measure BMD in white women older than 65 years and perhaps to use risk factors to select younger postmenopausal women for densitometry. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Other potential clinical applications of BMD that have not yet been adequately studied include screening men or nonwhite women, monitoring BMD in patients receiving treatment, and using BMD to identify patients who should be evaluated for secondary causes of osteoporosis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Anxiety about bias, lack of accountability, and poor quality of peer review has led to questions about the imbalance in anonymity between reviewers and authors. 	 CONTEXT
To evaluate the effect on the quality of peer review of blinding reviewers to the authors' identities and requiring reviewers to sign their reports. 	 OBJECTIVE
Randomized controlled trial. 	 DESIGN
A general medical journal. 	 SETTING
A total of 420 reviewers from the journal's database. 	 PARTICIPANTS
We modified a paper accepted for publication introducing 8 areas of weakness. 	 INTERVENTION
Reviewers were randomly allocated to 5 groups. 	 INTERVENTION
Groups 1 and 2 received manuscripts from which the authors' names and affiliations had been removed, while groups 3 and 4 were aware of the authors' identities. 	 INTERVENTION
Groups 1 and 3 were asked to sign their reports, while groups 2 and 4 were asked to return their reports unsigned. 	 INTERVENTION
The fifth group was sent the paper in the usual manner of the journal, with authors' identities revealed and a request to comment anonymously. 	 INTERVENTION
Group 5 differed from group 4 only in that its members were unaware that they were taking part in a study. 	 INTERVENTION
The number of weaknesses in the paper that were commented on by the reviewers. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
Reports were received from 221 reviewers (53%). 	 RESULTS
The mean number of weaknesses commented on was 2 (1.7, 2.1, 1.8, and 1.9 for groups 1, 2, 3, and 4 and 5 combined, respectively). 	 RESULTS
There were no statistically significant differences between groups in their performance. 	 RESULTS
Reviewers who were blinded to authors' dentities were less likely to recommend rejection than those who were aware of the authors' identities (odds ratio, 0.5; 95% confidence interval, 0.3-1.0). 	 RESULTS
Neither blinding reviewers to the authors and origin of the paper nor requiring them to sign their reports had any effect on rate of detection of errors. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Such measures are unlikely to improve the quality of peer review reports. 	 CONCLUSIONS
More than 2 million U.S. women receive an equivocal cervical cytologic diagnosis (atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance [ASCUS]) each year. 	 BACKGROUND
Effective colposcopy triage strategies are needed to identify the minority of women who have clinically significant disease while avoiding excessive follow-up evaluation for others. 	 BACKGROUND
The ASCUS/LSIL (i.e., low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion) Triage Study (ALTS) is a multicenter, randomized trial comparing the sensitivity and specificity of the following three management strategies to detect cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3 (CIN3): 1) immediate colposcopy (considered to be the reference standard), 2) triage to colposcopy based on human papillomavirus (HPV) results from Hybrid Capture 2(TM) (HC 2) and thin-layer cytology results, or 3) triage based on cytology results alone. 	 METHODS
This article summarizes the cross-sectional enrollment results for 3488 women with a referral diagnosis of ASCUS. 	 METHODS
All statistical tests are two-sided. 	 METHODS
Among participants with ASCUS, the underlying prevalence of histologically confirmed CIN3 was 5.1%. 	 RESULTS
Sensitivity to detect CIN3 or above by testing for cancer-associated HPV DNA was 96.3% (95% confidence interval [CI] = 91.6% to 98.8%), with 56.1% of women referred to colposcopy. 	 RESULTS
Sensitivity of a single repeat cytology specimen with a triage threshold of HSIL or above was 44.1% (95% CI = 35.6% to 52.9%), with 6.9% referred. 	 RESULTS
Sensitivity of a lower cytology triage threshold of ASCUS or above was 85.3% (95% CI = 78.2% to 90.8%), with 58.6% referred. 	 RESULTS
HC 2 testing for cancer-associated HPV DNA is a viable option in the management of women with ASCUS. 	 CONCLUSIONS
It has greater sensitivity to detect CIN3 or above and specificity comparable to a single additional cytologic test indicating ASCUS or above. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To examine whether past high sun exposure is associated with a reduced risk of multiple sclerosis. 	 OBJECTIVE
Population based case-control study. 	 DESIGN
Tasmania, latitudes 41-3 degrees S.   PARTICIPANTS 136 cases with multiple sclerosis and 272 controls randomly drawn from the community and matched on sex and year of birth. 	 SETTING
Multiple sclerosis defined by both clinical and magnetic resonance imaging criteria. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
Higher sun exposure when aged 6-15 years (average 2-3 hours or more a day in summer during weekends and holidays) was associated with a decreased risk of multiple sclerosis (adjusted odds ratio 0.31, 95% confidence interval 0.16 to 0.59). 	 RESULTS
Higher exposure in winter seemed more important than higher exposure in summer. 	 RESULTS
Greater actinic damage was also independently associated with a decreased risk of multiple sclerosis (0.32, 0.11 to 0.88 for grades 4-6 disease). 	 RESULTS
A dose-response relation was observed between multiple sclerosis and decreasing sun exposure when aged 6-15 years and with actinic damage. 	 RESULTS
Higher sun exposure during childhood and early adolescence is associated with a reduced risk of multiple sclerosis. 	 CONCLUSION
Insufficient ultraviolet radiation may therefore influence the development of multiple sclerosis. 	 CONCLUSION
To explore the association between a stable partnership and clinical outcome in HIV infected patients receiving highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). 	 OBJECTIVES
Prospective cohort study of adults with HIV (Swiss HIV cohort study). 	 DESIGN
Seven outpatient clinics throughout Switzerland. 	 SETTING
The 3736 patients in the cohort who started HAART before 2002 (median age 36 years, 29% female, median follow up 3.6 years). 	 PARTICIPANTS
Time to AIDS or death (primary endpoint), death alone, increases in CD4 cell count of at least 50 and 100 above baseline, optimal viral suppression (a viral load below 400 copies/ml), and viral rebound. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
During follow up 2985 (80%) participants reported a stable partnership on at least one occasion. 	 RESULTS
When starting HAART, 52% (545/1042) of participants reported a stable partnership; after five years of follow up 46% (190/412) of participants reported a stable partnership. 	 RESULTS
In an analysis stratified by previous antiretroviral therapy and clinical stage when starting HAART (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention group A, B, or C), the adjusted hazard ratio for progression to AIDS or death was 0.79 (95% confidence interval 0.63 to 0.98) for participants with a stable partnership compared with those without. 	 RESULTS
Adjusted hazards ratios for other endpoints were 0.59 (0.44 to 0.79) for progression to death, 1.15 (1.06 to 1.24) for an increase in CD4 cells of 100 counts/microl or more, and 1.06 (0.98 to 1.14) for optimal viral suppression. 	 RESULTS
A stable partnership is associated with a slower rate of progression to AIDS or death in HIV infected patients receiving HAART. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Previous studies indicate that the population attributable risk (PAR) of bladder cancer for tobacco smoking is 50% to 65% in men and 20% to 30% in women and that current cigarette smoking triples bladder cancer risk relative to never smoking. 	 CONTEXT
During the last 30 years, incidence rates have remained stable in the United States in men (123.8 per 100,000 person-years to 142.2 per 100,000 person-years) and women (32.5 per 100,000 person-years to 33.2 per 100,000 person-years); however, changing smoking prevalence and cigarette composition warrant revisiting risk estimates for smoking and bladder cancer. 	 CONTEXT
To evaluate the association between tobacco smoking and bladder cancer. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Men (n = 281,394) and women (n = 186,134) of the National Institutes of Health-AARP (NIH-AARP) Diet and Health Study cohort completed a lifestyle questionnaire and were followed up between October 25, 1995, and December 31, 2006. 	 OBJECTIVE
Previous prospective cohort studies of smoking and incident bladder cancer were identified by systematic review and relative risks were estimated from fixed-effects models with heterogeneity assessed by the I(2) statistic. 	 OBJECTIVE
Hazard ratios (HRs), PARs, and number needed to harm (NNH). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
During 4,518,941 person-years of follow-up, incident bladder cancer occurred in 3896 men (144.0 per 100,000 person-years) and 627 women (34.5 per 100,000 person-years). 	 RESULTS
Former smokers (119.8 per 100,000 person-years; HR, 2.22; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.03-2.44; NNH, 1250) and current smokers (177.3 per 100,000 person-years; HR, 4.06; 95% CI, 3.66-4.50; NNH, 727) had higher risks of bladder cancer than never smokers (39.8 per 100,000 person-years). 	 RESULTS
In contrast, the summary risk estimate for current smoking in 7 previous studies (initiated between 1963 and 1987) was 2.94 (95% CI, 2.45-3.54; I(2) = 0.0%). 	 RESULTS
The PAR for ever smoking in our study was 0.50 (95% CI, 0.45-0.54) in men and 0.52 (95% CI, 0.45-0.59) in women. 	 RESULTS
Compared with a pooled estimate of US data from cohorts initiated between 1963 and 1987, relative risks for smoking in the more recent NIH-AARP Diet and Health Study cohort were higher, with PARs for women comparable with those for men. 	 CONCLUSION
Accumulating evidence has shown that cancer cell metabolism differs from that of normal cells. 	 BACKGROUND
However, up to now it is not clear whether different cancer types are characterized by a specific metabolite profile. 	 BACKGROUND
Therefore, this study aims to evaluate whether the plasma metabolic phenotype allows to discriminate between lung and breast cancer. 	 BACKGROUND
The proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectrum of plasma is divided into 110 integration regions, representing the metabolic phenotype. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
These integration regions reflect the relative metabolite concentrations and were used to train a classification model in discriminating between 80 female breast cancer patients and 54 female lung cancer patients, all with an adenocarcinoma. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
The validity of the model was examined by permutation testing and by classifying an independent validation cohort of 60 female breast cancer patients and 81 male lung cancer patients, all with an adenocarcinoma. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
The model allows to classify 99% of the breast cancer patients and 93% of the lung cancer patients correctly with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.96 and can be validated in the independent cohort with a sensitivity of 89%, a specificity of 82% and an AUC of 0.94. 	 RESULTS
Decreased levels of sphingomyelin and phosphatidylcholine (phospholipids with choline head group) and phospholipids with short, unsaturated fatty acid chains next to increased levels of phospholipids with long, saturated fatty acid chains seem to indicate that cell membranes of lung tumors are more rigid and less sensitive to lipid peroxidation. 	 RESULTS
The other discriminating metabolites are pointing to a more pronounced response of the body to the Warburg effect for lung cancer. 	 RESULTS
Metabolic phenotyping of plasma allows to discriminate between lung and breast cancer, indicating that the metabolite profile reflects more than a general cancer marker. 	 CONCLUSION
NCT02362776. 	 CLINICAL TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER
This study sought to describe and quantify microcirculatory changes in the mucosal surfaces of patients with severe malaria, by direct in vivo observation using orthogonal polarization spectral (OPS) imaging. 	 BACKGROUND
The microcirculation in the rectal mucosa of adult patients with severe malaria was assessed by use of OPS imaging, at admission and then daily. 	 METHODS
Comparison groups comprised patients with uncomplicated falciparum malaria, patients with bacterial sepsis, and healthy individuals. 	 METHODS
Erythrocyte velocities were measured directly in 43 adult patients with severe falciparum malaria, of whom 20 died. 	 RESULTS
Microcirculatory blood flow was markedly disturbed, with heterogeneous obstruction that was proportional to severity of disease. 	 RESULTS
Blocked capillaries were found in 29 patients (67%) and were associated with concurrent hyperdynamic blood flow (erythrocyte velocity, >750 mm/s) in adjacent vessels in 27 patients (93%). 	 RESULTS
The proportion of blocked capillaries correlated with the base deficit in plasma and with the concentration of lactate. 	 RESULTS
Abnormalities disappeared when the patients recovered. 	 RESULTS
In healthy individuals and in patients with uncomplicated malaria or sepsis, no stagnant erythrocytes were detected, and, in patients with sepsis, hyperdynamic blood flow was prominent. 	 RESULTS
Patients with severe falciparum malaria show extensive microvascular obstruction that is proportional to the severity of the disease. 	 CONCLUSION
This finding underscores the prominent role that microvascular obstruction plays in the pathophysiology of severe malaria and illustrates the fundamental difference between the microvascular pathophysiology of malaria and that of bacterial sepsis. 	 CONCLUSION
To examine the potential effects of replacing the Swedish alcohol retail system with a private licensing system on alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harm. 	 AIM
Two possible scenarios were analysed: (1) replacing the current alcohol retail monopoly with private licensed stores that specialize in alcohol sales or (2) making all alcohol available in grocery stores. 	 DESIGN
We utilized a multiplicative model that projected effects of changes in a set of key factors including hours of sale, retail prices, promotion and advertising and outlet density. 	 DESIGN
Next, we estimated the effect of the projected consumption increase on a set of harm indicators. 	 DESIGN
Values for the model parameters were obtained from the research literature. 	 DESIGN
Measures of alcohol-related harm included explicitly alcohol-related mortality, accident mortality, suicide, homicide, assaults, drinking driving and sickness absence. 	 MEASUREMENTS
According to the projections, scenario 1 yields a consumption increase of 17% (1.4 litres/capita), which in turn would cause an additional 770 deaths, 8500 assaults, 2700 drinking driving offences and 4.5 million sick days per year. 	 FINDINGS
The corresponding figures for scenario 2 are a consumption increase of 37.4% (3.1 litres/capita) leading to an additional annual toll of 2000 deaths, 20 000 assaults, 6600 drinking driving offences and 11.1 million days of sick leave. 	 FINDINGS
Projections based on the research literature suggest that privatization of the Swedish alcohol retail market would significantly increase alcohol consumption and alcohol-related harm. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The prevalence of diabetes is increasing in all industrialized countries and its prevention has become a public health priority. 	 BACKGROUND
However, the predictors of diabetes risk are insufficiently understood. 	 BACKGROUND
We evaluated, whether 31 novel biomarkers could help to predict the risk of incident diabetes. 	 BACKGROUND
The biomarkers were evaluated primarily in the FINRISK97 cohort (n = 7,827; 417 cases of clinically incident diabetes during the follow-up). 	 METHODS
The findings were replicated in the Health 2000 cohort (n = 4,977; 179 cases of clinically incident diabetes during the follow-up). 	 METHODS
We used Cox proportional hazards models to calculate the relative risk of diabetes, after adjusting for the classic risk factors, separately for each biomarker. 	 METHODS
Next, we assessed the discriminatory ability of single biomarkers using receiver operating characteristic curves and C-statistics, integrated discrimination improvement (IDI) and net reclassification improvement (NRI). 	 METHODS
Finally, we derived a biomarker score in the FINRISK97 cohort and validated it in the Health 2000 cohort. 	 METHODS
A score consisting of adiponectin, apolipoprotein B, C-reactive protein and ferritin almost doubled the relative risk of diabetes in the validation cohort (HR per one standard deviation increase 1.88, p = 2.8 e-5). 	 RESULTS
It also improved discrimination of the model (IDI = 0.0149, p<0.0001) and reclassification of diabetes risk (NRI = 11.8%, p = 0.006). 	 RESULTS
Gender-specific analyses suggested that the best score differed between men and women. 	 RESULTS
Among men, the best results were obtained with the score of four biomarkers: adiponectin, apolipoprotein B, ferritin and interleukin-1 receptor antagonist, which gave an NRI of 25.4% (p<0.0001). 	 RESULTS
Among women, the best score included adiponectin, apolipoprotein B, C-reactive protein and insulin. 	 RESULTS
It gave an NRI of 13.6% (p = 0.041). 	 RESULTS
We identified novel biomarkers that were associated with the risk of clinically incident diabetes over and above the classic risk factors. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This gives new insights into the pathogenesis of diabetes and may help with targeting prevention and treatment. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To determine attrition and predictors of academic success among medical students at University of Split, Croatia. 	 AIM
We analysed academic records of 2054 students enrolled during 1979-2008 period. 	 METHODS
We found that 26% (533/2054) of enrolled students did not graduate. 	 RESULTS
The most common reasons for attrition were 'personal' (36.4%), transfer to another medical school (35.6%), and dismissal due to unsatisfactory academic record (21.2%). 	 RESULTS
Grade point average (GPA) and study duration of attrition students were significantly associated with parental education. 	 RESULTS
There were 1126 graduates, 395 men and 731 women. 	 RESULTS
Their average graduation GPA was 3.67±0.53 and study duration 7.6±2.44 years. 	 RESULTS
During 5-year curriculum only 6.4% (42/654) of students graduated in time, and 55% (240/472) of students graduated in time after curriculum was extended to 6 years. 	 RESULTS
Variables predicting whether a student will graduate or not were high school grades, entrance exam score and year of enrollment. 	 RESULTS
Significant predictors of graduation grades were high school grades and entrance exam score. 	 RESULTS
Entrance exam score predicted length of studying. 	 RESULTS
Preadmission academic qualifications and year of enrollment predict academic success in medical school. 	 CONCLUSION
More attention should be devoted to high attrition. 	 CONCLUSION
Interleukin (IL)-18 is a potent proinflammatory cytokine with potential atherogenic properties. 	 BACKGROUND
Its expression and role in atherosclerosis, however, are unknown. 	 BACKGROUND
In the present study, we examined stable and unstable human carotid atherosclerotic plaques retrieved by endarterectomy for the presence of IL-18 using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (PCR), Western blot, and immunohistochemical techniques. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
IL-18 was highly expressed in the atherosclerotic plaques compared with control normal arteries and was localized mainly in plaque macrophages. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
IL-18 receptor was also upregulated in plaque macrophages and endothelial cells, suggesting potential biological effects. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
To examine the role of IL-18 in atherosclerosis, we determined the relation between IL-18 mRNA expression and signs of plaque instability using real-time quantitative PCR. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Interestingly, significantly higher levels of IL-18 mRNA were found in symptomatic (unstable) plaques than asymptomatic (stable) plaques (P<0.01). 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
These results suggest, for the first time, a major role for IL-18 in atherosclerotic plaque destabilization leading to acute ischemic syndromes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
According to willingness of the Ministry of Health, Iran and presence of appropriate conditions for disease elimination, national malaria control program decided to conduct a research to clarify malaria status in 2007 and to provide required information to perform the elimination program. 	 BACKGROUND
This review is comprised of the basis of national malaria elimination program in vision of 2025, which was started in 2010. 	 BACKGROUND
In this descriptive study, data were analyzed by applications of different variables at district level. 	 METHODS
All districts in the three south eastern provinces, in which malaria has local transmission, were considered. 	 METHODS
Malaria cases has been determined and studied based on the national malaria surveillance system. 	 METHODS
Since vivax malaria is predominant in Sistan & Baluchestan Province, number of vivax cases is equal to malaria positive cases approximately. 	 RESULTS
The important point is that Nikshahr contains the maximum number of local vivax cases in this province and the maximum number of falciparum cases is reported from Sarbaz district. 	 RESULTS
Among all districts of Hormozgan Province, no case of autochthonous falciparum was detected except in Bandar Jask and one case in Minab. 	 RESULTS
There was no case of autochthonous falciparum in Kerman Province, except in Kahnoj and Ghale Ganj that each of them had one case in 2007. 	 RESULTS
It appears that the report of locally transmitted cases in Iran is increasing over the past few years, before starting malaria elimination plan. 	 CONCLUSION
Since the Afghan refugees started to return to their own country so the main source of reporting of imported malaria cases reduced and local cases would be demonstrated more clearly. 	 CONCLUSION
Sequence similarity searching is a very important bioinformatics task. 	 BACKGROUND
While Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) outperforms exact methods through its use of heuristics, the speed of the current BLAST software is suboptimal for very long queries or database sequences. 	 BACKGROUND
There are also some shortcomings in the user-interface of the current command-line applications. 	 BACKGROUND
We describe features and improvements of rewritten BLAST software and introduce new command-line applications. 	 RESULTS
Long query sequences are broken into chunks for processing, in some cases leading to dramatically shorter run times. 	 RESULTS
For long database sequences, it is possible to retrieve only the relevant parts of the sequence, reducing CPU time and memory usage for searches of short queries against databases of contigs or chromosomes. 	 RESULTS
The program can now retrieve masking information for database sequences from the BLAST databases. 	 RESULTS
A new modular software library can now access subject sequence data from arbitrary data sources. 	 RESULTS
We introduce several new features, including strategy files that allow a user to save and reuse their favorite set of options. 	 RESULTS
The strategy files can be uploaded to and downloaded from the NCBI BLAST web site. 	 RESULTS
The new BLAST command-line applications, compared to the current BLAST tools, demonstrate substantial speed improvements for long queries as well as chromosome length database sequences. 	 CONCLUSION
We have also improved the user interface of the command-line applications. 	 CONCLUSION
Various perinatal factors, including birth weight, birth order, maternal age, gestational age, twin status, and parental smoking, have been postulated to affect breast cancer risk in daughters by altering the hormonal environment of the developing fetal mammary glands. 	 INTRODUCTION
Despite ample biologic plausibility, epidemiologic studies to date have yielded conflicting results. 	 INTRODUCTION
We investigated the associations between perinatal factors and subsequent breast cancer risk through meta-analyses. 	 INTRODUCTION
We reviewed breast cancer studies published from January 1966 to February 2007 that included data on birth weight, birth order, maternal age, gestational age, twin status, and maternal or paternal smoking. 	 METHODS
Meta-analyses using random effect models were employed to summarize the results. 	 METHODS
We found that heavier birth weights were associated with increased breast cancer risk, with studies involving five categories of birth weight identifying odds ratios (ORs) of 1.24 (95% confidence interval [CI] 1.04 to 1.48) for 4,000 g or more and 1.15 (95% CI 1.04 to 1.26) for 3,500 g to 3,999 g, relative to a birth weight of 2,500 to 2,599 g. These studies provided no support for a J-shaped relationship of birthweight to risk. 	 RESULTS
Support for an association with birthweight was also derived from studies based on three birth weight categories (OR 1.15 [95% CI 1.01 to 1.31] for > or =4,000 g relative to <3,000 g) and two birth weight categories (OR 1.09 [95% CI 1.02 to 1.18] for > or =3,000 g relative to <3,000 g). 	 RESULTS
Women born to older mothers and twins were also at some increased risk, but the results were heterogeneous across studies and publication years. 	 RESULTS
Birth order, prematurity, and maternal smoking were unrelated to breast cancer risk. 	 RESULTS
Our findings provide some support for the hypothesis that in utero exposures reflective of higher endogenous hormone levels could affect risk for development of breast cancer in adulthood. 	 CONCLUSION
To review the evidence for the use of bisphosphonates to reduce skeletal morbidity in cancer patients with bone metastases. 	 OBJECTIVE
Electronic databases, scanning reference lists, and consultation with experts and pharmaceutical companies. 	 DATA SOURCES
Foreign language papers were included. 	 DATA SOURCES
Included trials were randomised controlled trials of patients with malignant disease and bone metastases who were treated with oral or intravenous bisphosphonate compared with another bisphosphonate, placebo, or standard care. 	 STUDY SELECTION
All trials measured at least one outcome of skeletal morbidity. 	 STUDY SELECTION
95 articles were identified; 30 studies fulfilled inclusion criteria. 	 RESULTS
In studies that lasted > or = 6 months, compared with placebo bisphosphonates significantly reduced the odds ratio for fractures (vertebral 0.69, 95% confidence interval 0.57 to 0.84, P < 0.0001; non-vertebral 0.65, 0.54 to 0.79, P < 0.0001; combined 0.65, 0.55 to 0.78, P < 0.0001), radiotherapy (0.67, 0.57 to 0.79, P < 0.0001), and hypercalcaemia (0.54, 0.36 to 0.81, P = 0.003) but not for orthopaedic surgery (0.70, 0.46 to 1.05, P = 0.086) or spinal cord compression (0.71, 0.47 to 1.08, P = 0.113). 	 RESULTS
The reduction in orthopaedic surgery was significant in studies that lasted over a year (0.59, 0.39 to 0.88, P = 0.009). 	 RESULTS
Use of bisphosphonates significantly increased time to first skeletal related event but did not increase survival. 	 RESULTS
Subanalyses showed that most evidence supports use of intravenous aminobisphosphonates. 	 RESULTS
In people with metastatic bone disease bisphosphonates significantly decrease skeletal morbidity, except for spinal cord compression and increased time to first skeletal related event. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Treatment should start when bone metastases are diagnosed and continue until it is no longer clinically relevant. 	 CONCLUSIONS
One factor that contributes to high maternal mortality in developing countries is the delayed use of Emergency Obstetric-Care (EmOC) facilities. 	 BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to determine the factors that hinder midwives and parturient women from using hospitals when complications occur during home birth in Sistan and Baluchestan province, Iran, where 23% of all deliveries take place in non- hospital settings. 	 BACKGROUND
In the study and data management, a mixed-methods approach was used. 	 METHODS
In the quantitative phase, we compared the existing health-sector data with World Health Organization (WHO) standards for the availability and use of EmOC services. 	 METHODS
The qualitative phase included collection and analysis of interviews with midwives and traditional birth attendants and twenty-one in-depth interviews with mothers. 	 METHODS
The data collected in this phase were managed according to the principles of qualitative data analysis. 	 METHODS
The findings demonstrate that three distinct factors lead to indecisiveness and delay in the use of EmOC by the midwives and mothers studied. 	 RESULTS
Socio-cultural and familial reasons compel some women to choose to give birth at home and to hesitate seeking professional emergency care for delivery complications. 	 RESULTS
Apprehension about being insulted by physicians, the necessity of protecting their professional integrity in front of patients and an inability to persuade their patients lead to an over-insistence by midwives on completing deliveries at the mothers' homes and a reluctance to refer their patients to hospitals. 	 RESULTS
The low quality and expense of EmOC and the mothers' lack of health insurance also contribute to delays in referral. 	 RESULTS
Women who choose to give birth at home accept the risk that complications may arise. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Training midwives and persuading mothers and significant others who make decisions about the value of referring women to hospitals at the onset of life-threatening complications are central factors to increasing the use of available hospitals. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The hospitals must be safe, comfortable and attractive environments for parturition and should give appropriate consideration to the ethical and cultural concerns of the women. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Appropriate management of financial and insurance-related issues can help midwives and mothers make a rational decision when complications arise. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Fructosamine, glycated albumin, and 1,5-anhydroglucitol (1,5-AG) are of interest for monitoring short-term glycemic control in patients with diabetes; however, their associations with diabetes risk are uncharacterized. 	 OBJECTIVE
METHODS 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND
We used Cox proportional hazards models to examine the associations of fructosamine, glycated albumin, and 1,5-AG with incident diabetes in 1,299 participants, from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) Study (2005-2006), who had no history of diagnosed diabetes at baseline. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND
Incident diabetes was self-reported during annual telephone calls. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND
There were 119 new cases of diabetes during a median follow-up of 3.3 years. 	 RESULTS
When compared with the lowest quartile, the fourth quartiles of fructosamine and glycated albumin were significantly associated with diabetes risk (hazard ratio [HR] 3.99 [95% CI 1.93-8.28] and 5.22 [2.49-10.94], respectively). 	 RESULTS
The fourth quartile of 1,5-AG was associated with a significantly lower diabetes risk (0.27 [0.14-0.55]). 	 RESULTS
Associations were attenuated but still significant after adjustment for hemoglobin A(1c) (A1C) or fasting glucose. 	 RESULTS
Fructosamine, glycated albumin, and 1,5-AG were associated with the subsequent development of diabetes independently of baseline A1C and fasting glucose. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Our results suggest these alternative biomarkers may be useful in identifying persons at risk for diabetes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The processing of the Affymetrix GeneChip data has been a recent focus for data analysts. 	 MOTIVATION
Alternatives to the original procedure have been proposed and some of these new methods are widely used. 	 MOTIVATION
The affy package is an R package of functions and classes for the analysis of oligonucleotide arrays manufactured by Affymetrix. 	 RESULTS
The package is currently in its second release, affy provides the user with extreme flexibility when carrying out an analysis and make it possible to access and manipulate probe intensity data. 	 RESULTS
In this paper, we present the main classes and functions in the package and demonstrate how they can be used to process probe-level data. 	 RESULTS
We also demonstrate the importance of probe-level analysis when using the Affymetrix GeneChip platform. 	 RESULTS
To investigate the effects of a high-intensity functional exercise program on independence in activities of daily living (ADLs) and balance in older people with dementia and whether exercise effects differed between dementia types. 	 OBJECTIVES
Cluster-randomized controlled trial: Umeå Dementia and Exercise (UMDEX) study. 	 DESIGN
Residential care facilities, Umeå, Sweden. 	 SETTING
Individuals aged 65 and older with a dementia diagnosis, a Mini-Mental State Examination score of 10 or greater, and dependence in ADLs (N=186). 	 PARTICIPANTS
Ninety-three participants each were allocated to the high-intensity functional exercise program, comprising lower limb strength and balance exercises, and 93 to a seated control activity. 	 INTERVENTION
Blinded assessors measured ADL independence using the Functional Independence Measure (FIM) and Barthel Index (BI) and balance using the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) at baseline and 4 (directly after intervention completion) and 7 months. 	 MEASUREMENTS
Linear mixed models showed no between-group effect on ADL independence at 4 (FIM=1.3, 95% confidence interval (CI)=-1.6-4.3; BI=0.6, 95% CI=-0.2-1.4) or 7 (FIM=0.8, 95% CI=-2.2-3.8; BI=0.6, 95% CI=-0.3-1.4) months. 	 RESULTS
A significant between-group effect on balance favoring exercise was observed at 4 months (BBS=4.2, 95% CI=1.8-6.6). 	 RESULTS
In interaction analyses, exercise effects differed significantly between dementia types. 	 RESULTS
Positive between-group exercise effects were found in participants with non-Alzheimer's dementia according to the FIM at 7 months and BI and BBS at 4 and 7 months. 	 RESULTS
In older people with mild to moderate dementia living in residential care facilities, a 4-month high-intensity functional exercise program appears to slow decline in ADL independence and improve balance, albeit only in participants with non-Alzheimer's dementia. 	 CONCLUSION
Appropriate understanding of health information by patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD) is fundamental for better management of risk factors and improved morbidity, which can also benefit their quality of life. 	 BACKGROUND
To assess the relationship between health literacy and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in patients with ischaemic heart disease (IHD), and to investigate the role of sociodemographic and clinical variables as possible confounders. 	 OBJECTIVES
Cross-sectional study of patients with IHD recruited from a stratified sample of general practices in two Australian states (Queensland and South Australia) between 2007 and 2009. 	 METHODS
Health literacy was measured using a validated questionnaire and classified as inadequate, marginal, or adequate. 	 METHODS
Physical and mental components of HRQoL were assessed using the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form (SF12) questionnaire. 	 METHODS
Analyses were adjusted for confounders (sociodemographic variables, clinical history of IHD, number of CVD comorbidities, and CVD risk factors) using multiple linear regression. 	 METHODS
A total sample of 587 patients with IHD (mean age 72.0±8.4 years) was evaluated: 76.8% males, 84.2% retired or pensioner, and 51.4% with up to secondary educational level. 	 RESULTS
Health literacy showed a mean of 39.6±6.7 points, with 14.3% (95%CI 11.8-17.3) classified as inadequate. 	 RESULTS
Scores of the physical component of HRQoL were 39.6 (95%CI 37.1-42.1), 42.1 (95%CI 40.8-43.3) and 44.8 (95%CI 43.3-46.2) for inadequate, marginal, and adequate health literacy, respectively (p-value for trend = 0.001). 	 RESULTS
This association persisted after adjustment for confounders. 	 RESULTS
Health literacy was not associated with the mental component of HRQoL (p-value = 0.482). 	 RESULTS
Advanced age, lower educational level, disadvantaged socioeconomic position, and a larger number of CVD comorbidities adversely affected both, health literacy and HRQoL.   CONCLUSION Inadequate health literacy is a contributing factor to poor physical functioning in patients with IHD. 	 RESULTS
Increasing health literacy may improve HRQoL and reduce the impact of IHD among patients with this chronic CVD. 	 RESULTS
To explore how a group of Swedish general practitioners (GPs) manage patients with a sore throat in relation to current guidelines as expressed in interviews. 	 OBJECTIVE
Qualitative content analysis was used to analyse semi-structured interviews. 	 DESIGN
Swedish primary care. 	 SETTING
A strategic sample of 25 GPs. 	 SUBJECTS
Perceived management of sore throat patients. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
It was found that nine of the interviewed GPs were adherent to current guidelines for sore throat and 16 were non-adherent. 	 RESULTS
The two groups differed in terms of guideline knowledge, which was shared within the team for adherent GPs while idiosyncratic knowledge dominated for the non-adherent GPs. 	 RESULTS
Adherent GPs had no or low concerns for bacterial infections and differential diagnosis whilst non-adherent GPs believed that in patients with a sore throat any bacterial infection should be identified and treated with antibiotics. 	 RESULTS
Patient history and examination was mainly targeted by adherent GPs whilst for non-adherent GPs it was often redundant. 	 RESULTS
Non-adherent GPs reported problems getting patients to abstain from antibiotics, whilst no such problems were reported in adherent GPs. 	 RESULTS
This interview study of sore throat management in a strategically sampled group of Swedish GPs showed that while two-thirds were non-adherent and had a liberal attitude to antibiotics one-third were guideline adherent with a restricted view on antibiotics. 	 CONCLUSION
Non-adherent GPs revealed significant knowledge gaps. 	 CONCLUSION
Adherent GPs had discussed guidelines within the primary care team while non-adherent GPs had not. 	 CONCLUSION
Guideline implementation thus seemed to be promoted by knowledge shared in team discussions. 	 CONCLUSION
Abciximab plus aspirin improves the TIMI 3 flow rate of the infarct-related artery in patients treated with either percutaneous coronary intervention or thrombolysis. 	 BACKGROUND
The present study investigated whether the reperfusion efficacy of abciximab relates to modifications of clot architecture in patients admitted for acute myocardial infarction (AMI). 	 BACKGROUND
A total of 23 AMI patients in the Abciximab before Direct angioplasty and stenting in Myocardial Infarction Regarding Acute and Long term follow-up (ADMIRAL) trial received, in a double-blind fashion, either abciximab (n=13) or placebo (n=10) before primary stenting. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Viscoelastic (G' in dyne/cm(2)) and morphological (mean platelet aggregate surface area [SAG] in micrometer(2)) indexes of ex vivo platelet-rich clots (PRC) were assessed in a double-blind fashion before and after the bolus administration of abciximab or placebo. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
G' and SAG reflect the mechanical and morphological impact of activated platelets on the PRC fibrin network, respectively. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Abciximab administration reduced G' by 63% (P=0.0001) and SAG by 65% (P=0.0007), and no effect was seen in the placebo group. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
These abciximab-related changes increased fibrin exposure as a consequence of the platelet-aggregate surface reduction and may have improved endogenous fibrinolysis. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
These effects were identified in all patients, independent of previous heparin administration. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Abciximab dramatically reduces platelet aggregate size and increases the fibrin accessibility of ex vivo PRC in AMI patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These modifications could participate in the better coronary artery patency observed with abciximab. 	 CONCLUSIONS
African Americans have higher rates of cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality than other ethnic groups. 	 BACKGROUND
Young adults are prime targets for intervention strategies to prevent and reduce disease risk. 	 BACKGROUND
The study purpose was to determine the level of knowledge of lifestyle risk factors for CVD among young African American adults in Phoenix. 	 BACKGROUND
The results will be used to guide the development of CVD outreach programs targeted to this population. 	 BACKGROUND
The Health Belief Model was used as a conceptual framework. 	 BACKGROUND
A convenience sample of 172 African American men and women aged 18-26 years completed a questionnaire adapted from the American Heart Association national surveys. 	 METHODS
Descriptive statistics were compared by age, gender, education level, and health status variables including BMI, smoking status, and physical activity. 	 METHODS
Some aspects of heart-disease were well known among young adult African Americans. 	 RESULTS
Knowledge of certain other important risk factors (menopause) and preventive behaviors (eating fewer animal products), however, was more variable and inconsistent among the respondents. 	 RESULTS
Differences in knowledge of individual variables was greater by education level than by gender overall. 	 RESULTS
Predictors of a summary CVD knowledge score included higher education, female gender, and high self-efficacy (adjusted R2 = 0.158, p < .001). 	 RESULTS
Predictors of self-efficacy in changing CVD risk were higher education and perceived low risk of CVD (adjusted R2 = 0.064, p < .001), but these characteristics explained only 6% of the variance. 	 RESULTS
Evaluation of baseline knowledge of CVD is essential before designing and implementing health promotion programs. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Existing strengths and weaknesses in knowledge can guide tailoring of programs to be more effective. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Further research would help to identify the range of other characteristics that determine knowledge and risk perception. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To evaluate the association of overall and specific headaches with volume of white matter hyperintensities, brain infarcts, and cognition. 	 OBJECTIVE
Population based, cross sectional study. 	 DESIGN
Epidemiology of Vascular Ageing study, Nantes, France. 	 SETTING
780 participants (mean age 69, 58.5% women) with detailed headache assessment. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Brain scans were evaluated for volume of white matter hyperintensities (by fully automated imaging processing) and for classification of infarcts (by visual reading with a standardised assessment grid). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Cognitive function was assessed by a battery of tests including the mini-mental state examination. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
163 (20.9%) participants reported a history of severe headache and 116 had migraine, of whom 17 (14.7%) reported aura symptoms. 	 RESULTS
An association was found between any history of severe headache and increasing volume of white matter hyperintensities. 	 RESULTS
The adjusted odds ratio of being in the highest third for total volume of white matter hyperintensities was 2.0 (95% confidence interval 1.3 to 3.1, P for trend 0.002) for participants with any history of severe headache when compared with participants without severe headache being in the lowest third. 	 RESULTS
The association pattern was similar for all headache types. 	 RESULTS
Migraine with aura was the only headache type strongly associated with volume of deep white matter hyperintensities (highest third odds ratio 12.4, 1.6 to 99.4, P for trend 0.005) and with brain infarcts (3.4, 1.2 to 9.3). 	 RESULTS
The location of infarcts was predominantly outside the cerebellum and brain stem. 	 RESULTS
Evidence was lacking for cognitive impairment for any headache type with or without brain lesions. 	 RESULTS
In this population based study, any history of severe headache was associated with an increased volume of white matter hyperintensities. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Migraine with aura was the only headache type associated with brain infarcts. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Evidence that headache of any type by itself or in combination with brain lesions was associated with cognitive impairment was lacking. 	 CONCLUSIONS
CCR2 plays a key role in regulating monocyte trafficking to sites of inflammation and therefore has been the focus of much interest as a target for inflammatory disease. 	 BACKGROUND
Here we examined the effects of CCR2 blockade with a potent small molecule antagonist to determine the pharmacodynamic consequences on the peripheral blood monocyte compartment in the context of acute and chronic inflammatory processes. 	 METHODS
We demonstrate that CCR2 antagonism in vivo led to a rapid decrease in the number of circulating Ly6Chi monocytes and that this decrease was largely due to the CXCR4-dependent sequestration of these cells in the bone marrow, providing pharmacological evidence for a mechanism by which monocyte dynamics are regulated in vivo. 	 RESULTS
CCR2 antagonism led to an accumulation of circulating CCL2 and CCL7 levels in the blood, indicating a role for CCR2 in regulating the levels of its ligands under homeostatic conditions. 	 RESULTS
