We controlled for sociodemographic characteristics, and for general practice using a random effect, and further, controlled for, and explored the importance of, health-related quality of life measured using the EuroQoL (EQ-5D) scale. 	 DESIGN AND METHODS
Most patients with long-term conditions report a positive experience of care at their general practice (after adjusting for sociodemographic characteristics and general practice, range 74.0-93.1% reporting positive experience of care across seven questions) with only modest variation by type of condition. 	 RESULTS
For all three domains of patient experience, an increasing number of comorbid conditions is associated with a reducing percentage of patients reporting a positive experience of care. 	 RESULTS
For example, compared with respondents with no long-term condition, the OR for reporting a positive experience is 0.83 (95% CI 0.80 to 0.87) for respondents with four or more long-term conditions. 	 RESULTS
However, this relationship is no longer observed after adjusting for health-related quality of life (OR (95% CI) single condition=1.23 (1.21 to 1.26); four or more conditions=1.31 (1.25 to 1.37)), with pain making the greatest difference among five quality of life variables included in the analysis. 	 RESULTS
Patients with multiple long-term conditions more frequently report worse experiences in primary care. 	 CONCLUSIONS
However, patient-centred measures of health-related quality of life, especially pain, are more important than the number of conditions in explaining why patients with multiple long-term conditions report worse experiences of care. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To investigate comparative national trends in mortality from conditions amenable to timely, appropriate medical care and from those considered not to be amenable to such care. 	 OBJECTIVE
Analysis of trends in direct age standardised mortality from the 1950s to 1987. 	 DESIGN
Four eastern European nations (Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, the German Democratic Republic) and two western European (the Federal Republic of Germany and England and Wales) and two North American nations (United States and Canada). 	 SETTING
The total populations of the relevant countries during the period examined. 	 SUBJECTS
Proportional changes over time in age standardised mortality. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Mortality from amenable and non-amenable causes was restricted to the age group 0-64. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
A divergence in the trends for all cause mortality between eastern Europe and the western nations occurred in about 1970, when the rates in western countries steadily declined but those in eastern Europe remained fairly static. 	 RESULTS
In the age group 0-64 mortality from causes considered amenable to medical care fell less quickly in eastern Europe than in the West, particularly after 1970. 	 RESULTS
In the same age group, mortality from non-amenable causes rose in eastern European countries from the late 1960s compared with substantial declines in such mortality in the West. 	 RESULTS
Non-amenable causes of death seem to be the principal, but not exclusive, reason for lack of improvement in trends in all cause mortality in eastern Europe from 1970. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The agenda for action in eastern Europe should give priority to a healthier lifestyle and improvement of the environment though not neglect enhancements in the quality and efficiency of direct health services. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To report data relating to the informed uptake of screening tests. 	 OBJECTIVE
Electronic databases, bibliographies and experts were used to identify relevant published and unpublished studies up until August 2000. 	 SEARCH STRATEGY
RCTs, quasi-RCTs and controlled trials of interventions aimed at increasing the informed uptake of screening. 	 INCLUSION CRITERIA
All participants were eligible as defined by the entry criteria of individual programmes. 	 INCLUSION CRITERIA
Studies had to report actual uptake and meet three out of four criteria used to define informed uptake. 	 INCLUSION CRITERIA
Relevant studies were identified, data extracted and their validity assessed by two reviewers independently. 	 DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS
Outcome data included screening uptake, knowledge, informed decision-making and attitudes to screening. 	 DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS
A random-effects model was used to calculate individual relative risks and 95% confidence intervals. 	 DATA EXTRACTION AND SYNTHESIS
Six controlled trials (five RCTs and one quasi-RCT), focusing on antenatal and prostate specific antigen screening, were included. 	 MAIN RESULTS
All reported risks/benefits of screening and assessed knowledge. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Two also assessed decision-making. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Two reported risks/benefits to all randomized groups and evaluated different ways of presenting information. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Neither found that interventions such as videos, information leaflets with decision trees, or touch screen computers conveyed any additional benefits over well-prepared leaflets. 	 MAIN RESULTS
There is some evidence to suggest that changing the format of informed choice interventions in screening does not alter knowledge, satisfaction or decisions about screening. 	 CONCLUSIONS
It is not clear whether informed choice in screening affects uptake. 	 CONCLUSIONS
More well-designed RCTs are required and further research should also be directed towards the development of a valid instrument for measuring all components of informed choice in screening. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Five or more circulating tumor cells (CTCs) per 7.5 mL of blood predicts for poorer progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with metastatic breast cancer (MBC). 	 PURPOSE
We conducted a prospective study to demonstrate that CTC results correlate strongly with radiographic disease progression at the time of and in advance of imaging. 	 PURPOSE
Serial CTC levels were obtained in patients starting a new treatment regimen for progressive, radiographically measurable MBC. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Peripheral blood was collected for CTC enumeration at baseline and at 3- to 4-week intervals. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Clinical outcomes were based on radiographic studies performed in 9- to 12-week intervals. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Sixty-eight patients were evaluable for the CTC-imaging correlations, and 74 patients were evaluable for the PFS analysis. 	 RESULTS
Median follow-up was 13.3 months. 	 RESULTS
A statistically significant correlation was demonstrated between CTC levels and radiographic disease progression in patients receiving chemotherapy or endocrine therapy. 	 RESULTS
This correlation applied to CTC results obtained at the time of imaging (odds ratio [OR], 6.3), 3 to 5 weeks before imaging (OR, 3.1), and 7 to 9 weeks before imaging (OR, 4.9). 	 RESULTS
Results from analyses stratified by type of therapy remained statistically significant. 	 RESULTS
Shorter PFS was observed for patients with five or more CTCs at 3 to 5 weeks and at 7 to 9 weeks after the start of treatment. 	 RESULTS
We provide, to our knowledge, the first evidence of a strong correlation between CTC results and radiographic disease progression in patients receiving chemotherapy or endocrine therapy for MBC. 	 CONCLUSION
These findings support the role of CTC enumeration as an adjunct to standard methods of monitoring disease status in MBC. 	 CONCLUSION
Gastric bypass patients with a range of disturbed eating patterns before surgery may be at risk of returning to old patterns postoperatively. 	 BACKGROUND
Recent research has shown that binge eating is common among the obese before surgery as well as in the postoperative maintenance phase and appears to be linked to poorer outcome. 	 BACKGROUND
Although "grazing" behavior has not been specifically studied, it is also a high-risk pattern. 	 BACKGROUND
This paper is a descriptive investigation summarizing postoperative eating patterns in a group of patients. 	 BACKGROUND
Patients completed self-report questionnaires before surgery and were seen for a preoperative mental health evaluation with particular focus on assessing eating patterns. 	 METHODS
Patients with high-risk eating patterns, both binge eating and "grazing", were identified, invited to attend a post-surgery therapy group, and were given additional follow-up questionnaires regarding postoperative eating patterns. 	 METHODS
Consistent with recent studies, many high-risk patients reported recurrent loss of control over eating and, in some cases, subsequent weight gain. 	 RESULTS
Although no longer able to eat large amounts, "grazing" became a more common pattern, appearing >or=6 months following surgery. 	 RESULTS
Different forms of overeating need to be assessed in this population, focusing on the subjective loss of control rather than on the quantity consumed. 	 CONCLUSION
Although many patients do not meet strict criteria for binge eating disorder before surgery, these "grazers" are also high-risk. 	 CONCLUSION
Former binge eaters often turn into "grazers" following surgery. 	 CONCLUSION
Interventions are needed for at-risk patients. 	 CONCLUSION
Real-time adherence monitoring is now possible through medication storage devices equipped with cellular technology. 	 BACKGROUND
We assessed the effect of triggered cell phone reminders and counseling using objective adherence data on antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence among Chinese HIV-infected patients. 	 BACKGROUND
We provided ART patients in Nanning, China, with a medication device (Wisepill) to monitor their ART adherence electronically. 	 METHODS
After 3 months, we randomized subjects within optimal (≥95%) and suboptimal (<95%) adherence strata to intervention vs. control arms. 	 METHODS
In months 4-9, intervention subjects received individualized reminders triggered by late dose taking (no device opening by 30 minutes past dose time) and counseling using device-generated data. 	 METHODS
Controls received no reminders or data-informed counseling. 	 METHODS
We compared postintervention proportions achieving optimal adherence, mean adherence, and clinical outcomes. 	 METHODS
Of 120 subjects enrolled, 116 (96.7%) completed the trial. 	 RESULTS
Preintervention optimal adherence was similar in intervention vs. control arms (63.5% vs. 58.9%, respectively; P = 0.60). 	 RESULTS
In the last intervention month, 87.3% vs. 51.8% achieved optimal adherence [risk ratio (RR): 1.7, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.3 to 2.2] and mean adherence was 96.2% vs. 89.1% (P = 0.003). 	 RESULTS
Among preintervention suboptimal adherers, 78.3% vs. 33.3% (RR: 2.4, CI: 1.2 to 4.5) achieved optimal adherence and mean adherence was 93.3% vs. 84.7% (P = 0.039). 	 RESULTS
Proportions were 92.5% and 62.9% among optimal adherers, respectively (RR: 1.5, CI: 1.1 to 1.9) and mean adherence was 97.8% vs. 91.7% (P = 0.028). 	 RESULTS
Postintervention clinical outcomes were not significant. 	 RESULTS
Real-time reminders significantly improved ART adherence in this population. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This approach seems promising for managing HIV and other chronic diseases and warrants further investigation and adaptation in other settings. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Most gynecologists determine therapy based on current International Society of Gynecologic Pathologists (ISGP)/World Health Organization classification of endometrial hyperplasia, the reproducibility of which has been questioned. 	 BACKGROUND
The Gynecologic Oncology Group (GOG) initiated a protocol to assess the efficacy of hormonal therapy of atypical endometrial hyperplasia (AEH). 	 BACKGROUND
Primary goals of the first phase (Part A) were to prospectively determine reproducibility of referring institution's pathologist's diagnosis of AEH by a panel of 3 gynecologic pathologists and to determine reproducibility of diagnoses by panel members. 	 BACKGROUND
Three hundred six women were entered on this protocol with a referring institution's pathologist diagnosis of AEH based on biopsy or curettage. 	 METHODS
Available slides were assessed independently and interpreted by each of a panel of 3 gynecologic pathologists who used International Society of Gynecologic Pathologists (ISGP)/World Health Organization criteria. 	 METHODS
The majority diagnosis was based on diagnostic concordance by at least 2 of the 3 panelists. 	 METHODS
The referring institution's pathologist's diagnosis of AEH was supported by the majority of the panel in only 38% of cases. 	 RESULTS
Overall kappa value for the panel diagnosis of AEH was 0.28. 	 RESULTS
The majority diagnosis was adenocarcinoma in 29%, cycling endometrium in 7%, and nonatypical hyperplasia in 18% of cases. 	 RESULTS
Unanimous agreement for any diagnosis was reached among all 3 of the panel in 40% of cases. 	 RESULTS
For the panel, paired kappa values for any diagnosis ranged 0.34-0.43, with an overall kappa value of 0.40. 	 RESULTS
Reproducibility of referring institution's pathologists' diagnosis of AEH by a panel of gynecologic pathologists is poor. 	 CONCLUSION
Both underestimation and overestimation of the severity of the lesion are very common. 	 CONCLUSION
The level of reproducibility among subspecialist panel members for diagnosis of AEH in these specimens also is poor. 	 CONCLUSION
Better criteria and better sampling are needed to improve reproducibility of this diagnosis, particularly if it is to be used for clinical decisions. 	 CONCLUSION
To resolve uncertainty as to the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) associated with sleeping in bed with your baby if neither parent smokes and the baby is breastfed. 	 OBJECTIVE
Bed sharing was defined as sleeping with a baby in the parents' bed; room sharing as baby sleeping in the parents' room. 	 DESIGN
Frequency of bed sharing during last sleep was compared between babies who died of SIDS and living control infants. 	 DESIGN
Five large SIDS case-control datasets were combined. 	 DESIGN
Missing data were imputed. 	 DESIGN
Random effects logistic regression controlled for confounding factors. 	 DESIGN
Home sleeping arrangements of infants in 19 studies across the UK, Europe and Australasia. 	 SETTING
1472 SIDS cases, and 4679 controls. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Each study effectively included all cases, by standard criteria. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Controls were randomly selected normal infants of similar age, time and place. 	 PARTICIPANTS
In the combined dataset, 22.2% of cases and 9.6% of controls were bed sharing, adjusted OR (AOR) for all ages 2.7; 95% CI (1.4 to 5.3). 	 RESULTS
Bed sharing risk decreased with increasing infant age. 	 RESULTS
When neither parent smoked, and the baby was less than 3 months, breastfed and had no other risk factors, the AOR for bed sharing versus room sharing was 5.1 (2.3 to 11.4) and estimated absolute risk for these room sharing infants was very low (0.08 (0.05 to 0.14)/1000 live-births). 	 RESULTS
This increased to 0.23 (0.11 to 0.43)/1000 when bed sharing. 	 RESULTS
Smoking and alcohol use greatly increased bed sharing risk. 	 RESULTS
Bed sharing for sleep when the parents do not smoke or take alcohol or drugs increases the risk of SIDS. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Risks associated with bed sharing are greatly increased when combined with parental smoking, maternal alcohol consumption and/or drug use. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A substantial reduction of SIDS rates could be achieved if parents avoided bed sharing. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To define the impact of chronic viremia and associated immune activation on B-cell exhaustion in HIV infection. 	 OBJECTIVE
Progressive HIV infection is marked by B-cell anergy and exhaustion coupled with dramatic hypergammaglobulinemia. 	 DESIGN
Although both upregulation of CD95 and loss of CD21 have been used as markers of infection-associated B-cell dysfunction, little is known regarding the specific profiles of dysfunctional B cells and whether persistent viral replication and its associated immune activation play a central role in driving B-cell dysfunction. 	 DESIGN
Multiparameter flow cytometry was used to define the profile of dysfunctional B cells. 	 METHODS
The changes in the expression of CD21 and CD95 were tracked on B-cell subpopulations in patients with differential control of viral replication. 	 METHODS
: Although the emergence of exhausted, CD21 tissue-like memory B cells followed similar patterns in both progressors and controllers, the frequency of CD21 activated memory B cells was lower in spontaneous controllers. 	 RESULTS
Our results suggest that the loss of CD21 and the upregulation of CD95 occur as separate events during the development of B-cell dysfunction. 	 CONCLUSION
The loss of CD21 is a marker of B-cell exhaustion induced in the absence of appreciable viral replication, whereas the upregulation of CD95 is tightly linked to persistent viral replication and its associated immune activation. 	 CONCLUSION
Thus, these dysfunctional profiles potentially represent two functionally distinct states within the B-cell compartment. 	 CONCLUSION
The bidirectional relationships between metabolic syndrome (MetS) and schizophrenia (SCZ) play a crucial role in clinical treatment of both diseases but such bidirectional causal effects have not been comprehensively elucidated. 	 BACKGROUND
To investigate the influence of MetS on incident SCZ and the opposite direction as well as their predictors for each direction with a population-based cohort sample. 	 AIMS
We enrolled 76,545 subjects who had participated in a community-based health screening program during 1999-2004. 	 METHOD
After excluding those with the existing MetS or SCZ at baseline, the two normal prospective cohorts corresponding to each independent variable of MetS or SCZ, respectively, were followed over time to ascertain incident outcome of SCZ and MetS. The crude and adjusted hazard ratios for the effect of the predictor on each incident outcome were estimated after controlling for the possible confounding factors. 	 METHOD
The overall incidence rate (per 10(5)person-years) of SCZ was 61.15. 	 RESULTS
The incidence rate in patients with MetS was lower than those without (44.24 versus 64.20), indicating the presence of MetS failed to find an increased risk of developing incident SCZ. 	 RESULTS
However, participants with abnormal waist circumference (WC) were two times (95% CI: 1.37 to 2.93) more likely to yield incident SCZ compared to those with normal WC. 	 RESULTS
In the opposite direction, the incidence of MetS was statistically higher in patients with SCZ than those without SCZ (11.25% vs 7.94%, respectively), suggesting SCZ conferred a higher risk for yielding incident MetS (adjusted hazard ratio=1.89, 95% CI: 1.36, 2.63). 	 RESULTS
After examining the bidirectional causal relationships between SCZ and MetS with the theoretically sound and large population-based prospective cohort study, central obesity, one of the individual components of MetS, was corroborated as an independent predictor for incident SCZ. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Patients diagnosed with SCZ were at greater risk of having incident cases of MetS. Such significant temporal bidirectional relationships between SCZ and central obesity suggest a reciprocal interaction exits between SCZ and central obesity. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Large-scale genome projects generate a rapidly increasing number of sequences, most of them biochemically uncharacterized. 	 MOTIVATION
Research in bioinformatics contributes to the development of methods for the computational characterization of these sequences. 	 MOTIVATION
However, the installation and application of these methods require experience and are time consuming. 	 MOTIVATION
We present here an automatic system for preliminary functional annotation of protein sequences that has been applied to the analysis of sets of sequences from complete genomes, both to refine overall performance and to make new discoveries comparable to those made by human experts. 	 RESULTS
The GeneQuiz system includes a Web-based browser that allows examination of the evidence leading to an automatic annotation and offers additional information, views of the results, and links to biological databases that complement the automatic analysis. 	 RESULTS
System structure and operating principles concerning the use of multiple sequence databases, underlying sequence analysis tools, lexical analyses of database annotations and decision criteria for functional assignments are detailed. 	 RESULTS
The system makes automatic quality assessments of results based on prior experience with the underlying sequence analysis tools; overall error rates in functional assignment are estimated at 2.5-5% for cases annotated with highest reliability ('clear' cases). 	 RESULTS
Sources of over-interpretation of results are discussed with proposals for improvement. 	 RESULTS
A conservative definition for reporting 'new findings' that takes account of database maturity is presented along with examples of possible kinds of discoveries (new function, family and superfamily) made by the system. 	 RESULTS
System performance in relation to sequence database coverage, database dynamics and database search methods is analysed, demonstrating the inherent advantages of an integrated automatic approach using multiple databases and search methods applied in an objective and repeatable manner. 	 RESULTS
The GeneQuiz system is publicly available for analysis of protein sequences through a Web server at http://www.sander.ebi.ac. 	 AVAILABILITY
uk/gqsrv/submit 	 AVAILABILITY
To examine associations between mean daily fluid balance during intensive care unit study enrollment and clinical outcomes in patients enrolled in the Randomized Evaluation of Normal vs. Augmented Level (RENAL) replacement therapy study. 	 OBJECTIVE
Statistical analysis of data from multicenter, randomized, controlled trials. 	 DESIGN
Thirty-five intensive care units in Australia and New Zealand. 	 SETTING
Cohort of 1453 patients enrolled in the RENAL study. 	 PATIENTS
We analyzed the association between daily fluid balance on clinical outcomes using multivariable logistic regression, Cox proportional hazards, time-dependent analysis, and repeated measure analysis models. 	 INTERVENTIONS
During intensive care unit stay, mean daily fluid balance among survivors was -234 mL/day compared with +560 mL/day among nonsurvivors (p < .0001). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
Mean cumulative fluid balance over the same period was -1941 vs. +1755 mL (p = .0003). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
A negative mean daily fluid balance during study treatment was independently associated with a decreased risk of death at 90 days (odds ratio 0.318; 95% confidence interval 0.24-0.43; p < .000.1) and with increased survival time (p < .0001). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
In addition, a negative mean daily fluid balance was associated with significantly increased renal replacement-free days (p = .0017), intensive care unit-free days (p < .0001), and hospital-free days (p = .01). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
These findings were unaltered after the application of different statistical models. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
In the RENAL study, a negative mean daily fluid balance was consistently associated with improved clinical outcomes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Fluid balance may be a target for specific manipulation in future interventional trials of critically ill patients receiving renal replacement therapy. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To quantify the effects of quantity and frequency of alcohol consumption on risk of acute myocardial infarction and coronary death. 	 OBJECTIVE
Case-control study. 	 DESIGN
Lower Hunter region of New South Wales, Australia, 1983-94. 	 SETTING
Men and women aged 35-69 years. 	 SUBJECTS
Acute myocardial infarction or coronary death. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
Alcohol consumption patterns were compared between 11,511 cases of acute myocardial infarction or coronary death and 6077 controls randomly selected from the same study population. 	 RESULTS
After adjusting for the effects of age, smoking, and medical history, men and women who consumed one or two drinks of alcohol on five or six days a week had a reduction in risk of a major coronary event compared with men and women who were non-drinkers (odds ratios: men 0.31 (95% confidence interval 0.22 to 0.45); women 0.33 (0.18 to 0.59)). 	 RESULTS
A similar reduction in risk was found after excluding non-drinkers who were formerly moderate to heavy drinkers. 	 RESULTS
An acute protective effect of alcohol consumption was also found for regular drinkers who consumed one or two drinks in the 24 hours preceding the onset of symptoms (odds ratios: men 0.74 (0.51 to 1.09); women 0.43 (0.20 to 0.95)). 	 RESULTS
Frequency and quantity of alcohol consumption are important in assessing the risk of a major coronary event. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Risk is lowest among men who report one to four drinks daily on five or six days a week and among women who report one or two drinks daily on five or six days a week. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To assess mortality, quality of life (QOL), and quality-adjusted life-years (QALYs) for critically ill elderly patients. 	 OBJECTIVES
Cross-sectional survey. 	 DESIGN
A ten-bed medical-surgical intensive care unit (ICU) in a tertiary care university hospital. 	 SETTING
The study group included 882 elderly patients (> or =65 yrs of age) and 1,827 controls (<65 yrs of age) treated during the period of 1995 to 2000. 	 PATIENTS
None. 	 INTERVENTION
Mortality was assessed during the ICU and hospital stays, and 12, 24, and 36 months after ICU discharge. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
The cumulative 3-yr mortality rate among the elderly (57%) was higher (p < .05) than that among the controls (40%). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
The majority (66%) of the elderly nonsurvivors died within 1 month after intensive care discharge. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
All elderly patients with day-1 Sequential Organ Failure (SOFA) scores >15 died during the ICU stay. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
was assessed with EQ-5D and RAND-36 measures from 10 months to 7 yrs after discharge. 	 QOL
The majority (88%) of the elderly survivors assessed their present health state as good or satisfactory; 66% found it to be similar or better than 12 months earlier, and 48% similar or better than their preadmission state. 	 QOL
measures by RAND-36 revealed that aging decreased their competencies most in physical functioning, physical role limitations, and vitality, but the elderly had better values in mental health than the controls. 	 QOL
However, QALYs of the elderly respondents were 21% to 35% lower than the mean QALY minus 2 sd units of the age- and gender-adjusted general population. 	 QOL
High age alone is not a valid reason to refuse intensive care, but the benefits perceived by intensive care seem to decrease with aging, if reflected as QALYs. 	 CONCLUSIONS
However, 97% of the elderly survivors lived at home and 88% of them considered their QOL satisfactory or good after hospital discharge. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Therefore, more reliable information on the outcome for the elderly is clearly needed. 	 CONCLUSIONS
OF REVIEW As the migration of neutrophils from blood to inflamed tissues is an essential component of innate immunity and a key contributing factor to the pathogenesis of inflammatory disorders, this aspect of leukocyte biology continues to be a highly dynamic field of research. 	 PURPOSE
This review summarizes recent findings in this area, focusing on the mechanisms that mediate neutrophil transmigration, an area where significant progress has been made. 	 PURPOSE
The topics to be covered will include responses that are prerequisite to neutrophil migration through venular walls, such as leukocyte luminal crawling and cellular and molecular changes in leukocytes and endothelial cells (e.g. formation of protrusions) that collectively support leukocyte transendothelial cell migration. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Advances in both paracellular and transcellular neutrophil migration through endothelial cells will be discussed, addressing the associated roles and regulation of expression of endothelial cell luminal and junctional adhesion molecules. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Beyond the endothelium, migration through the vascular pericyte coverage and basement membrane will be reviewed. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
The unquestionable role of neutrophils in the development and progression of inflammatory conditions suggests that a better understanding of the tissue-specific and stimulus-specific mechanisms that mediate this response may identify novel pathways that could be exploited for the development of more specific anti-inflammatory interventions. 	 SUMMARY
To investigate incidence, mortality and case survival trends for cancer of unknown primary site (CUP) and consider clinical implications. 	 OBJECTIVES
South Australian Cancer Registry data were used to calculate age-standardised incidence and mortality rates from 1977 to 2004. 	 METHOD
Disease-specific survivals, socio-demographic, histological and secular predictors of CUP, compared with cancers of known primary site, and of CUP histological types, using multivariable logistic regression were investigated. 	 METHOD
Incidence and mortality rates increased approximately 60% between 1977--80 and 1981--84. 	 RESULTS
Rates peaked in 1993--96. 	 RESULTS
Male to female incidence and mortality rate ratios approximated 1.3:1. 	 RESULTS
Incidence and mortality rates increased with age. 	 RESULTS
The odds of unspecified histological type, compared with the more common adenocarcinomas, were higher for males than females, non-metropolitan residents, low socio-economic areas, and for 1977--88 than subsequent diagnostic periods. 	 RESULTS
represented a higher proportion of cancers in Indigenous patients. 	 CUP
Case survival was 7% at 10 years from diagnosis. 	 CUP
Factors predictive of lower case survival included older age, male sex, Indigenous status, lower socio-economic status, and unspecified histology type. 	 CUP
Results point to poor CUP outcomes, but with a modest improvement in survival. 	 CONCLUSION
The study identifies socio-demographic groups at elevated risk of CUP and of worse treatment outcomes where increased research and clinical attention are required. 	 CONCLUSION
Although inhaled corticosteroids have an established role in the treatment of asthma, studies have tended to concentrate on non-smokers and little is known about the possible effect of cigarette smoking on the efficacy of treatment with inhaled steroids in asthma. 	 BACKGROUND
A study was undertaken to investigate the effect of active cigarette smoking on responses to treatment with inhaled corticosteroids in patients with mild asthma. 	 BACKGROUND
The effect of treatment with inhaled fluticasone propionate (1000 microg daily) or placebo for 3 weeks was studied in a double blind, prospective, randomised, placebo controlled study of 38 steroid naïve adult asthmatic patients (21 non-smokers). 	 METHODS
Efficacy was assessed using morning and evening peak expiratory flow (PEF) readings, spirometric parameters, bronchial hyperreactivity, and sputum eosinophil counts. 	 METHODS
Comparison was made between responses to treatment in non-smoking and smoking asthmatic patients. 	 METHODS
There was a significantly greater increase in mean morning PEF in non-smokers than in smokers following inhaled fluticasone (27 l/min v -5 l/min). 	 RESULTS
Non-smokers had a statistically significant increase in mean morning PEF (27 l/min), mean forced expiratory volume in 1 second (0.17 l), and geometric mean PC20 (2.6 doubling doses), and a significant decrease in the proportion of sputum eosinophils (-1.75%) after fluticasone compared with placebo. 	 RESULTS
No significant changes were observed in the smoking asthmatic patients for any of these parameters. 	 RESULTS
Active cigarette smoking impairs the efficacy of short term inhaled corticosteroid treatment in mild asthma. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This finding has important implications for the management of patients with mild asthma who smoke. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To systematically review and integrate data on the neurodevelopmental outcome of children after administration of a single course of antenatal corticosteroids for threatened preterm labor. 	 OBJECTIVE
MEDLINE, Scopus, CENTRAL, and www.clinicaltrials.gov (inception to August 2014) using combinations of the terms "prenatal," "antenatal," "cortico*," "*steroid*," "betamethasone," "dexamethasone," "neurodevelopment*," "*development*," and "follow-up. 	 DATA SOURCES
" 	 DATA SOURCES
We perused the references of the retrieved articles. 	 DATA SOURCES
OF STUDY SELECTION We included randomized and nonrandomized trials reporting on the neurodevelopmental outcomes of children whose mothers were administered a single course of betamethasone or dexamethasone antenatally for threatened preterm birth as opposed to placebo or no treatment. 	 METHODS
TABULATION, INTEGRATION, AND RESULTS Summary risk ratio (RR) was calculated for dichotomous data; standardized mean difference was calculated for trials that measured the same outcome but used different methods. 	 METHODS
Heterogeneity was assessed using the I statistic. 	 METHODS
Sensitivity and subgroup analyses were planned according to study design, specific steroid, and mean gestational age at birth. 	 METHODS
A single course of antenatal corticosteroids was associated with reduced risk for cerebral palsy (seven studies; treated: 390 of 5,199, untreated: 146 of 1,379; RR 0.678, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.564-0.815), psychomotor development index less than 70 (two studies; treated: 783 of 3,049, untreated: 258 of 969; RR 0.829, 95% CI 0.737-0.933), and severe disability (five studies; treated: 1,567 of 4,840, untreated: 475 of 1,211; RR 0.787, 95% CI 0.729-0.850). 	 METHODS
Steroid treatment increased the rates of intact survival (six studies; treated: 1,082 of 2,013, untreated: 273 of 561; RR 1.186, 95% CI 1.056-1.332). 	 METHODS
Betamethasone was found to significantly decrease the risk for severe disability and increase the rate of intact survival. 	 METHODS
Dexamethasone increased the rate of intact survival; however, data for dexametasone and the other planned subgroup analyses were limited (fewer than 1,000 children at most). 	 METHODS
The major limitations involved inclusion of nonrandomized studies and scarcity of data on finer neurodevelopmental outcomes. 	 METHODS
A single course of antenatal corticosteroids in women at high risk for preterm birth appears to improve most neurodevelopmental outcomes in offspring born before 34 weeks of gestation. 	 CONCLUSION
Minimal (< 10 mm thick) pleural effusion (PE) may represent an early phase of malignant PE, but its clinical relevance has rarely been studied. 	 PURPOSE
Therefore, we examined the proportion of minimal PE in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and its impact on survival. 	 PURPOSE
We also considered possible accumulation mechanisms in our data set. 	 PURPOSE
On the basis of PE status from chest computed tomography scans at diagnosis, 2,061 patients were classified into three groups: no PE, minimal PE, and malignant PE. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Twenty-one variables associated with four factors-patient, stage migration, tumor, and treatment-were investigated for correlation with survival. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Minimal PE presented in 272 patients (13.2%). 	 RESULTS
Of 2,061 patients, the proportion of each stage was the following: 5.2% stage I, 10.9% stage II, 13.2% stage IIIA, 23.8% stage IIIB, and 13.9% stage IV. 	 RESULTS
Minimal PE correlated significantly with shorter survival time than did no PE (median survival time, 7.7 v 17.7 months; log-rank P < .001), even after full adjustment with all variables (adjusted hazard ratio, 1.40; 95% CI, 1.21 to 1.62). 	 RESULTS
Prognostic impact of minimal PE was higher in early versus advanced stages (Pinteraction = .001). 	 RESULTS
In 237 patients (87.8%) with minimal PE, pleural invasion or attachment as a direct mechanism was observed, and it was an independent factor predicting worse survival (P = .03). 	 RESULTS
Minimal PE is a commonly encountered clinical concern in staging NSCLCs. 	 CONCLUSION
Its presence is an important prognostic factor of worse survival, especially in early-stage disease. 	 CONCLUSION
We investigated the outcome of repeated gamma knife radiosurgery (GKS) for local or remote recurrence after initial radiosurgery. 	 OBJECTIVE
We retrospectively reviewed 204 patients who were treated with GKS. 	 MATERIAL AND METHODS
Among them 43 patients (21%) underwent GKS more than once. 	 MATERIAL AND METHODS
The second GKS was given for recurrence at the previously treated sites in 16 patients, new lesions at remote sites in 13, and both local recurrence and new lesions in 14. 	 MATERIAL AND METHODS
The median survival from the first GKS was 36 (7-190) weeks in all patients and 68 (16-156) weeks in 43 patients with repeated GKS. 	 RESULTS
The median time from the first GKS to the second was 37 weeks. 	 RESULTS
The median survival from the second radiosurgical intervention was 32 (7-132) weeks. 	 RESULTS
Local control rate at 6 months after salvage GKS was 90.7%. 	 RESULTS
class was the commonly dominant prognostic factor in both initial and salvage GKS. 	 RPA
Recurrence is common for patients with metastatic brain tumors after initial radiosurgery. 	 CONCLUSION
Local control and survival time after salvage treatment are comparable with those after initial radiosurgery. 	 CONCLUSION
as a salvage treatment may provide additional survival benefit in selected patients. 	 GKS
To examine the symptoms of hypoglycemia in children with insulin-dependent diabetes, from the perspective both of the child and of the child's parents, and to compare the symptom reporting of the diabetic children with that of adult diabetic patients. 	 OBJECTIVE
Interviews were conducted with 100 parents and 43 of their children. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
The frequency and intensity of symptoms of hypoglycemia were documented using a structured interview and classified into groups using Principal Components Analysis (PCA). 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Diabetic children and their parents showed close agreement concerning the relative frequency and the intensity of symptoms reported. 	 RESULTS
of the symptom reports showed that diabetic children and their parents identified the same distinct subgroups of hypoglycemia-related symptoms: behavioral disturbance and autonomic-neuroglycopenic subgroups. 	 PCA
Hypoglycemic symptoms in children with diabetes clearly differ from those experienced by insulin-treated adults and, in particular, include behavioral changes as primary features of a low blood glucose. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These observations have important implications for parental education on hypoglycemia. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To examine the association between the use of right heart catheterization (RHC) during the first 24 hours of care in the intensive care unit (ICU) and subsequent survival, length of stay, intensity of care, and cost of care. 	 OBJECTIVE
Prospective cohort study. 	 DESIGN
Five US teaching hospitals between 1989 and 1994. 	 SETTING
A total of 5735 critically ill adult patients receiving care in an ICU for 1 of 9 prespecified disease categories. 	 SUBJECTS
Survival time, cost of care, intensity of care, and length of stay in the ICU and hospital, determined from the clinical record and from the National Death Index. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
A propensity score for RHC was constructed using multivariable logistic regression. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Case-matching and multivariable regression modeling techniques were used to estimate the association of RHC with specific outcomes after adjusting for treatment selection using the propensity score. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Sensitivity analysis was used to estimate the potential effect of an unidentified or missing covariate on the results. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
By case-matching analysis, patients with RHC had an increased 30-day mortality (odds ratio, 1.24; 95% confidence interval, 1.03-1.49). 	 RESULTS
The mean cost (25th, 50th, 75th percentiles) per hospital stay was $49 300 ($17 000, $30 500, $56 600) with RHC and $35 700 ($11 300, $20 600, $39 200) without RHC. 	 RESULTS
Mean length of stay in the ICU was 14.8 (5, 9, 17) days with RHC and 13.0 (4, 7, 14) days without RHC. 	 RESULTS
These findings were all confirmed by multivariable modeling techniques. 	 RESULTS
Subgroup analysis did not reveal any patient group or site for which RHC was associated with improved outcomes. 	 RESULTS
Patients with higher baseline probability of surviving 2 months had the highest relative risk of death following RHC. 	 RESULTS
Sensitivity analysis suggested that a missing covariate would have to increase the risk of death 6-fold and the risk of RHC 6-fold for a true beneficial effect of RHC to be misrepresented as harmful. 	 RESULTS
In this observational study of critically ill patients, after adjustment for treatment selection bias, RHC was associated with increased mortality and increased utilization of resources. 	 CONCLUSION
The cause of this apparent lack of benefit is unclear. 	 CONCLUSION
The results of this analysis should be confirmed in other observational studies. 	 CONCLUSION
These findings justify reconsideration of a randomized controlled trial of RHC and may guide patient selection for such a study. 	 CONCLUSION
C-reactive protein (CRP) is a known risk factor for cardiovascular events in the healthy population and in patients with coronary artery disease. 	 BACKGROUND
High CRP levels before cardiac surgery are associated with worse short-term outcome, but its role after discharge home remains unknown. 	 BACKGROUND
The study objective was to evaluate the effect of CRP on short-term and mid-term outcome after cardiac surgery. 	 BACKGROUND
From August 2000 to May 2004, values for preoperative CRP were available for 597 unselected patients undergoing cardiac operations. 	 METHODS
of 0.5 mg/dL or more. 	 CRP
Follow-up lasted a maximum of 3 years (median, 1.8 +/- 	 CRP
1.5 years) and was 92.6% complete. 	 CRP
In-hospital mortality was 8.2% in the HIS group and 3.4% in the LIS group (odds ratio [OR], 2.61; p = 0.02). 	 RESULTS
Incidence of postoperative infections was 16.5% in the HIS group and 5.1% in the LIS group (OR, 3.25; p = 0.0001). 	 RESULTS
Sternal wound infections were also more frequent in the HIS group (10.7% versus 2.8%; OR, 3.43; p = 0.002). 	 RESULTS
During follow-up, the HIS group had worse survival (88.5% +/- 	 RESULTS
2.9% versus 91.9% +/- 	 RESULTS
2.5%; OR, 1.93; p = 0.05) and a higher need of hospitalization for cardiac-related causes (73.6% +/- 	 RESULTS
6% versus 86.5% +/- 	 RESULTS
3.2%; OR, 1.82; p = 0.05). 	 RESULTS
Patients undergoing cardiac surgery with a CRP level of 0.5 mg/dL or more are exposed to a higher risk of in-hospital mortality and postoperative infections. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Despite surgical correction of cardiac disease, a high preoperative CRP value is an independent risk factor for mid-term survival and hospitalization for cardiac causes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
& AIMS GS-9620, an oral agonist of toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7), is in clinical development for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B (CHB). 	 BACKGROUND
GS-9620 was previously shown to induce prolonged suppression of serum viral DNA and antigens in the woodchuck and chimpanzee models of CHB. 	 BACKGROUND
Herein, we investigated the molecular mechanisms that contribute to the antiviral response to GS-9620 using in vitro models of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. 	 BACKGROUND
Cryopreserved primary human hepatocytes (PHH) and differentiated HepaRG (dHepaRG) cells were infected with HBV and treated with GS-9620, conditioned media from human peripheral blood mononuclear cells treated with GS-9620 (GS-9620 conditioned media [GS-9620-CM]), or other innate immune stimuli. 	 METHODS
The antiviral and transcriptional response to these agents was determined. 	 METHODS
GS-9620 had no antiviral activity in HBV-infected PHH, consistent with low level TLR7 mRNA expression in human hepatocytes. 	 RESULTS
In contrast, GS-9620-CM induced prolonged reduction of HBV DNA, RNA, and antigen levels in PHH and dHepaRG cells via a type I interferon (IFN)-dependent mechanism. 	 RESULTS
GS-9620-CM did not reduce covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA) levels in either cell type. 	 RESULTS
Transcriptional profiling demonstrated that GS-9620-CM strongly induced various HBV restriction factors - although not APOBEC3A or the Smc5/6 complex - and indicated that established HBV infection does not modulate innate immune sensing or signaling in cryopreserved PHH. 	 RESULTS
GS-9620-CM also induced expression of immunoproteasome subunits and enhanced presentation of an immunodominant viral peptide in HBV-infected PHH. 	 RESULTS
Type I IFN induced by GS-9620 durably suppressed HBV in human hepatocytes without reducing cccDNA levels. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Moreover, HBV antigen presentation was enhanced, suggesting additional components of the TLR7-induced immune response played a role in the antiviral response to GS-9620 in animal models of CHB. 	 CONCLUSIONS
GS-9620 is a drug currently being tested in clinical trials for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. 	 LAY SUMMARY
GS-9620 has previously been shown to suppress HBV in various animal models, but the underlying antiviral mechanisms were not completely understood. 	 LAY SUMMARY
In this study, we determined that GS-9620 does not directly activate antiviral pathways in human liver cells, but can induce prolonged suppression of HBV via induction of an antiviral cytokine called interferon. 	 LAY SUMMARY
However, interferon did not destroy the HBV genome, suggesting that other parts of the immune response (e.g. activation of immune cells that kill infected cells) also play an important role in the antiviral response to GS-9620. 	 LAY SUMMARY
Falciparum malaria or malaria tropica is one of the leading causes of childhood mortality worldwide. 	 BACKGROUND
Malaria-related deaths occur mainly in sub-Saharan Africa, where an estimated 365 million clinical cases of Plasmodium falciparum malaria occur each year. 	 BACKGROUND
In Europe, imported malaria cases occur due to returning travellers or immigration mostly from African countries. 	 BACKGROUND
Children are more at risk than adults. 	 BACKGROUND
The objective of this study was to identify high risk groups for imported childhood malaria in Europe in order to guide development of strategies for prevention, early recognition and management. 	 BACKGROUND
In the period May 2003-January 2005 we reviewed all cases of paediatric malaria in the Netherlands notified by the Dutch Paediatric Surveillance System (Nederland Signalerings Centrum Kindergeneeskunde, NSCK) and the literature on imported malaria in children in Europe published between 1996 and 2006. 	 METHODS
Malaria occurred mainly in children of long-term (n = 15, 47%) and new (n = 8, 25%) immigrants and was mostly acquired in sub-Saharan Africa. 	 RESULTS
The dominant species was P. falciparum. 	 RESULTS
Only one quarter of children had used adequate malaria chemoprophylaxis. 	 RESULTS
Complicated disease occurred in 10 (31%) of cases. 	 RESULTS
We also reviewed the literature and found 6082 reported cases of imported malaria among children in Europe; among these, four died and only one was reported to develop neurological sequelae. 	 RESULTS
Imported malaria in children remains an important problem and is unlikely to decrease unless the reasons for inadequate prophylaxis are addressed. 	 CONCLUSION
Long-term exposure to pollution can lead to an increase in the rate of decline of lung function, especially in older individuals and in those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), whereas shorter-term exposure at higher pollution levels has been implicated in causing excess deaths from ischaemic heart disease and exacerbations of COPD. 	 BACKGROUND
We aimed to assess the effects on respiratory and cardiovascular responses of walking down a busy street with high levels of pollution compared with walking in a traffic-free area with lower pollution levels in older adults. 	 BACKGROUND
In this randomised, crossover study, we recruited men and women aged 60 years and older with angiographically proven stable ischaemic heart disease or stage 2 Global initiative for Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) COPD who had been clinically stable for 6 months, and age-matched healthy volunteers. 	 METHODS
Individuals with ischaemic heart disease or COPD were recruited from existing databases or outpatient respiratory and cardiology clinics at the Royal Brompton & Harefield NHS Foundation Trust and age-matched healthy volunteers using advertising and existing databases. 	 METHODS
All participants had abstained from smoking for at least 12 months and medications were taken as recommended by participants' doctors during the study. 	 METHODS
Participants were randomly assigned by drawing numbered disks at random from a bag to do a 2 h walk either along a commercial street in London (Oxford Street) or in an urban park (Hyde Park). 	 METHODS
Baseline measurements of participants were taken before the walk in the hospital laboratory. 	 METHODS
During each walk session, black carbon, particulate matter (PM) concentrations, ultrafine particles, and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) concentrations were measured. 	 METHODS
Between October, 2012, and June, 2014, we screened 135 participants, of whom 40 healthy volunteers, 40 individuals with COPD, and 39 with ischaemic heart disease were recruited. 	 FINDINGS
Concentrations of black carbon, NO2, PM10, PM2.5, and ultrafine particles were higher on Oxford Street than in Hyde Park. 	 FINDINGS
Participants with COPD reported more cough (odds ratio [OR] 1·95, 95% CI 0·96-3·95; p<0·1), sputum (3·15, 1·39-7·13; p<0·05), shortness of breath (1·86, 0·97-3·57; p<0·1), and wheeze (4·00, 1·52-10·50; p<0·05) after walking down Oxford Street compared with Hyde Park. 	 FINDINGS
In all participants, irrespective of their disease status, walking in Hyde Park led to an increase in lung function (forced expiratory volume in the first second [FEV1] and forced vital capacity [FVC]) and a decrease in pulse wave velocity (PWV) and augmentation index up to 26 h after the walk. 	 FINDINGS
By contrast, these beneficial responses were attenuated after walking on Oxford Street. 	 FINDINGS
In participants with COPD, a reduction in FEV1 and FVC, and an increase in R5-20 were associated with an increase in during-walk exposure to NO2, ultrafine particles and PM2.5, and an increase in PWV and augmentation index with NO2 and ultrafine particles. 	 FINDINGS
In healthy volunteers, PWV and augmentation index were associated both with black carbon and ultrafine particles. 	 FINDINGS
Short-term exposure to traffic pollution prevents the beneficial cardiopulmonary effects of walking in people with COPD, ischaemic heart disease, and those free from chronic cardiopulmonary diseases. 	 INTERPRETATION
Medication use might reduce the adverse effects of air pollution in individuals with ischaemic heart disease. 	 INTERPRETATION
Policies should aim to control ambient levels of air pollution along busy streets in view of these negative health effects. 	 INTERPRETATION
British Heart Foundation. 	 FUNDING
Whether immunosuppressive treatment adversely affects survival is unclear. 	 CONTEXT
To assess whether immunosuppressive drugs increase mortality. 	 OBJECTIVE
Retrospective cohort study evaluating overall and cancer mortality in relation to immunosuppressive drug exposure among patients with ocular inflammatory diseases. 	 DESIGN
Demographic, clinical, and treatment data derived from medical records, and mortality results from United States National Death Index linkage. 	 DESIGN
The cohort's mortality risk was compared with US vital statistics using standardised mortality ratios. 	 DESIGN
Overall and cancer mortality in relation to use or non-use of immunosuppressive drugs within the cohort was studied with survival analysis. 	 DESIGN
Five tertiary ocular inflammation clinics. 	 SETTING
Patients 7957 US residents with non-infectious ocular inflammation, 2340 of whom received immunosuppressive drugs during follow up. 	 SETTING
Exposures Use of antimetabolites, T cell inhibitors, alkylating agents, and tumour necrosis factor inhibitors. 	 SETTING
Overall mortality, cancer mortality. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Over 66 802 person years (17 316 after exposure to immunosuppressive drugs), 936 patients died (1.4/100 person years), 230 (24.6%) from cancer. 	 RESULTS
For patients unexposed to immunosuppressive treatment, risks of death overall (standardised mortality ratio 1.02, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.94 to 1.11) and from cancer (1.10, 0.93 to 1.29) were similar to those of the US population. 	 RESULTS
Patients who used azathioprine, methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil, ciclosporin, systemic corticosteroids, or dapsone had overall and cancer mortality similar to that of patients who never took immunosuppressive drugs. 	 RESULTS
In patients who used cyclophosphamide, overall mortality was not increased and cancer mortality was non-significantly increased. 	 RESULTS
Tumour necrosis factor inhibitors were associated with increased overall (adjusted hazard ratio [HR] 1.99, 95% CI 1.00 to 3.98) and cancer mortality (adjusted HR 3.83, 1.13 to 13.01). 	 RESULTS
Most commonly used immunosuppressive drugs do not seem to increase overall or cancer mortality. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Our results suggesting that tumour necrosis factor inhibitors might increase mortality are less robust than the other findings; additional evidence is needed. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To evaluate the association between vascular inflammation as measured by subacute C-reactive protein (CRP; 1-10 mg/l) and all-cause mortality and the association between change in CRP status (normal <or=3 mg/l and elevated >3 mg/l) and all-cause mortality. 	 OBJECTIVE
Probabilistic record linkage was used to match hospital episode data, laboratory reports and mortality statistics in a large urban population. 	 METHODS
Survival was evaluated using Cox proportional hazards regression models. 	 METHODS
22 962 patients had their first CRP measurement in the subacute range (1-10 mg/l). 	 RESULTS
Analysis grouped by each additional unit increase in CRP across the subacute range was associated with a 7.3% (95% CI 5.4% to 9.2%) increase in the hazard ratio (HR) of death over 4 years, after controlling for confounding factors (p<0.001). 	 RESULTS
Repeated CRP observations around 1 year apart were recorded in 5811 subjects. 	 RESULTS
After controlling for confounding factors, in patients whose CRP changed from normal (<or=3 mg/l) to elevated (>3 mg/l), the HR increased 6.7-fold (p<0.001) relative to cases whose CRP remained normal. 	 RESULTS
By comparison, among those subjects whose CRP was reduced from elevated to normal, the hazard ratio halved to 3.5 (p = 0.018). 	 RESULTS
In an underpowered analysis of time to cardiovascular events, an identical pattern of risk emerged. 	 RESULTS
level predicted all-cause mortality, and additional inclusion of prior change in CRP level and current CRP level more so. 	 CONCLUSIONS CRP
Increasing vascular inflammation, as measured by CRP, increases the likelihood of death. 	 CONCLUSIONS CRP
To assay the efficiency for celiac disease (CD) screening of 2 immunochromatographic visual stick assays based on human recombinant tissue transglutaminase (tTG). 	 OBJECTIVE
One was the antitissue transglutaminase antibodies (AtTGA) stick for IgA/G antibodies to tTG detection, the other was the AtTGA/antigliadin antibodies (AGA) stick for IgA antibodies for tTG and/or gliadins. 	 OBJECTIVE
In a prospective multicenter study, 4 pediatric gastroenterology units from Spain and 2 from Latin America enrolled 72 control children with a normal small bowel mucosa and 113 untreated patients with CD with Marsh type 3 lesions. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Evaluation of results by the gastroenterologists and by 2 independent observers at the coordination center showed a remarkably low interobserver variability. 	 RESULTS
For the AtTGA stick, sensitivity was 96.5% and specificity was 98.6%. 	 RESULTS
The AtTGA/AGA stick displayed a sensitivity of 94.5% and a specificity of 98.6% for AtTGA and a sensitivity of 63.1% and a specificity of 95.2% for AGA. 	 RESULTS
The highest efficiency and positive likelihood ratio was obtained for the AtTGA stick, higher than for IgA AtTGA by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. 	 RESULTS
One additional advantage was that previous investigation of total serum IgA levels could be eluded. 	 RESULTS
The IgA AtTGA/AGA stick, with an efficiency of 95.1%, compared with 89.2% when the combined results of the 2 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays were considered, turned out to be an excellent diagnostic tool for infants with no IgA deficiency. 	 RESULTS
These 2 assays are extremely efficient for CD screening, by combining a high diagnostic accuracy with the simplicity and rapidity of visual methods. 	 CONCLUSION
This study aimed to identify relevant keratin subtypes that may associate with the pathogenesis of oral epithelial neoplasms. 	 AIMS
Expression of all the keratin subtypes was examined by cDNA microarray analysis of 43 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cases. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Immunohistochemical expression of the major keratins was examined in 100 OSCC and oral epithelial dysplasia (OED) cases. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Many changes in keratin expression were observed and, significantly, consistent down-regulation of keratin 4 (K4) and K13 expression was observed. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Aberrant expression of K4 and K13 was associated with morphological changes in the affected oral epithelium. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Experiments with cell cultures transfected with various keratin subtypes suggested that alterations in keratin subtype expression can cause changes in cell shape and movement. 	 METHODS AND RESULTS
Aberrant expression of K4 and K13, which are the dominant pair of differentiation-related keratins in oral keratinocytes, indicates dysregulation of epithelial differentiation in OSCC and OED. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These keratins, especially K4, may be useful for pathological diagnosis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
We propose that the aberrant expression of K4 and K13 and concomitant up-regulation of the other keratins may be one of the causative factors for morphological alterations in the affected epithelium. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To assess the association between use of macrolide antibiotics in mothers and infants from pregnancy onset until 120 days after birth and infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). 	 OBJECTIVE
Nationwide register based cohort study. 	 DESIGN
Denmark, 1996-2011. 	 SETTING
999,378 liveborn singletons and linked individual level information on macrolide prescriptions (maternal use during pregnancy, n=30,091; maternal use after birth, n=21,557; use in infants, n=6591), surgery for IHPS, and potential confounders. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Surgery for IHPS by three categories of macrolide use: in mothers during pregnancy, in mothers after birth, and in infants after birth. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
880 infants developed IHPS (0.9 cases per 1000 births). 	 RESULTS
Compared with infants with no use of macrolides, the adjusted rate ratio for IHPS in infants with use of macrolides during days 0 to 13 after birth was 29.8 (95% confidence interval 16.4 to 54.1) and during days 14 to 120 was 3.24 (1.20 to 8.74); the corresponding absolute risk differences were 24.4 (95% confidence interval 13.0 to 44.1) and 0.65 (0.06 to 2.21) cases per 1000 infants exposed to macrolides, respectively. 	 RESULTS
The rate ratio for maternal use of macrolides for days 0 to 13 after birth was 3.49 (1.92 to 6.34) and for days 14 to 120 was 0.70 (0.26 to 1.90); the corresponding absolute risk differences were 2.15 (0.82 to 4.64) and -0.11 (-0.26 to 0.31). 	 RESULTS
The rate ratios for maternal use of macrolides during pregnancy were 1.02 (0.65 to 1.59) for weeks 0 to 27 and 1.77 (0.95 to 3.31) for weeks 28 to birth; the corresponding absolute risk differences were 0.01 (-0.31 to 0.50) and 0.67 (-0.06 to 2.02). 	 RESULTS
Treatment of young infants with macrolide antibiotics was strongly associated with IHPS and should therefore only be administered if potential treatment benefits outweigh the risk. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Maternal use of macrolides during the first two weeks after birth was also associated with an increased risk of IHPS. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A possible association was also found with use during late pregnancy. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Mitochondrial disorders are caused by gene mutations in mitochondrial or nuclear DNA and affect energy-dependent organs such as the brain. 	 OBJECTIVE
Patients with psychiatric illness, particularly those with medical comorbidities, may have primary mitochondrial disorders. 	 OBJECTIVE
To date, this issue has received little attention in the literature, and mitochondrial disorders are likely underdiagnosed in psychiatric patients. 	 OBJECTIVE
This article describes a patient who presented with borderline personality disorder and treatment-resistant depression and was ultimately diagnosed with mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS) 3271. 	 DATA SOURCES
We also searched the literature for all case reports of patients with mitochondrial disorders who initially present with prominent psychiatric symptoms by using MEDLINE (from 1948-February 2011), Embase (from 1980-February 2011), PsycINFO (from 1806-February 2011), and the search terms mitochondrial disorder, mitochondria, psychiatry, mental disorders, major depression, anxiety, schizophrenia, and psychosis. 	 DATA SOURCES
Fifty cases of mitochondrial disorders with prominent psychiatric symptomatology were identified. 	 STUDY SELECTION
Information about the psychiatric presentation of the cases was extracted. 	 DATA EXTRACTION
This information was combined with our case, the most common psychiatric manifestations of mitochondrial disorders were identified, and the important diagnostic and treatment implications for patients with psychiatric illness were reviewed. 	 DATA EXTRACTION
The most common psychiatric presentations in the cases of mitochondrial disorders included mood disorder, cognitive deterioration, psychosis, and anxiety. 	 RESULTS
The most common diagnosis (52% of cases) was a MELAS mutation. 	 RESULTS
Other genetic mitochondrial diagnoses included polymerase gamma mutations, Kearns-Sayre syndrome, mitochondrial DNA deletions, point mutations, twinkle mutations, and novel mutations. 	 RESULTS
Patients with mitochondrial disorders can present with primary psychiatric symptomatology, including mood disorder, cognitive impairment, psychosis, and anxiety. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Psychiatrists need to be aware of the clinical features that are indicative of a mitochondrial disorder, investigate patients with suggestive presentations, and be knowledgeable about the treatment implications of the diagnosis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Chronic physical comorbidity is common in dementia. 	 OBJECTIVE
However, there is an absence of evidence to support good practice guidelines for attention to these problems. 	 OBJECTIVE
We aimed to study the extent of this comorbidity and its impact on cognitive function and disability in population-based studies in low and middle income countries, where chronic diseases and impairments are likely to be both common and undertreated. 	 OBJECTIVE
A multicentre cross-sectional survey of all over 65 year old residents (n = 15 022) in 11 catchment areas in China, India, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Venezuela, Mexico and Peru. 	 METHODS
We estimated the prevalence of pain, incontinence, hearing and visual impairments, mobility impairment and undernutrition according to the presence of dementia and its severity, and, among those with dementia, the independent contribution of these impairments to cognitive function and disability, adjusting for age, gender, education and dementia severity. 	 METHODS
Incontinence, hearing impairment, mobility impairment and undernutrition were consistently linearly associated with the presence of dementia and its severity across regions. 	 RESULTS
Among people with dementia, incontinence, hearing impairment and mobility impairment were independently associated with disability in all regions while the contributions of pain, visual impairment and undernutrition were inconsistent. 	 RESULTS
Only hearing impairment made a notable independent contribution to cognitive impairment. 	 RESULTS
There is an urgent need for clinical trials of the feasibility, efficacy and cost-effectiveness of regular physical health checks and remediation of identified pathologies, given the considerable comorbidity identified in our population based studies, and the strong evidence for independent impact upon functioning. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Recent studies show that COPD patients exhibit low-grade systemic inflammation, and that plasma fibrinogen and high neutrophil counts are related to faster declines in lung function. 	 BACKGROUND
We examined correlations between serum biomarkers and the decline of lung function in COPD patients. 	 BACKGROUND
Baseline levels of 9 serum biomarkers (TIMP-1, alpha1-antitrypsin, MMP-9, TNF-alpha, TGF-beta, IL-6, IL-8, neutrophil elastase and CRP), fibrinogen and white blood cell counts (WCC) were measured in 96 COPD patients. 	 METHOD
Lung function was measured at the time of blood sampling and every 3-6 months during the observation period (median 25.0 months). 	 METHOD
Twenty patients were rapid decliners of lung function and 53 patients were non-decliners. 	 RESULTS
Neutrophil counts, serum CRP and MMP-9 were significantly higher in the rapid decliners (p<0.05). 	 RESULTS
The annual change of % predicted FEV(1) was inversely correlated with MMP-9 (r=-0.288; p<0.01) and CRP (r=-0.354; p<0.005) (partial correlation coefficients adjusted for age, sex, cardiovascular disease, smoking history, and baseline % predicted FEV(1)). 	 RESULTS
The remaining biomarkers were not correlated with the annual change of % predicted FEV(1). 	 RESULTS
Serum CRP and MMP-9 levels were related to FEV(1) decline. 	 CONCLUSION
These markers are good candidates as predictors for rapid decline of FEV(1) in COPD patients. 	 CONCLUSION
Additional long-term and larger size studies of COPD patients could help determine the exact roles for these biomarkers. 	 CONCLUSION
Patients considered for arterial surgery, have been shown to have a high incidence of coexistent cardiac, vascular and other diseases, affecting operative risk and survival. 	 BACKGROUND
We developed a systematic workup strategy for detecting these coexistent diseases in our vascular surgical patients, mainly based on non-invasive diagnostic techniques. 	 BACKGROUND
We evaluated 200 consecutive patients, admitted to the department of vascular surgery in an academic teaching hospital, in order to establish the total incidence of relevant concomitant disorders, the extent to which this screening yielded previously unknown diagnostic information, and the impact on short-term (one year) survival. 	 METHODS
Coronary artery disease was present in 46% of the patients; 22% had active ischaemia, newly diagnosed in 5.5%. 	 RESULTS
Impaired cardiac function was found in 37%: severely impaired in 12%, newly diagnosed in 27%. 	 RESULTS
Carotid artery disease was present in 32%: critical stenoses were found in 9%; new diagnoses in 29.9%. 	 RESULTS
Aortic aneurysms were present in 7%, newly diagnosed in 5%. 	 RESULTS
Severe renal artery stenosis was present in 5%, newly diagnosed in 3.5%. 	 RESULTS
Sixteen % of the patients had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, newly diagnosed in 3.5%, and 4.5% had unexpected disorders, which were all new diagnoses. 	 RESULTS
Overall, new diagnoses were reached in 64.5% of the population, affecting therapeutic strategy immediately in 21% of the patients. 	 RESULTS
The presence of coronary artery disease and of cardiac failure were clearly related to one year survival. 	 RESULTS
We conclude that a systematic screening strategy, mainly based on noninvasive techniques, can detect the presence of concomitant diseases in the vascular surgical patient. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Most important seem the newly diagnosed diseases altering surgical management in one out of every five patients; they also have important implications for patient prognosis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To assess if family care givers of patients with lung cancer experience the patterns of social, psychological, and spiritual wellbeing and distress typical of the patient, from diagnosis to death. 	 OBJECTIVE
Secondary analysis of serial qualitative interviews carried out every three months for up to a year or to bereavement. 	 DESIGN
South east Scotland. 	 SETTING
19 patients with lung cancer and their 19 family carers, totalling 88 interviews (42 with patients and 46 with carers). 	 PARTICIPANTS
Carers followed clear patterns of social, psychological, and spiritual wellbeing and distress that mirrored the experiences of those for whom they were caring, with some carers also experiencing deterioration in physical health that impacted on their ability to care. 	 RESULTS
Psychological and spiritual distress were particularly dynamic and commonly experienced. 	 RESULTS
In addition to the "Why us?" response, witnessing suffering triggered personal reflections in carers on the meaning and purpose of life. 	 RESULTS
Certain key time points in the illness tended to be particularly problematic for both carers and patients: at diagnosis, at home after initial treatment, at recurrence, and during the terminal stage. 	 RESULTS
Family carers witness and share much of the illness experience of the dying patient. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The multidimensional experience of distress suffered by patients with lung cancer was reflected in the suffering of their carers in the social, psychological, and spiritual domains, with psychological and spiritual distress being most pronounced. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Carers may need to be supported throughout the period of illness not just in the terminal phase and during bereavement, as currently tends to be the case. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Patient experience is increasingly used to assess organizational performance, for example in public reporting or pay-for-performance schemes. 	 BACKGROUND
Conventional approaches using 95% confidence intervals are commonly used to determine required survey samples or to report performance but these may result in unreliable organizational comparisons. 	 BACKGROUND
We analyzed data from 2.2 million patients who responded to the English 2009 General Practice Patient Survey, which included 45 patient experience questions nested within 6 different care domains (access, continuity of care, communication, anticipatory care planning, out-of-hours care, and overall care satisfaction). 	 METHODS
For each question, unadjusted and case-mix adjusted (for age, sex, and ethnicity) organization-level reliability, and intraclass correlation coefficients were calculated. 	 METHODS
Mean responses per organization ranged from 23 to 256 for questions evaluating primary care practices, and from 1454 to 2758 for questions evaluating out-of-hours care organizations. 	 RESULTS
Adjusted and unadjusted reliability values were similar. 	 RESULTS
Twenty-six questions had excellent reliability (≥0.90). 	 RESULTS
Seven nurse communication questions had very good reliability (≥0.85), but 3 anticipatory care planning questions had lower reliability (<0.70). 	 RESULTS
Reliability was typically <0.70 for questions with <100 mean responses per practice, usually indicating questions which only a subset of patients were eligible to answer. 	 RESULTS
Nine questions had both excellent reliability and high intraclass correlation coefficients (≥0.10) indicating both reliable measurement and substantial performance variability. 	 RESULTS
High reliability is a necessary property of indicators used to compare health care organizations. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Using the English General Practice Patient Survey as a case study, we show how reliability and intraclass correlation coefficients can be used to select measures to support robust organizational comparisons, and to design surveys that will both provide high-quality measurement and optimize survey costs. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To determine the frequency of moderate and severe hypoglycemia and to identify clinical predictors associated with its occurrence in a large population-based sample of children and adolescents with IDDM. 	 OBJECTIVE
A total of 657 patients (age: 12.1 +/- 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
4.4 years, mean +/- 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
SD) were included in the study, yielding 1,449 patient-years of data. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
A prospective assessment of severe hypoglycemia (an event resulting in a seizure or coma) and moderate hypoglycemia (an event requiring assistance of another, excluding severe episodes) was made over a 3-year period. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Patients and caregivers detailed episodes of significant hypoglycemia (moderate and severe events) and these were recorded at each 3-month clinic visit along with HbA1c. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Data were analyzed using generalized estimating equation models fitted with the exchange correlation structure. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
The overall incidence of severe events was 4.8/100 patient-years and of moderate events was 13.1/100 patient-years. 	 RESULTS
Over 3 years, severe events occurred in 8.5% of children and moderate events occurred in 26.9%. 	 RESULTS
Significant hypoglycemia was rare in the first 12 months after diagnosis. 	 RESULTS
Rates of hypoglycemia were increased in children < 6 years of age versus > 6 years of age (40.9 vs. 16.6/100 patient-years, age < or = 6 years vs. age > 6 years, P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Rates of hypoglycemia doubled when HbA1c fell below 8%, and children with HbA1c < 7% had a threefold increase in both moderate and severe hypoglycemia (e.g., severe episodes 14.9 vs. 4.1/100 patient-years, HbA1c < or = 7% vs. HbA1c > 7%, P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Most severe events were seizures, and 75% of them occurred at night. 	 RESULTS
The majority of events were related to missed meals or increased activity. 	 RESULTS
However, in 38% no predisposing factor was evident. 	 RESULTS
Newly diagnosed children appear to be protected from severe hypoglycemia. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Rates increase with lower glycated hemoglobin, especially when mean HbA1c is < 8.0%. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Younger children, who may be more susceptible to the adverse effects of neuroglycopenia, are at a particular risk of significant hypoglycemia. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The outcome of fully intermittent thrice-weekly antituberculosis treatment of various durations in HIV-associated tuberculosis is unclear. 	 RATIONALE
To compare the efficacy of an intermittent 6-month regimen (Reg6M: 2EHRZ(3)/4HR(3) [ethambutol, 1,200 mg; isoniazid, 600 mg; rifampicin, 450 or 600 mg depending on body weight <60 or > or =60 kg; and pyrazinamide, 1,500 mg for 2 mo; followed by 4 mo of isoniazid and rifampicin at the same doses]) versus a 9-month regimen (Reg9M: 2EHRZ(3)/7HR(3)) in HIV/tuberculosis (TB). 	 OBJECTIVES
HIV-infected patients with newly diagnosed pulmonary or extrapulmonary TB were randomly assigned to Reg6M (n = 167) or Reg9M (n = 160) and monitored by determination of clinical, immunological, and bacteriological parameters for 36 months. 	 METHODS
Primary outcomes included favorable responses at the end of treatment and recurrences during follow-up, whereas the secondary outcome was death. 	 METHODS
Intent-to-treat and on-treatment analyses were performed. 	 METHODS
All patients were antiretroviral treatment-naive during treatment. 	 METHODS
Of the patients, 70% had culture-positive pulmonary TB; the median viral load was 155,000 copies/ml and the CD4(+) cell count was 160 cells/mm(3). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
Favorable response to antituberculosis treatment was similar by intent to treat (Reg6M, 83% and Reg9M, 76%; P = not significant). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
Bacteriological recurrences occurred significantly more often in Reg6M than in Reg9M (15 vs. 7%; P < 0.05) although overall recurrences were not significantly different (Reg6M, 19% vs. Reg9M, 13%). 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
By 36 months, 36% of patients undergoing Reg6M and 35% undergoing Reg9M had died, with no significant difference between regimens. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
All 19 patients who failed treatment developed acquired rifamycin resistance (ARR), the main risk factor being baseline isoniazid resistance. 	 MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS
Among antiretroviral treatment-naive HIV-infected patients with TB, a 9-month regimen resulted in a similar outcome at the end of treatment but a significantly lower bacteriological recurrence rate compared with a 6-month thrice-weekly regimen. 	 CONCLUSIONS
was altered by lengthening TB treatment. 	 ARR
Clinical Trials Registry Information: ID# NCT00376012 registered at www.clinicaltrials.gov. 	 ARR
The association between the deficiency in mismatch repair (MMR) genes and prognosis in women with endometrial cancer is unclear. 	 BACKGROUND
Here we report a systematic review and meta-analysis exploring this association. 	 BACKGROUND
We searched literature databases (MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane) from 1980 until December 2011 to identify studies evaluating the association between MMR status and clinical outcome in endometrial cancer. 	 METHODS
The main outcome measures were overall survival (OS) and disease-free survival (DFS). 	 METHODS
Twenty-three studies met the inclusion criteria. 	 RESULTS
The median sample size of studies was 112, 74% were retrospective case-series and 70% performed microsatellite instability (MSI) analysis to evaluate the status of MMR. 	 RESULTS
Only 22% of studies used the panel of five microsatellite markers recommended by the National Cancer Institute. 	 RESULTS
Seven studies used immunohistochemistry to define MMR deficiency, but only two of them determined the expression of all four MMR proteins. 	 RESULTS
Overall, significant associations between MMR and outcome were observed in 32% of studies. 	 RESULTS
There was marked inter-study heterogeneity for estimates of OS and DFS. 	 RESULTS
Pooled analysis did not show any significant association between deficiency in MMR and worse OS (6 studies, hazard ratio [HR] 2.0, p=0.11) or DFS (4 studies, HR ratio 1.31, p=0.66). 	 RESULTS
There is no definitive evidence of a significant association between MMR status and detrimental survival in endometrial cancer. 	 CONCLUSION
To investigate the overall occurrence and relationship of genetic alterations in the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt pathway in thyroid tumors and explore the scope of this pathway as a therapeutic target for thyroid cancer. 	 PURPOSE
We examined collectively the major genetic alterations and their relationship in this pathway, including PIK3CA copy number gain and mutation, Ras mutation, and PTEN mutation, in a large series of primary thyroid tumors. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Occurrence of any of these genetic alterations was found in 25 of 81 (31%) benign thyroid adenoma (BTA), 47 of 86 (55%) follicular thyroid cancer (FTC), 21 of 86 (24%) papillary thyroid cancer (PTC), and 29 of 50 (58%) anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC), with FTC and ATC most frequently harboring these genetic alterations. 	 RESULTS
PIK3CA copy gain was associated with increased PIK3CA protein expression. 	 RESULTS
A mutual exclusivity among these genetic alterations was seen in BTA, FTC, and PTC, suggesting an independent role of each of them through the PI3K/Akt pathway in the tumorigenesis of the differentiated thyroid tumors. 	 RESULTS
