In 4, 12 and 24 weeks of treatment, HAMD score was lower significantly than that before the treatment in the three groups (all P<0.05), and the score in the comprehensive group at each time point after treatment was lower than the other two groups (all P<0.05). 	 RESULTS
In 4 and 12 weeks of treatment, there were not different significantly between the ziwuliuzhu group and the prozac group (both P>0.05). 	 RESULTS
In 24 weeks of treatment, HAMD score in the ziwuliuzhu group was lower than that in the prozac group (P<0.05). 	 RESULTS
For the adverse reaction, there were 2 cases in the comprehensive group, 6 cases in the prozac group and 0 case in the ziwzuliuzhu group. 	 RESULTS
The comprehensive therapy of acupuncture at the acupoints based on ziwuliuzhu and oral administration of prozac is superior to either the simple oral administration of prozac or the ziwuliuzhu acu-puncture in terms of clinical efficacy and the improvements in depressive state. 	 CONCLUSION
Regarding the clinical efficacy, the impact of simple ziwuliuzhu acupuncture is not different significantly as compared with the simple oral administration of prozac, but it is better than the simple oral administration of prozac in terms of the long-term HAMD score and safety. 	 CONCLUSION
The Diabetes Prevention Program (DPP) is a 27-center randomized clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of interventions that may delay or prevent development of diabetes in people at increased risk for type 2 diabetes. 	 OBJECTIVE
Eligibility requirements were age > or = 25 years, BMI > or = 24 kg/m2 (> or = 22 kg/m2 for Asian-Americans), and impaired glucose tolerance plus a fasting plasma glucose of 5.3-6.9 mmol/l (or < or = 6.9 mmol for American Indians). 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Randomization of participants into the DPP over 2.7 years ended in June 1999. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Baseline data for the three treatment groups--intensive lifestyle modification, standard care plus metformin, and standard care plus placebo--are presented for the 3,234 participants who have been randomized. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Of all participants 	 RESULTS
, 55% were Caucasian, 20% were African-American, 16% were Hispanic, 5% were American Indian, and 4% were Asian-American. 	 RESULTS
Their average age at entry was 51 +/- 	 RESULTS
10.7 years (mean +/- 	 RESULTS
SD), and 67.7% were women. 	 RESULTS
Moreover, 16% were < 40 years of age, and 20% were > or = 60 years of age. 	 RESULTS
Of the women, 48% were postmenopausal. 	 RESULTS
Men and women had similar frequencies of history of hypercholesterolemia (37 and 33%, respectively) or hypertension (29 and 26%, respectively). 	 RESULTS
On the basis of fasting lipid determinations, 54% of men and 40% of women fit National Cholesterol Education Program criteria for abnormal lipid profiles. 	 RESULTS
More men than women were current or former cigarette smokers or had a history of coronary heart disease. 	 RESULTS
Furthermore, 66% of men and 71% of women had a first-degree relative with diabetes. 	 RESULTS
Overall, BMI averaged 34.0 +/- 	 RESULTS
6.7 kg/m2 at baseline with 57% of the men and 73% of women having a BMI > or = 30 kg/m2. 	 RESULTS
Average fasting plasma glucose (6.0 +/- 	 RESULTS
0.5 mmol/l) and HbA1c (5.9 +/- 	 RESULTS
0.5%) in men were comparable with values in women (5.9 +/- 0.4 mmol/l and 5.9 +/- 	 RESULTS
0.5%, respectively). 	 RESULTS
The DPP has successfully randomized a large cohort of participants with a wide distribution of age, obesity, and ethnic and racial backgrounds who are at high risk for developing type 2 diabetes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The study will examine the effects of interventions on the development of diabetes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
& AIMS Helicobacter pylori is an important etiologic factor in the development of gastric cancer. 	 BACKGROUND
The aim of this study was to analyze the role of H. pylori infections in the induction of mutagenic events in gastric epithelial cells. 	 BACKGROUND
The effect of a high-salt diet as a genotoxic risk factor was also investigated. 	 BACKGROUND
Big Blue transgenic male mice (C57Bl/6) were inoculated with H. pylori (strain SS1) or Helicobacter felis (strain CS1) for 6 and 12 months. 	 METHODS
The frequency and spectrum of mutations at the stomach level were assessed. 	 METHODS
Inflammatory host response and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) expression by reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction and immunohistochemistry analysis were also performed. 	 METHODS
After 6 months, the gastric mutant frequency was 4-fold and 1.7-fold higher in mice infected with H. pylori and H. felis, respectively, than in uninfected mice. 	 RESULTS
It was associated with a high frequency of transversions (AT --> CG and GC --> TA) known to result from oxidative damages. 	 RESULTS
The Helicobacter-infected mice exhibited severe gastritis and a high level of iNOS messenger RNA expression. 	 RESULTS
Hyperplasia developed 12 months after inoculation, and both the mutagenic effects and iNOS expression decreased in H. pylori- and H. felis-infected mice. 	 RESULTS
No synergistic effects of a high-salt diet and Helicobacter infection were observed regarding the frequency of gastric mutation. 	 RESULTS
A direct gastric mutagenic effect due to H. pylori infection in the Big Blue transgenic mouse model has been shown 6 months after inoculation. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This genotoxicity can be attributable to oxidative DNA damage involving the inflammatory host response. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The absolute risk of fractures in renal transplant patients is 3 times that of matched controls. 	 BACKGROUND
Most of the symptomatic fractures are peripheral, suggesting a greater compromise of cortical bone. 	 BACKGROUND
Peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT) is a new imaging technique that allows separate noninvasive evaluations of cortical and trabecular bones. 	 BACKGROUND
We investigated cortical bone by pQCT in 12 renal transplant patients (seven men and five women) for comparison with 27 normal controls. 	 BACKGROUND
pQCT (XCT 960, Stratec, Pforheim, Germany) was performed upon the distal radius of the nondominant forearm (15% the length of the ulna, proximal from the radius end plate). 	 METHODS
We evaluated total and cortical bone mineral density (TBMD, cBMD), total (cross-sectional) and cortical area (TA, cA), cortical thickness (cThk), endosteal and periosteal circumferences, and the buckling ratio (r/cThK). 	 METHODS
Compared with normal controls transplant patients as a whole showed a significant increase in TA, in endosteal circumference (P < .001), and in the buckling ratio (P < .001) with a significant reduction in cThK (P < .001). 	 RESULTS
Female patients had a marked decrease in cA (51.4 vs 69.3 [pixel n]; P < .0001) and cThK (2.08 vs 2.78 mm; P < .0001). 	 RESULTS
Male patients also had a decrease in cThK (2.54 vs 3.30 mm; P = .0001) and an increase in endosteal perimeter (31.2 vs 26.4 mm; P < .0001). 	 RESULTS
Total time on dialysis prior to renal graft correlated negatively with cortical thickness (r = .62; P < .01). 	 RESULTS
Our results suggest that a marked thinning of cortical bone may explain the increased incidence of peripheral fractures among renal transplant patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The combination of ataxia and hypogonadism was first described more than a century ago, but its genetic basis has remained elusive. 	 BACKGROUND
We performed whole-exome sequencing in a patient with ataxia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, followed by targeted sequencing of candidate genes in similarly affected patients. 	 METHODS
Neurologic and reproductive endocrine phenotypes were characterized in detail. 	 METHODS
The effects of sequence variants and the presence of an epistatic interaction were tested in a zebrafish model. 	 METHODS
Digenic homozygous mutations in RNF216 and OTUD4, which encode a ubiquitin E3 ligase and a deubiquitinase, respectively, were found in three affected siblings in a consanguineous family. 	 RESULTS
Additional screening identified compound heterozygous truncating mutations in RNF216 in an unrelated patient and single heterozygous deleterious mutations in four other patients. 	 RESULTS
Knockdown of rnf216 or otud4 in zebrafish embryos induced defects in the eye, optic tectum, and cerebellum; combinatorial suppression of both genes exacerbated these phenotypes, which were rescued by nonmutant, but not mutant, human RNF216 or OTUD4 messenger RNA. 	 RESULTS
All patients had progressive ataxia and dementia. 	 RESULTS
Neuronal loss was observed in cerebellar pathways and the hippocampus; surviving hippocampal neurons contained ubiquitin-immunoreactive intranuclear inclusions. 	 RESULTS
Defects were detected at the hypothalamic and pituitary levels of the reproductive endocrine axis. 	 RESULTS
The syndrome of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, ataxia, and dementia can be caused by inactivating mutations in RNF216 or by the combination of mutations in RNF216 and OTUD4. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These findings link disordered ubiquitination to neurodegeneration and reproductive dysfunction and highlight the power of whole-exome sequencing in combination with functional studies to unveil genetic interactions that cause disease. 	 CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by the National Institutes of Health and others.). 	 CONCLUSIONS
Aspirin is widely used for relief of pain and for cardioprotective effects. 	 CONTEXT
Its use is of concern to ophthalmologists when ocular surgery is being considered and also in the presence of age-related macular degeneration (AMD). 	 CONTEXT
To examine the association of regular aspirin use with incidence of AMD. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS The Beaver Dam Eye Study, a longitudinal population-based study of age-related eye diseases conducted in Wisconsin. 	 OBJECTIVE
Examinations were performed every 5 years over a 20-year period (1988-1990 through 2008-2010). 	 OBJECTIVE
Study participants (N = 4926) were aged 43 to 86 years at the baseline examination. 	 OBJECTIVE
At subsequent examinations, participants were asked if they had regularly used aspirin at least twice a week for more than 3 months. 	 OBJECTIVE
Incidence of early AMD, late AMD, and 2 subtypes of late AMD (neovascular AMD and pure geographic atrophy), assessed in retinal photographs according to the Wisconsin Age-Related Maculopathy Grading System. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
The mean duration of follow-up was 14.8 years. 	 RESULTS
There were 512 incident cases of early AMD (of 6243 person-visits at risk) and 117 incident cases of late AMD (of 8621 person-visits at risk) over the course of the study. 	 RESULTS
Regular aspirin use 10 years prior to retinal examination was associated with late AMD (hazard ratio [HR], 1.63 [95% CI, 1.01-2.63]; P = .05), with estimated incidence of 1.76% (95% CI, 1.17%-2.64%) in regular users and 1.03% (95% CI, 0.70%-1.51%) in nonusers. 	 RESULTS
For subtypes of late AMD, regular aspirin use 10 years prior to retinal examination was significantly associated with neovascular AMD (HR, 2.20 [95% CI, 1.20-4.15]; P = .01) but not pure geographic atrophy (HR, 0.66 [95% CI, 0.25-1.95]; P = .45). 	 RESULTS
Aspirin use 5 years (HR, 0.86 [95% CI, 0.71-1.05]; P = .13) or 10 years (HR, 0.86 [95% CI, 0.65-1.13]; P = .28) prior to retinal examination was not associated with incident early AMD. 	 RESULTS
Among an adult cohort, aspirin use 5 years prior to observed incidence was not associated with incident early or late AMD. 	 CONCLUSIONS
However, regular aspirin use 10 years prior was associated with a small but statistically significant increase in the risk of incident late and neovascular AMD. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To describe a naturally occurring X-linked recessive mutation, no b-wave (nob), that compromises visual transmission between photoreceptors and second-order neurons in mice. 	 PURPOSE
Affected mice were identified by recording the light-evoked response of the retina, the electroretinogram (ERG). 	 METHODS
To evaluate visual transmission, cortical potentials were recorded with a scalp electrode. 	 METHODS
The inheritance pattern for nob was defined by breeding nob animals with normal mice. 	 METHODS
Retinal histologic analysis was performed by light microscopy. 	 METHODS
Although the photoreceptor-mediated ERG component (a-wave) was normal in nob mice, the major response component reflecting postreceptoral neuronal activity (b-wave) was missing. 	 RESULTS
Visually-driven cortical activity was also abnormal in nob animals. 	 RESULTS
At the light microscopic level, the nob retina appeared to have a normal cytoarchitecture. 	 RESULTS
These findings suggest that the nob defect interferes with the transmission of visual information through the retina and that these mice are a useful model for the study of outer retinal synaptic function. 	 CONCLUSIONS
In addition, this mutant mouse seems to provide an animal model for the complete form of congenital stationary night blindness, a human disorder in which patients have a profound loss of rod-mediated visual sensitivity. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Interleukin (IL)-17F, produced in IL-23R-expressing Th17 cells, is a novel member of the IL-17 cytokine family. 	 BACKGROUND
Given the association of IL23R with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), we characterized the role of IL-17F in IBD including its intestinal gene expression and the effect of the IL17F p. 	 BACKGROUND
His161Arg polymorphism on disease susceptibility and phenotype of Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC). 	 BACKGROUND
In addition, we analyzed the IL17F p. 	 BACKGROUND
His161Arg polymorphism for potential epistasis with IL23R and NOD2/CARD15 variants. 	 BACKGROUND
Intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was measured by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 	 METHODS
Genomic DNA from 1682 individuals (CD: n = 499; UC: n = 216; controls: n = 967) was analyzed for the presence of the IL17F p. 	 METHODS
His161Arg polymorphism, the 3 NOD2 variants, p. 	 METHODS
Arg702Trp, p. 	 METHODS
Gly908Arg, and p. 	 METHODS
Leu1007fsX1008, and 10 CD-associated IL23R variants. 	 METHODS
Intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was 4.4-fold increased in inflamed colonic lesions compared to uninflamed biopsies in CD (P = 0.016) but not in UC. 	 RESULTS
However, the mean intestinal IL-17F mRNA expression was higher in UC than in CD (P < 0.0001). 	 RESULTS
The IL17F p. 	 RESULTS
His161Arg substitution was observed with similar frequencies in IBD patients and controls and was not associated with a certain disease phenotype, but weakly associated with a low body mass index (BMI; P = 0.009) and an earlier age of disease onset (P = 0.039) in UC. 	 RESULTS
There was no evidence for epistasis between the IL17F p. 	 RESULTS
His161Arg polymorphism and IBD-associated single nucleotide polymorphisms within the IL23R gene. 	 RESULTS
Intestinal IL17F gene expression is increased in active CD. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The IL17F p. 	 CONCLUSIONS
His161Arg polymorphism is not associated with IBD susceptibility and has no epistatic interaction with CD-associated IL23R variants. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The value of HER-2/neu status as a predictor of response to anthracycline-based chemotherapy is still a matter of debate. 	 OBJECTIVES
We evaluated the contribution of HER-2/neu gene amplification and other biologic markers in predicting response to different doses of neoadjuvant anthracycline-based chemotherapy. 	 OBJECTIVES
Clinical and pathologic records of 115 primary breast cancer patients were reviewed. 	 METHODS
Forty-eight and 67 patients received high (doxorubicin > or =20 mg/m2/wk; epirubicin > or =30 mg/m2/wk) and moderate-low anthracycline dose intensity regimens, respectively. 	 METHODS
Pathologic diagnosis, hormonal receptor status (HR), Ki67, and HER-2/neu status were assessed on tumor samples before neoadjuvant chemotherapy. 	 METHODS
HER-2/neu was determined by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). 	 METHODS
HER-2/neu amplification was observed in 29/115 (25%) tumors, 18 from moderate-low-dose and 11 from high-dose group. 	 RESULTS
In the univariate analysis, a high Ki67 index (> or =20%) and positive clinical axillary nodes were predictive of an objective tumor response (P = 0.033 and 0.001, respectively). 	 RESULTS
In the multivariate analysis, Ki67 was the only factor predictive of response (OR = 3.08, 95% CI = 1.1-8.5, P = 0.03). 	 RESULTS
HER-2/neu status was not a factor in predicting objective response to different anthracycline dose intensities. 	 RESULTS
The same finding was observed with regards to HR and Ki67. 	 RESULTS
In our series, no significant dose-response relationship was found according to HER-2/neu status. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The use of bisphosphonates for the prevention of skeletal related events in women with bone metastases from breast cancer is well established. 	 BACKGROUND
We undertook an evaluation of bisphosphonate use in clinical practice in three Canadian cancer centres. 	 BACKGROUND
In addition we assessed whether or not physicians at these centres are following their local treatment guidelines and funding policies. 	 BACKGROUND
Charts and electronic files of patients who had received either clodronate or pamidronate at any time between January 2000 and December 2001 at three Canadian cancer centres were retrospectively reviewed. 	 METHODS
There has been a marked improvement in the time between the diagnosis of bone metastases and the commencement of bisphosphonates from a median of 155 days in 1998 to 24 days in 2001. 	 RESULTS
However, despite a local funding policy requiring that oral clodronate be the first bisphosphonate used, this was the case in only 67% of patients. 	 RESULTS
In addition, despite one centre's guidelines recommending that bisphosphonates be stopped once the patient was progressing, 90% of their patients remained on bisphosphonates until they died. 	 RESULTS
A considerable amount of effort is spent on the creation of "evidence based" treatment guidelines. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Funding agencies develop policies based on these treatment guidelines, but often funding is more restrictive than the treatment guideline would suggest. 	 CONCLUSIONS
It is clear from this review that physicians still appear to manage a substantial proportion of patients outside of funding policies, but within evidence based recommendations. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Therefore, a need exists for either the creation of guidelines and policies that physicians will follow or the implementation of methods to ensure that restrictive policies are actually followed. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To determine whether an increased resting energy expenditure (REE) and weight loss in lung cancer patients are related to a systemic inflammatory response. 	 PURPOSE
was measured by indirect calorimetry using a ventilated hood system. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS REE
Soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor 55 (sTNF-R55) and sTNF-R75, soluble intercellular adhesion molecule (sICAM)-1, soluble E (sE)-selectin, lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-binding protein (LBP), interleukin (IL)-6, and TNF-alpha were measured using sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), and C-reactive protein (CRP) was measured by turbidimetry. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS REE
A cross-sectional study was performed to compare inflammatory mediators between hypermetabolic (REE/Harris Benedict [HB] equation > or = 110%) versus normometabolic (REE/HB < 110%) patients and between patients who lost weight (more than 10% loss of preillness weight) versus those whose weight remained stable. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS REE
Eighty-seven patients with primary non-small-cell lung cancer were consecutively entered onto the study. 	 RESULTS
Mean REE expressed as a percentage of the HB reference values was 118% +/- 	 RESULTS
12%; 67 patients were considered hypermetabolic. 	 RESULTS
Twenty-six patients had a substantial loss of more than 10% of their preillness weight. 	 RESULTS
Hypermetabolic patients were found to have significantly increased levels of sTNF-R55, sE-selectin, LBP, and CRP compared with normometabolic patients. 	 RESULTS
Weight loss was related with increased levels of the sTNF-Rs, sICAM-1, IL-6, LBP, and CRP. 	 RESULTS
Hypermetabolism and weight loss are related to the presence of a systemic inflammatory response as reflected by enhanced levels of inflammatory mediators and acute phase proteins in patients with primary non-small-cell lung cancer. 	 CONCLUSION
To demonstrate the relation of exercise capacity and BMI to mortality in a population of male veterans with type 2 diabetes. 	 OBJECTIVE
After excluding two underweight patients (BMI <18.5 kg/m2), the study population comprised 831 consecutive patients with type 2 diabetes (mean age 61 +/- 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
9 years) referred for exercise testing for clinical reasons between 1995 and 2006. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Exercise capacity was determined from a maximal exercise test and measured in metabolic equivalents (METs). 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Patients were classified both according to BMI category (18.5-24.9, 25.0-29.9, and > or =30 kg/m2) and by exercise capacity (<5.0 or > or =5.0 maximal METs). 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
The association among exercise capacity, BMI, other clinical variables, and all-cause mortality was assessed by Cox proportional hazards. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
Study participants were followed for mortality up to 30 June 2006. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS
During a mean follow-up of 4.8 +/- 	 RESULTS
3.0 years, 112 patients died, for an average annual mortality rate of 2.2%. 	 RESULTS
Each 1-MET increase in exercise capacity conferred a 10% survival benefit (hazard ratio 0.90 [95% CI 0.82-0.98]; P = 0.01), but BMI was not significantly associated with mortality. 	 RESULTS
After adjustment for age, ethnicity, examination year, BMI, presence of cardiovascular disease (CVD), and CVD risk factors, diabetic patients achieving <5 maximal METs were 70% more likely to die (1.70 [1.13-2.54]) than those achieving > or =5 maximal METs. 	 RESULTS
There was a strong inverse association between exercise capacity and mortality in this cohort of men with documented diabetes, and this relationship was independent of BMI. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To determine the frequency of neurobehavioral signs and symptoms reported in every published case of traumatic encephalopathy with a view toward the development of clinical diagnostic criteria with predictive validity. 	 OBJECTIVES
Cases of persistent or progressive neurological or neurobehavioral change following exposure to one or more head injuries have been reported since 1928. 	 INTRODUCTION
This condition is often referred to as traumatic encephalopathy (TE). 	 INTRODUCTION
To date, however, no diagnostic criteria have been advanced or accepted for the clinical diagnosis of TE. 	 INTRODUCTION
Provisional research diagnostic criteria are required not only for meaningful diagnosis but also to facilitate research to determine the epidemiology, etiology, course, prognosis, imaging and biomarkers, neuropathological features and potentially effective treatments of TE. 	 INTRODUCTION
All 436 published cases of TE in all languages were reviewed. 	 METHODS
All symptoms and signs reported in these cases were classified and enumerated. 	 METHODS
Ninety-seven cases met inclusion criteria based on sufficient documentation of the history and neurobehavioral examination. 	 RESULTS
Provisional research diagnostic criteria for clinically probable and clinically possible TE were developed based on the most frequently reported clinical features. 	 RESULTS
The provisional diagnostic criteria for TE presented here are the first published criteria for this condition based upon a systematic analysis of its clinical characteristics. 	 CONCLUSION
This is the first a step toward scientifically derived consensus criteria, which are essential to accelerate progress in the investigation of this important condition. 	 CONCLUSION
To investigate hypoxia measured by pimonidazole binding, glucose transporter 1 (GLUT1) and carbonic anhydrase IX (CA-IX) expression, proliferation, and vascularity in liver metastases of colorectal cancer and to compare GLUT1 and CA-IX expression in corresponding primary tumors. 	 PURPOSE
Twenty-five patients with liver metastases of colorectal cancer, planned for metastasectomy, were included. 	 METHODS AND MATERIALS
The hypoxia marker pimonidazole and proliferation marker iododeoxyuridine were administered before surgery. 	 METHODS AND MATERIALS
After immunofluorescent staining of the frozen metastases, pimonidazole binding, vascularity, and proliferation were analyzed quantitatively. 	 METHODS AND MATERIALS
Thirteen paraffin-embedded primary tumors were stained immunohistochemically for GLUT1 and CA-IX expression, which was analyzed semiquantitatively in primary tumors and corresponding liver metastases. 	 METHODS AND MATERIALS
In liver metastases, pimonidazole binding showed a pattern consistent with diffusion-limited hypoxia. 	 RESULTS
The mean pimonidazole-positive fraction was 0.146; the mean distance from vessels to pimonidazole-positive areas was 80 microm. 	 RESULTS
When expressed, often co-localization was observed between pimonidazole binding and GLUT1 or CA-IX expression, but microregional areas of mismatch were also observed. 	 RESULTS
No correlation between the level of pimonidazole binding and GLUT1 or CA-IX expression was observed. 	 RESULTS
In some patients, a large fraction (up to 30%) of proliferating cells was present in pimonidazole-stained areas. 	 RESULTS
Expression of CA-IX in primary tumors and metastases showed a significant correlation, which was absent for GLUT1 expression. 	 RESULTS
Compared with other tumor types, liver metastases of colorectal cancer contain large amounts of hypoxic cells. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The lack of correlation with pimonidazole binding brings into question the value of GLUT1 and CA-IX as endogenous markers of hypoxia. 	 CONCLUSIONS
In patients with unstable coronary artery disease, there is a relation between the short-term risk of death and blood levels of troponin T (a marker of myocardial damage) and C-reactive protein and fibrinogen (markers of inflammation). 	 BACKGROUND
Using information obtained during an extension of the follow-up period in the Fragmin during Instability in Coronary Artery Disease trial, we evaluated the usefulness of troponin T, C-reactive protein, and fibrinogen levels and other indicators of risk as predictors of the long-term risk of death from cardiac causes. 	 BACKGROUND
Levels of C-reactive protein and fibrinogen at enrollment and the maximal level of troponin T during the first 24 hours after enrollment were analyzed in 917 patients included in a clinical trial of low-molecular-weight heparin in unstable coronary artery disease. 	 METHODS
The patients were followed for a mean of 37.0 months (range, 1.6 to 50.6). 	 METHODS
During follow-up, 1.2 percent of the 173 patients with maximal blood troponin T levels of less than 0.06 microg per liter died of cardiac causes, as compared with 8.7 percent of the 367 patients with levels of 0.06 to 0.59 microg per liter and 15.4 percent of the 377 patients with levels of at least 0.60 microg per liter (P=0.007 and P=0.001, respectively). 	 RESULTS
The rates of death from cardiac causes were 5.7 percent among the 314 patients with blood C-reactive protein levels of less than 2 mg per liter, 7.8 percent among the 294 with levels of 2 to 10 mg per liter, and 16.5 percent among the 309 with levels of more than 10 mg per liter (P=0.29 and P=0.001, respectively). 	 RESULTS
The rates of death from cardiac causes were 5.4 percent among the 314 patients with blood fibrinogen levels of less than 3.4 g per liter, 12.0 percent among the 300 with levels of 3.4 to 3.9 g per liter, and 12.9 percent among the 303 with levels of at least 4.0 g per liter (P=0.004 and P=0.69, respectively). 	 RESULTS
In a multivariate analysis, levels of troponin T and C-reactive protein were independent predictors of the risk of death from cardiac causes. 	 RESULTS
In unstable coronary artery disease, elevated levels of troponin T and C-reactive protein are strongly related to the long-term risk of death from cardiac causes. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These markers are independent risk factors, and their effects are additive with respect to each other and other clinical indicators of risk. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To conduct an economic analysis of the Hlabisa community-based directly observed therapy management strategy for tuberculosis and to project costs of three alternative strategies. 	 OBJECTIVE
Hlabisa health district, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. 	 SETTING
An economic analysis comparing the current tuberculosis management strategy in Hlabisa with three alternative strategies (the Hlabisa strategy prior to 1991 based on hospitalisation, the national strategy and sanatorium care) in terms of costs to both health service and patient and of cost-effectiveness. 	 METHODS
The current Hlabisa strategy was the most cost-effective (R3799 per patient cured), compared with R98307 for the strategy used prior to 1991, R9940 for the national strategy, and R11145 for sanatorium care. 	 RESULTS
Between 71% and 88% of treatment costs lie with the health service, and hospitalisation (R119 per day) is the most expensive item. 	 RESULTS
Prolonged hospitalisation is extremely expensive, but community care is cheaper (community clinic visit, R28; community health worker visit, R7). 	 RESULTS
The total cost of supervising a patient in the community under the current Hlabisa strategy was R503, equivalent to 4.2 days in hospital. 	 RESULTS
Drug costs (R157) are equivalent to just 1.3 days in hospital. 	 RESULTS
Cost to both health service and patient can be substantially reduced by using community-based directly observed therapy for tuberculosis, a strategy that is cheap and cost-effective in Hlabisa. 	 CONCLUSION
These findings have important national implications, supporting the goals of the new tuberculosis control programme. 	 CONCLUSION
The proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-18 (IL-18) putatively modulates food intake and energy metabolism, but the effects of IL-18 in high-fat diet fed animals are unknown. 	 OBJECTIVE
Whether IL-18 alters basal metabolic rate or metabolic processes of living is unknown. 	 OBJECTIVE
Here, we tested the hypothesis that IL-18 modulates weight gain, energy intake, whole-body energy expenditure, and utilization of lipid as a fuel substrate in high-fat diet fed mice. 	 OBJECTIVE
Food intake, whole-body metabolism, and motor activity of IL-18 knockout mice were compared to those of wildtype littermates; anorectic effects of intracerebroventricular IL-18 administration were compared between IL-18 receptor knockout, IL-18/IL-18R knockout and wildtype mice. 	 METHODS
Chow-reared IL-18 knockout mice were overweight at 6 months of age and then gained excess weight on both low-fat and high-fat diets, ate more high-fat diet, and showed reduced whole-body energy expenditure and increased respiratory exchange ratios. 	 RESULTS
Reductions in energy expenditure of IL-18 knockout mice were seen across fasting vs. feeding conditions, low- vs. high-fat diets, high vs. low levels of physical activity and times of day, suggesting actions on basal metabolic rate. 	 RESULTS
The circadian amplitude of energy expenditure, but not respiratory exchange ratio, food intake, or motor activity, also was blunted in IL-18 knockout mice. 	 RESULTS
Central IL-18 administration reduced high-fat diet intake in wildtype mice, but not in mice lacking the IL-18 receptor. 	 RESULTS
The loss-of-function results support the hypothesis that endogenous IL-18 suppresses appetite and promote energy expenditure and lipid fuel substrate utilization not only during sickness, but also in healthy adults consuming high-fat diets. 	 CONCLUSION
To describe the epidemiology of urban malaria, an emerging problem in sub-Saharan Africa. 	 OBJECTIVE
Cross-sectional surveys of communities in Accra and Kumasi, Ghana, determining risk factors for malaria infection and anaemia in children aged 6-60 months. 	 METHOD
Malaria prevalence rates ranged from 2% to 33% between urban communities. 	 RESULTS
47.1% of children were anaemic (Hb<11.0 g/dl). 	 RESULTS
Factors associated with malaria prevalence were low socio-economic status, age and anaemia. 	 RESULTS
The attributable risks of anaemia and severe anaemia (Hb<8.0 g/dl) caused by malaria were 5% and 23% respectively. 	 RESULTS
Malaria in urban areas displayed a heterogeneity and complexity that differed from the rural environment, which has important implications for malaria control. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Marked intra-city variation indicates the importance of targeting specific areas or districts. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The most vulnerable group, the urban poor, should be prioritized when designing control measures. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This would require careful assessment of the malaria risk pattern in any city to guide an integrated control program. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Delayed cerebral vasospasm causes permanent neurological deficits or death in at least 15% of patients following otherwise successful treatment for ruptured intracranial aneurysm. 	 CONTEXT
Decreased bioavailability of nitric oxide has been associated with the development of cerebral vasospasm. 	 CONTEXT
To determine whether infusions of nitrite will prevent delayed cerebral vasospasm. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND SUBJECTS A total of 14 anesthetized cynomolgus monkeys had an autologous blood clot placed around the right middle cerebral artery. 	 OBJECTIVE
Cerebral arteriography was performed before clot placement and on days 7 and 14 to assess vasospasm. 	 OBJECTIVE
The study was conducted from August 2003 to February 2004. 	 OBJECTIVE
A 90-mg sodium nitrite intravenous solution infused over 24 hours plus a 45-mg sodium nitrite bolus daily (n = 3); a 180-mg sodium nitrite intravenous solution infused over 24 hours (n = 3); or a control saline solution infusion (n = 8). 	 INTERVENTIONS
Each was infused continuously for 14 days. 	 INTERVENTIONS
Nitrite, S-nitrosothiol, and methemoglobin levels in blood and cerebrospinal fluid and degree of arteriographic vasospasm. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
In control monkeys, mean (SD) cerebrospinal fluid nitrite levels decreased from 3.1 (1.5) micromol/L to 0.4 (0.1) micromol/L at day 7 and to 0.4 (0.4) micromol/L at day 14 (P = .03). 	 RESULTS
All 8 control monkeys developed significant vasospasm of the right middle cerebral artery, which was complicated by stroke and death in 1 animal. 	 RESULTS
Sodium nitrite infusions increased the nitrite and methemoglobin levels (<2.1% of total hemoglobin) in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid without evoking systemic hypotension. 	 RESULTS
Nitrite infusion prevented development of vasospasm (no animals developed significant vasospasm; mean [SD] reduction in right middle cerebral artery area on day 7 after subarachnoid hemorrhage of 8% [9%] in nitrite-treated monkeys vs 47% [5%] in saline-treated controls; P<.001). 	 RESULTS
There was a negative correlation between the concentration of nitrite in cerebrospinal fluid and the degree of cerebral vasospasm (P<.001). 	 RESULTS
Pharmacological effects of nitrite infusion were also associated with the formation of S-nitrosothiol in cerebrospinal fluid. 	 RESULTS
There was no clinical or pathological evidence of nitrite toxicity. 	 RESULTS
Subacute sodium nitrite infusions prevented delayed cerebral vasospasm in a primate model of subarachnoid hemorrhage. 	 CONCLUSION
To assess the association between severity of neuropathy and disease stage, and estimate the rate of neuropathy progression in a retrospective cross-sectional analysis of a multinational population of patients with familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP). 	 OBJECTIVES
We characterize neuropathy severity and rate of progression in available patients with FAP in France, the United States, Portugal, and Italy. 	 METHODS
Neuropathy Impairment Scores (NIS), time from symptom onset to NIS measurement, polyneuropathy disability (PND) scores, FAP disease stage, and manual grip strength data were collected. 	 METHODS
We estimated neuropathy progression using Loess Fit and Gompertz Fit models. 	 METHODS
For the 283 patients studied (mean age, 56.4 years), intercountry genotypic variation in the transthyretin (TTR) mutation was observed, with the majority of patients in Portugal (92%) having early-onset Val30Met-FAP. 	 RESULTS
There was also marked intercountry variation in PND score, FAP stage, and TTR stabilizer use. 	 RESULTS
14 and 99 for stages 1 and 3, respectively; p < 0.0001). 	 NIS
In addition, there was an association between NIS and TTR genotype. 	 NIS
The estimated rate of NIS progression for a population with a median NIS of 32 was 14.3 points/year; the corresponding estimated rate for the modified NIS+7 is 17.8 points/year. 	 NIS
In a multinational population of patients with FAP, rapid neuropathic progression is observed and the severity of neuropathy is associated with functional scales of locomotion. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Despite improvements in mental health services in recent decades, it is unclear whether the risk of mortality in schizophrenia has changed over time. 	 CONTEXT
To explore the distribution of standardized mortality ratios (SMRs) for people with schizophrenia. 	 OBJECTIVE
Broad search terms were used in MEDLINE, PsychINFO, Web of Science, and Google Scholar to identify all studies that investigated mortality in schizophrenia, published between January 1, 1980, and January 31, 2006. 	 DATA SOURCES
References were also identified from review articles, reference lists, and communication with authors. 	 DATA SOURCES
Population-based studies that reported primary data on deaths in people with schizophrenia. 	 STUDY SELECTION
Operationalized criteria were used to extract key study features and mortality data. 	 DATA EXTRACTION
We examined the distribution of SMRs and pooled selected estimates using random-effects meta-analysis. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
We identified 37 articles drawn from 25 different nations. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
The median SMR for all persons for all-cause mortality was 2.58 (10%-90% quantile, 1.18-5.76), with a corresponding random-effects pooled SMR of 2.50 (95% confidence interval, 2.18-2.43). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
No sex difference was detected. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
Suicide was associated with the highest SMR (12.86); however, most of the major causes-of-death categories were found to be elevated in people with schizophrenia. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
The SMRs for all-cause mortality have increased during recent decades (P = .03). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
With respect to mortality, a substantial gap exists between the health of people with schizophrenia and the general community. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This differential mortality gap has worsened in recent decades. 	 CONCLUSIONS
In light of the potential for second-generation antipsychotic medications to further adversely influence mortality rates in the decades to come, optimizing the general health of people with schizophrenia warrants urgent attention. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Limited information exists regarding the role of left ventricular function in predicting exercise capacity and impact on age- and sex-related differences. 	 CONTEXT
To determine the impact of measures of cardiac function assessed by echocardiography on exercise capacity and to determine if these associations are modified by sex or advancing age. 	 OBJECTIVES
Cross-sectional study of patients undergoing exercise echocardiography with routine measurements of left ventricular systolic and diastolic function by 2-dimensional and Doppler techniques. 	 DESIGN
Analyses were conducted to determine the strongest correlates of exercise capacity and the age and sex interactions of these variables with exercise capacity. 	 DESIGN
Large tertiary referral center in Rochester, Minnesota, in 2006. 	 SETTING
Patients undergoing exercise echocardiography using the Bruce protocol (N = 2867). 	 PARTICIPANTS
Patients with echocardiographic evidence of exercise-induced ischemia, ejection fractions lower than 50%, or significant valvular heart disease were excluded. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Exercise capacity in metabolic equivalents (METs). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
Diastolic dysfunction was strongly and inversely associated with exercise capacity. 	 RESULTS
Compared with normal function, after multivariate adjustment, those with moderate/severe resting diastolic dysfunction (-1.30 METs; 95% confidence interval [CI], -1.52 to -0.99; P < .001) and mild resting diastolic dysfunction (-0.70 METs; 95% CI, -0.88 to -0.46; P < .001) had substantially lower exercise capacity. 	 RESULTS
Variation of left ventricular systolic function within the normal range was not associated with exercise capacity. 	 RESULTS
Left ventricular filling pressures measured by resting E/e' of 15 or greater (-0.41 METs; 95% CI, -0.70 to -0.11; P = .007) or postexercise E/e' of 15 or greater (-0.41 METs; 95% CI, -0.71 to -0.11; P = .007) were similarly associated with a reduction in exercise capacity, each in separate multivariate analyses. 	 RESULTS
Individuals with impaired relaxation (mild dysfunction) or resting E/e' of 15 or greater had a progressive increase in the magnitude of reduction in exercise capacity with advancing age (P < .001 and P = .02, respectively). 	 RESULTS
Other independent correlates of exercise capacity were age (unstandardized beta coefficient, -0.85 METs; 95% CI, -0.92 to -0.77, per 10-year increment; P < .001), female sex (-1.98 METs; 95% CI, -2.15 to -1.84; P < .001), and body mass index greater than 30 (-1.24 METs; 95% CI, -1.41 to -1.10; P < .001). 	 RESULTS
In this large cross-sectional study of those referred for exercise echocardiography and not limited by ischemia, abnormalities of left ventricular diastolic function were independently associated with exercise capacity. 	 CONCLUSION
The GOLD guidelines advocate not to institute inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) in patients with mild-to-moderate COPD. 	 INTRODUCTION
However, many patients do use ICS and in some patients, withdrawal is associated with deteriorating lung function and increased exacerbation rates. 	 INTRODUCTION
Unfortunately, physicians do not know in which patients they can stop ICS treatment safely. 	 INTRODUCTION
To identify predictors of COPD exacerbations after ICS withdrawal. 	 AIM
During ICS treatment, post-bronchodilator spirometry, body plethysmography, and health status assessment were performed in 68 COPD patients using ICS. 	 METHODS
Additionally, sputum cell differentials, supernatant leukotriene B(4), eosinophilic cationic protein, and myeloperoxidase, serum C-reactive protein and soluble intracellular adhesion molecule, and urinary desmosine were assessed. 	 METHODS
Sputum was also analysed for mRNA levels of haemoxygenase-1, tumour necrosis factor-α, RANTES, interleukin 5(IL-5), IL-10, IL-12, IL-13, transforming growth factor-β, and interferon-γ. 	 METHODS
Cox regression analyses were performed using time to exacerbation as outcome variable to identify significant hazards for a COPD exacerbation after ICS withdrawal. 	 STATISTICS
Higher sputum % eosinophils, higher sputum MPO/neutrophil level, longer duration of COPD symptoms, <40 packyears smoking, and ICS withdrawal in November, December or January were significant hazards (all p<0.05) for experiencing a COPD exacerbation after ICS withdrawal in a monovariate model. 	 RESULTS
In a multivariate model, all factors proved independent predictors except for sputum MPO/neutrophil level. 	 RESULTS
Decisions on whether or not inhaled corticosteroids can be safely withdrawn in mild-to-moderate COPD can be facilitated by assessment of sputum inflammation, particularly eosinophil numbers, next to packyears smoking, season, and duration of COPD symptoms. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR) regulate lipid and glucose metabolism but their anticancer properties have been recently studied as well. 	 PURPOSE
We previously reported the antimetastatic activity of the PPARalpha ligand, fenofibrate, against melanoma tumors in vivo. 	 PURPOSE
Here we investigated possible molecular mechanisms of fenofibrate anti metastatic action. 	 PURPOSE
Monolayer cultures of mouse (B16F10) and human (SkMell88) melanoma cell lines, soft agar assay, and cell migration assay were used in this study. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
In addition, we analyzed PPARalpha expression and its transcriptional activity in response to fenotibrate by using Western blots and liciferase-based reporter system. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Fenofibrate inhibited migration of B16F10 and SkMel188 cells in Transwell chambers and colony formation in soft agar. 	 RESULTS
These effects were reversed by PPAR inhibitor, GW9662. 	 RESULTS
Western blot analysis revealed time-dependent down-regulation of Akt and extracellular signal-regulated kinase l/2 phosphorylation in fenofibrate-treated cells. 	 RESULTS
A B16F10 cell line stably expressing constitutively active Akt mutant was resistant to fenofibrate. 	 RESULTS
In contrast, Akt gene silencing with siRNA mimicked the fenofibrate action and reduced the migratory ability of B16F1O cells. 	 RESULTS
In addition, fenofibrate strongly sensitized BI6FIO cells to the proapoptotic drug staurosporine, further supporting the possibility that fenofibrate-induced down-regulation of Akt function contributes to fenofibrate-mediated inhibition of metastatic potential in this experimental model. 	 RESULTS
Our results show that the PPAR-dependent antimetastatic activity of fenofibrate involves down-regulation of Akt phosphorylation and suggest that supplementation with this drug may improve the effectiveness of melanoma chemotherapy. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Mutations in the leucine rich, glioma inactivated gene (LGI1) were recently described in a small number of families with autosomal dominant lateral temporal epilepsy (ADLTE). 	 PURPOSE
is characterized by partial seizures with symptoms suggestive of a lateral temporal onset, including frequent auditory aura. 	 ADLTE
Here we report the results of clinical and genetic analyses of two newly identified families with ADTLE. 	 ADLTE
We identified two families whose seizure semiology was suggestive of ADLTE. 	 METHODS
Evaluation included a detailed history and neurologic examination, as well as collection of DNA. 	 METHODS
The coding sequence of the LGI1 gene from affected subjects from both families was analyzed for evidence of mutation. 	 METHODS
Each patient had a history of partial seizures, often with secondary generalization earlier in the course. 	 RESULTS
Auditory aura was reported by approximately two thirds of affected patients in each pedigree. 	 RESULTS
Novel mutations in LGI1 were detected in both families. 	 RESULTS
A heterozygous single-nucleotide deletion at position 329 (del 329C) was detected in affected individuals from one family, whereas patients from the second family had a nonsynonymous variation, corresponding to C435G. 	 RESULTS
We identified two novel mutations in the LGI1 gene. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The phenotype of these two families was similar to that of other kindreds with ADLTE, as auditory aura was absent in one third of affected individuals. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Our results further support that LGI1 mutations should be considered in patients with a history of partial seizures if the semiology of seizures is consistent with the onset in the lateral temporal lobe. 	 CONCLUSIONS
More than 80% of deaths from cardiovascular disease are estimated to occur in low-income and middle-income countries, but the reasons are unknown. 	 BACKGROUND
We enrolled 156,424 persons from 628 urban and rural communities in 17 countries (3 high-income, 10 middle-income, and 4 low-income countries) and assessed their cardiovascular risk using the INTERHEART Risk Score, a validated score for quantifying risk-factor burden without the use of laboratory testing (with higher scores indicating greater risk-factor burden). 	 METHODS
Participants were followed for incident cardiovascular disease and death for a mean of 4.1 years. 	 METHODS
The mean 	 RESULTS
Risk Score was highest in high-income countries, intermediate in middle-income countries, and lowest in low-income countries (P<0.001). 	 INTERHEART
However, the rates of major cardiovascular events (death from cardiovascular causes, myocardial infarction, stroke, or heart failure) were lower in high-income countries than in middle- and low-income countries (3.99 events per 1000 person-years vs. 5.38 and 6.43 events per 1000 person-years, respectively; P<0.001). 	 INTERHEART
Case fatality rates were also lowest in high-income countries (6.5%, 15.9%, and 17.3% in high-, middle-, and low-income countries, respectively; P=0.01). 	 INTERHEART
Urban communities had a higher risk-factor burden than rural communities but lower rates of cardiovascular events (4.83 vs. 6.25 events per 1000 person-years, P<0.001) and case fatality rates (13.52% vs. 17.25%, P<0.001). 	 INTERHEART
The use of preventive medications and revascularization procedures was significantly more common in high-income countries than in middle- or low-income countries (P<0.001). 	 INTERHEART
Although the risk-factor burden was lowest in low-income countries, the rates of major cardiovascular disease and death were substantially higher in low-income countries than in high-income countries. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The high burden of risk factors in high-income countries may have been mitigated by better control of risk factors and more frequent use of proven pharmacologic therapies and revascularization. 	 CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by the Population Health Research Institute and others.). 	 CONCLUSIONS
T cell immunoglobulin and mucin domain (Tim) proteins are expressed by numerous immune cells, recognize phosphatidylserine on apoptotic cells, and function as costimulators or coinhibitors. 	 OBJECTIVE
Tim-1 is expressed by activated T cells but is also found on dendritic cells and B cells. 	 OBJECTIVE
Tim-4, present on macrophages and dendritic cells, plays a critical role in apoptotic cell clearance, regulates the number of phosphatidylserine-expressing activated T cells, and is genetically associated with low low-density lipoprotein and triglyceride levels. 	 OBJECTIVE
Because these functions of Tim-1 and Tim-4 could affect atherosclerosis, their modulation has potential therapeutic value in cardiovascular disease. 	 OBJECTIVE
ldlr(-/-) mice were fed a high-fat diet for 4 weeks while being treated with control (rat immunoglobulin G1) or anti-Tim-1 (3D10) or -Tim-4 (21H12) monoclonal antibodies that block phosphatidylserine recognition and phagocytosis. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Both anti-Tim-1 and anti-Tim-4 treatments enhanced atherosclerosis by 45% compared with controls by impairment of efferocytosis and increasing aortic CD4(+)T cells. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Consistently, anti-Tim-4-treated mice showed increased percentages of activated T cells and late apoptotic cells in the circulation. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Moreover, in vitro blockade of Tim-4 inhibited efferocytosis of oxidized low-density lipoprotein-induced apoptotic macrophages. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Although anti-Tim-4 treatment increased T helper cell (Th)1 and Th2 responses, anti-Tim-1 induced Th2 responses but dramatically reduced the percentage of regulatory T cells. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Finally, combined blockade of Tim-1 and Tim-4 increased atherosclerotic lesion size by 59%. 	 APPROACH AND RESULTS
Blockade of Tim-4 aggravates atherosclerosis likely by prevention of phagocytosis of phosphatidylserine-expressing apoptotic cells and activated T cells by Tim-4-expressing cells, whereas Tim-1-associated effects on atherosclerosis are related to changes in Th1/Th2 balance and reduced circulating regulatory T cells. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To determine the relative accuracy of clinic measurements and home blood pressure monitoring compared with ambulatory blood pressure monitoring as a reference standard for the diagnosis of hypertension. 	 OBJECTIVE
Systematic review with meta-analysis with hierarchical summary receiver operating characteristic models. 	 DESIGN
Methodological quality was appraised, including evidence of validation of blood pressure measurement equipment. 	 DESIGN
Medline (from 1966), Embase (from 1980), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, DARE, Medion, ARIF, and TRIP up to May 2010. 	 DATA SOURCES
Eligibility criteria for selecting studies Eligible studies examined diagnosis of hypertension in adults of all ages using home and/or clinic blood pressure measurement compared with those made using ambulatory monitoring that clearly defined thresholds to diagnose hypertension. 	 DATA SOURCES
The 20 eligible studies used various thresholds for the diagnosis of hypertension, and only seven studies (clinic) and three studies (home) could be directly compared with ambulatory monitoring. 	 RESULTS
Compared with ambulatory monitoring thresholds of 135/85 mm Hg, clinic measurements over 140/90 mm Hg had mean sensitivity and specificity of 74.6% (95% confidence interval 60.7% to 84.8%) and 74.6% (47.9% to 90.4%), respectively, whereas home measurements over 135/85 mm Hg had mean sensitivity and specificity of 85.7% (78.0% to 91.0%) and 62.4% (48.0% to 75.0%). 	 RESULTS
Neither clinic nor home measurement had sufficient sensitivity or specificity to be recommended as a single diagnostic test. 	 CONCLUSIONS
If ambulatory monitoring is taken as the reference standard, then treatment decisions based on clinic or home blood pressure alone might result in substantial overdiagnosis. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Ambulatory monitoring before the start of lifelong drug treatment might lead to more appropriate targeting of treatment, particularly around the diagnostic threshold. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Corin has been suggested to be associated with hypertension by cell- and animal-based studies. 	 BACKGROUND
However, the association still lacks population-based evidence which critically promotes translation from basic research to clinical and preventive practice. 	 BACKGROUND
Here, we aimed to explore the association in a general population of China. 	 BACKGROUND
From January to May 2010, we conducted a cross-sectional study in 2,498 participants aged above 30 years, residing in Gusu district of Suzhou. 	 METHODS
Serum soluble corin and blood pressure were measured. 	 METHODS
Hypertensive participants had a higher level of serum corin than nonhypertensive participants (median (interquartile range): 1,836.83 (1,497.85-2,327.87) pg/ml vs. 1,579.14 (1,322.18-1,956.82) pg/ml, P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Higher serum corin was positively associated with prevalent hypertension (odds ratio (OR) = 2.01, P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
In the multiple analysis, participants in the third (OR = 1.43, P = 0.007) and fourth (OR = 1.96, P < 0.001) quartiles had significantly increased odds of hypertension compared to those in the lowest quartile of serum corin. 	 RESULTS
ORs of hypertension positively and significantly increased with serum corin levels (P for trend <0.001). 	 RESULTS
Further subgroup analysis showed that ORs of hypertension associated with high corin (over the median level of serum corin: 1,689.20 pg/ml) were still significant in subgroups by age, body mass index, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and fasting plasma glucose (all P < 0.05). 	 RESULTS
Our study showed that hypertensive participants had an increased serum corin level compared to those without hypertension. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This ﬁnding suggests that corin may play a role in the pathology of hypertension. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Two inflammatory disorders, type 1 diabetes and celiac disease, cosegregate in populations, suggesting a common genetic origin. 	 BACKGROUND
Since both diseases are associated with the HLA class II genes on chromosome 6p21, we tested whether non-HLA loci are shared. 	 BACKGROUND
We evaluated the association between type 1 diabetes and eight loci related to the risk of celiac disease by genotyping and statistical analyses of DNA samples from 8064 patients with type 1 diabetes, 9339 control subjects, and 2828 families providing 3064 parent-child trios (consisting of an affected child and both biologic parents). 	 METHODS
We also investigated 18 loci associated with type 1 diabetes in 2560 patients with celiac disease and 9339 control subjects. 	 METHODS
Three celiac disease loci--RGS1 on chromosome 1q31, IL18RAP on chromosome 2q12, and TAGAP on chromosome 6q25--were associated with type 1 diabetes (P<1.00x10(-4)). 	 RESULTS
The 32-bp insertion-deletion variant on chromosome 3p21 was newly identified as a type 1 diabetes locus (P=1.81x10(-8)) and was also associated with celiac disease, along with PTPN2 on chromosome 18p11 and CTLA4 on chromosome 2q33, bringing the total number of loci with evidence of a shared association to seven, including SH2B3 on chromosome 12q24. 	 RESULTS
The effects of the IL18RAP and TAGAP alleles confer protection in type 1 diabetes and susceptibility in celiac disease. 	 RESULTS
Loci with distinct effects in the two diseases included INS on chromosome 11p15, IL2RA on chromosome 10p15, and PTPN22 on chromosome 1p13 in type 1 diabetes and IL12A on 3q25 and LPP on 3q28 in celiac disease. 	 RESULTS
A genetic susceptibility to both type 1 diabetes and celiac disease shares common alleles. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These data suggest that common biologic mechanisms, such as autoimmunity-related tissue damage and intolerance to dietary antigens, may be etiologic features of both diseases. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Fatal adverse events (FAEs) have been reported in cancer patients treated with the widely used angiogenesis inhibitor bevacizumab in combination with chemotherapy. 	 CONTEXT
Currently, the role of bevacizumab in treatment-related mortality is not clear. 	 CONTEXT
To perform a systematic review and meta-analysis of published randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to determine the overall risk of FAEs associated with bevacizumab. 	 OBJECTIVE
PubMed, EMBASE, and Web of Science databases as well as abstracts presented at American Society of Clinical Oncology conferences from January 1966 to October 2010 were searched to identify relevant studies. 	 DATA SOURCES
Eligible studies included prospective RCTs in which bevacizumab in combination with chemotherapy or biological therapy was compared with chemotherapy or biological therapy alone. 	 STUDY SELECTION AND DATA EXTRACTION
Summary incidence rates, relative risks (RRs), and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated using fixed- or random-effects models. 	 STUDY SELECTION AND DATA EXTRACTION
A total of 10,217 patients with a variety of advanced solid tumors from 16 RCTs were included in the analysis. 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
The overall incidence of FAEs with bevacizumab was 2.5% (95% CI, 1.7%-3.9%). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
Compared with chemotherapy alone, the addition of bevacizumab was associated with an increased risk of FAEs, with an RR of 1.46 (95% CI, 1.09-1.94; P = .01; incidence, 2.5% vs 1.7%). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
This association varied significantly with chemotherapeutic agents (P = .045) but not with tumor types (P = .13) or bevacizumab doses (P = .16). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
Bevacizumab was associated with an increased risk of FAEs in patients receiving taxanes or platinum agents (RR, 3.49; 95% CI, 1.82-6.66; incidence, 3.3% vs 1.0%) but was not associated with increased risk of FAEs when used in conjunction with other agents (RR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.25-2.88; incidence, 0.8% vs 0.9%). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
The most common causes of FAEs were hemorrhage (23.5%), neutropenia (12.2%), and gastrointestinal tract perforation (7.1%). 	 DATA SYNTHESIS
In a meta-analysis of RCTs, bevacizumab in combination with chemotherapy or biological therapy, compared with chemotherapy alone, was associated with increased treatment-related mortality. 	 CONCLUSION
To determine rates of suicide associated with pregnancy by the type of pregnancy. 	 OBJECTIVE
Register linkage study. 	 DESIGN
Information on suicides in women of reproductive age was linked with the Finnish birth, abortion, and hospital discharge registers to find out how many women who committed suicide had had a completed pregnancy during her last year of life. 	 DESIGN
Nationwide data from Finland. 	 SETTING
Women who committed suicide in 1987-94. 	 SUBJECTS
There were 73 suicides associated with pregnancy, representing 5.4% of all suicides in women in this age group. 	 RESULTS
The mean annual suicide rate was 11.3 per 100,000. 	 RESULTS
The suicide rate associated with birth was significantly lower (5.9) and the rates associated with miscarriage (18.1) and induced abortion (34.7) were significantly higher than in the population. 	 RESULTS
The risk associated with birth was higher among teenagers and that associated with abortion was increased in all age groups. 	 RESULTS
Women who had committed a suicide tended to come from lower social classes and were more likely to be unmarried than other women who had had a completed pregnancy. 	 RESULTS
The increased risk of suicide after an induced abortion indicates either common risk factors for both or harmful effects of induced abortion on mental health. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Lactic acidosis is a well recognized complication of biguanide therapy which is potentially serious. 	 AIMS
Although the prevalence of metformin-associated lactic acidosis (MALA) is much lower than that associated with phenformin, it is still being reported sporadically which raises concerns for the practising clinicians. 	 AIMS
We review the currently available world-wide data of the prevalence of MALA, the risk factors for its development and the current practical guidelines on the use of metformin to minimize the risk of this potential hazard. 	 AIMS
An extensive literature search was conducted from both Medline and Ovid (1965-98) using the following keywords: 'Type 2 diabetes mellitus', 'oral hypoglycaemic drugs', 'biguanides', 'metformin-associated lactic acidosis' and 'renal impairment'. 	 METHODS
was found to be a very rare clinical entity, being 20 times less common than phenformin-associated lactic acidosis. 	 RESULTS MALA
Amongst all the risk factors, renal impairment appears to be the major precipitating factor for the development of MALA in metformin-treated patients. 	 RESULTS MALA
We also found cases of MALA where no precipitating factors were identified and the underlying mechanism in these cases remains unclear. 	 RESULTS MALA
Practical recommendations of metformin use to minimize the risk of MALA have been listed based on previous reports. 	 RESULTS MALA
The low prevalence of MALA is comparable to the prevalence of sulphonylurea-induced hypoglycaemia. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Metformin has many beneficial metabolic effects in the management of Type 2 diabetes mellitus. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Provided that the recommended guidelines for metformin use are strictly adhered to, its widespread use would be safe and the incidence of MALA will be further reduced. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To establish the mental health needs of homeless children and families before and after rehousing. 	 OBJECTIVE
Cross sectional, longitudinal study. 	 DESIGN
City of Birmingham. 	 SETTING
58 rehoused families with 103 children aged 2-16 years and 21 comparison families of low socioeconomic status in stable housing, with 54 children. 	 SUBJECTS
Children's mental health problems and level of communication; mothers' mental health problems and social support one year after rehousing. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Mental health problems remained significantly higher in rehoused mothers and their children than in the comparison group (mothers 26% v 5%, P = 0.04; children 39% v 11%, P = 0.0003). 	 RESULTS
Homeless mothers continued to have significantly less social support at follow up. 	 RESULTS
Mothers with a history of abuse and poor social integration were more likely to have children with persistent mental health problems. 	 RESULTS
Homeless families have a high level of complex needs that cannot be met by conventional health services and arrangements. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Local strategies for rapid rehousing into permanent accommodation, effective social support and health care for parents and children, and protection from violence and intimidation should be developed and implemented. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Circulating tumor cells (CTCs) and [(18)F]fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) are two new promising tools for therapeutic monitoring. 	 PURPOSE
In this study, we compared the prognostic value of CTC and FDG-PET/CT monitoring during systemic therapy for metastatic breast cancer (MBC). 	 PURPOSE
A retrospective analyses of 115 MBC patients who started a new line of therapy and who had CTC counts and FDG-PET/CT scans performed at baseline and at 9 to 12 weeks during therapy (midtherapy) was performed. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Patients were categorized according to midtherapy CTC counts as favorable (ie, < five CTCs/7.5 mL blood) or unfavorable (> or = five CTCs/7.5 mL blood) outcomes. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
counts and FDG-PET/CT response at midtherapy were compared, and univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify factors associated with survival. 	 CTC
In 102 evaluable patients, the median overall survival time was 14 months (range, 1 to > 41 months). 	 RESULTS
Midtherapy CTC levels correlated with FDG-PET/CT response in 68 (67%) of 102 evaluable patients. 	 RESULTS
In univariate analysis, midtherapy CTC counts and FDG-PET/CT response predicted overall survival (P < .001 and P = .001, respectively). 	 RESULTS
FDG-PET/CT predicted overall survival (P = .0086) in 31 (91%) of 34 discordant patients who had fewer than five CTCs at midtherapy. 	 RESULTS
Only midtherapy CTC levels remained significant in a multivariate analysis (P = .004). 	 RESULTS
Detection of five or more CTCs during therapeutic monitoring can accurately predict prognosis in MBC beyond metabolic response. 	 CONCLUSION
FDG-PET/CT deserves a role in patients who have fewer than five CTCs at midtherapy. 	 CONCLUSION
Prospective trials should evaluate the most sensitive and cost-effective modality for therapeutic monitoring in MBC. 	 CONCLUSION
The quality of histopathology slides of endoscopic biopsies from different laboratories varies, but the effect of biopsy quality on outcome is unknown. 	 BACKGROUND
The ability to demonstrate a histologic lesion in the stomach or duodenum of a dog or cat is affected by the quality of endoscopic biopsy samples submitted. 	 HYPOTHESIS
More endoscopic samples are needed to find a lesion in poor-quality tissue specimens. 	 HYPOTHESIS
Tissues from 99 dogs and 51 cats were examined as clinical cases at 8 veterinary institutions or practices in 5 countries. 	 ANIMALS
Histopathology slides from sequential cases that underwent endoscopic biopsy were submitted by participating institutions. 	 METHODS
Quality of the histologic section of tissue (inadequate, marginal, adequate), type of lesion (lymphangiectasia, crypt lesion, villus blunting, cellular infiltrate), and severity of lesion (normal, mild, moderate, severe) were determined. 	 METHODS
Sensitivity of different quality tissue samples for finding different lesions was determined. 	 METHODS
Fewer samples were required from dogs for diagnosis as the quality of the sample improved from inadequate to marginal to adequate. 	 RESULTS
Duodenal lesions in cats displayed the same trend except for moderate duodenal infiltrates for which quality of tissue sample made no difference. 	 RESULTS
Gastric lesions in dogs and mild gastric lesions in cats had the same trend, whereas the number of tissue samples needed to diagnose moderately severe gastric lesions in cats was not affected by the quality of tissue sample. 	 RESULTS
The quality of endoscopically obtained tissue samples has a profound effect on their sensitivity for identifying certain lesions, and there are differences between biopsies of canine and feline tissues. 	 CONCLUSIONS AND CLINICAL IMPORTANCE
Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are known to reduce proteinuria. 	 BACKGROUND
Their combination might be more effective than either treatment alone, but long-term data for comparative changes in renal function are not available. 	 BACKGROUND
We investigated the renal effects of ramipril (an ACE inhibitor), telmisartan (an ARB), and their combination in patients aged 55 years or older with established atherosclerotic vascular disease or with diabetes with end-organ damage. 	 BACKGROUND
The trial ran from 2001 to 2007. 	 METHODS
After a 3-week run-in period, 25 620 participants were randomly assigned to ramipril 10 mg a day (n=8576), telmisartan 80 mg a day (n=8542), or to a combination of both drugs (n=8502; median follow-up was 56 months), and renal function and proteinuria were measured. 	 METHODS
The primary renal outcome was a composite of dialysis, doubling of serum creatinine, and death. 	 METHODS
Analysis was by intention to treat. 	 METHODS
This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00153101. 	 METHODS
784 patients permanently discontinued randomised therapy during the trial because of hypotensive symptoms (406 on combination therapy, 149 on ramipril, and 229 on telmisartan). 	 FINDINGS
The number of events for the composite primary outcome was similar for telmisartan (n=1147 [13.4%]) and ramipril (1150 [13.5%]; hazard ratio [HR] 1.00, 95% CI 0.92-1.09), but was increased with combination therapy (1233 [14.5%]; HR 1.09, 1.01-1.18, p=0.037). 	 FINDINGS
The secondary renal outcome, dialysis or doubling of serum creatinine, was similar with telmisartan (189 [2.21%]) and ramipril (174 [2.03%]; HR 1.09, 0.89-1.34) and more frequent with combination therapy (212 [2.49%]: HR 1.24, 1.01-1.51, p=0.038). 	 FINDINGS
Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) declined least with ramipril compared with telmisartan (-2.82 [SD 17.2] mL/min/1.73 m(2)vs -4.12 [17.4], p<0.0001) or combination therapy (-6.11 [17.9], p<0.0001). 	 FINDINGS
The increase in urinary albumin excretion was less with telmisartan (p=0.004) or with combination therapy (p=0.001) than with ramipril. 	 FINDINGS
In people at high vascular risk, telmisartan's effects on major renal outcomes are similar to ramipril. 	 INTERPRETATION
Although combination therapy reduces proteinuria to a greater extent than monotherapy, overall it worsens major renal outcomes. 	 INTERPRETATION
Prolonged hypothermia, as occurs during solid organ transplantation, negatively influences transplantation outcome. 	 BACKGROUND
Proteolysis is one of the deleterious events implicated in preservation injury of organ allografts. 	 BACKGROUND
This strongly affects graft quality and hence immediate organ function. 	 BACKGROUND
Since donor catecholamine treatment improves transplantation outcome after renal transplantation, the present study was conducted to examine the influence of dopamine (DA) pretreatment on hypothermia induced proteolysis in endothelial cells subjected to prolonged cold storage. 	 BACKGROUND
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) assay, two-dimensional electrophoresis, ubiquitination analysis, intracellular calcium measurement, and Western blot analysis were performed on human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) subjected to hypothermic preservation or not. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
were highly susceptible to cold storage, which was reflected by morphological changes, loss of viability, and by significant changes in cellular proteome. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
DA pretreatment prevented cell death during cold storage. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
Western blot analysis demonstrated a time dependent up-regulation of calpain 1 and 2 during cold storage, which could be prevented by addition of EDTA. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
DA pretreatment abolished autoproteolysis of calpain 1. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
Analysis of ubiquitination revealed a significant increase in ubiquitinated conjugates after cold storage. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
This was not prevented by DA pretreatment. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
Neither proteasome nor calpain inhibitors prevented cell death during cold storage. 	 RESULTS HUVEC
In endothelial cells subjected to cold preservation, activation of the calpain pathway and the ubiquitin proteasome system occur. 	 CONCLUSION
Although DA pretreatment inhibits the former, calpain inhibition did not protect endothelial cells during cold storage. 	 CONCLUSION
DA pretreatment might influence proteolysis, but proteolysis is not the major cause of endothelial cell death. 	 CONCLUSION
Increased expression of the tetraspanin TSPAN7 has been observed in a number of cancers; however, it is unclear how TSPAN7 plays a role in cancer progression. 	 BACKGROUND
We investigated the expression of TSPAN7 in the haematological malignancy multiple myleoma (MM) and assessed the consequences of TSPAN7 expression in the adhesion, migration and growth of MM plasma cells (PC) in vitro and in bone marrow (BM) homing and tumour growth in vivo. 	 METHODS
Finally, we characterised the association of TSPAN7 with cell surface partner molecules in vitro. 	 METHODS
TSPAN7 was found to be highly expressed at the RNA and protein level in CD138(+) MM PC from approximately 50% of MM patients. 	 RESULTS
TSPAN7 overexpression in the murine myeloma cell line 5TGM1 significantly reduced tumour burden in 5TGM1/KaLwRij mice 4 weeks after intravenous adminstration of 5TGM1 cells. 	 RESULTS
While TSPAN7 overexpression did not affect cell proliferation in vitro, TSPAN7 increased 5TGM1 cell adhesion to BM stromal cells and transendothelial migration. 	 RESULTS
In addition, TSPAN7 was found to associate with the molecular chaperone calnexin on the cell surface. 	 RESULTS
These results suggest that elevated TSPAN7 may be associated with better outcomes for up to 50% of MM patients. 	 CONCLUSION
Dual eligibles, persons who qualify for both Medicare and Medicaid coverage, often receive poorer quality care relative to other Medicare beneficiaries. 	 BACKGROUND
To determine whether dual eligibles are discharged to lower quality post-acute skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) compared with Medicare-only beneficiaries. 	 OBJECTIVES
Following the random utility maximization model, we specified a discharge function using a conditional logit model and tested how this discharge rule varied by dual-eligibility status. 	 RESEARCH DESIGN
A total of 692,875 Medicare fee-for-service patients (22% duals) who were discharged for Medicare paid SNF care between July 2004 and June 2005. 	 SUBJECTS
Medicare enrollment and the Medicaid Analytic Extract files were used to determine dual eligibility. 	 MEASURES
The proportion of Medicaid patients and nursing staff characteristics provided measures of SNF quality. 	 MEASURES
Duals are more likely to be discharged to SNFs with a higher share of Medicaid patients and fewer nurses. 	 RESULTS
These results are robust to estimation with an alternative subsample of patients based on primary diagnoses, propensity of being dual eligible, and likelihood of remaining in the nursing home. 	 RESULTS
Disparities exist in access to quality SNF care for duals. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Strategies to improve discharge planning processes are required to redirect patients to higher quality providers, regardless of Medicaid eligibility. 	 CONCLUSIONS
OF REVIEW The 2009 pandemic HIN1 influenza strain (H1N12009) produced more severe disease and increased risk for mortality. 	 PURPOSE
As an at-risk population for more severe influenza illness, particular concern regarding HIV patients triggered a focused effort to evaluate disease burden and vaccine efficacy in these populations. 	 PURPOSE
As with other immune-compromised individuals, most HIV-infected individuals recovered without major consequence. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Although HIV infection was assumed to be a risk factor for more severe disease and death, the published literature does not indicate this to be so. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Neuraminadase inhibitors were well tolerated by this population and there was no evidence of clinically significant pharmacokinetic interactions with antiretroviral therapy. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Immunogenicity was increased with H1N12009 vaccine compared to the historical results of nonpandemic vaccines and optimized by the use of adjuvants. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Booster dosing was also of benefit. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
H1N12009 vaccine was generally well tolerated without evidence of detrimental effect on HIV status. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
The worse case scenario was not realized for H1N12009 in the general population or in those with HIV. 	 SUMMARY
Immunization with adjuvant represents a key measure to protect this population from H1N12009 and other future novel influenza strains. 	 SUMMARY
Therapies to target prostate cancer bone metastases have only limited effects. 	 PURPOSE
New treatments are focused on the interaction between cancer cells, bone marrow cells and the bone matrix. 	 PURPOSE
Osteoclasts play an important role in the development of bone tumors caused by prostate cancer. 	 PURPOSE
Since Src kinase has been shown to be necessary for osteoclast function, we hypothesized that dasatinib, a Src family kinase inhibitor, would reduce osteoclast activity and prostate cancer (PC-3) cell-induced osteoclast formation. 	 PURPOSE
Dasatinib inhibited RANKL-induced osteoclast differentiation of bone marrow-derived monocytes with an EC(50) of 7.5 nM. PC-3 cells, a human prostate cancer cell line, were able to differentiate RAW 264.7 cells, a murine monocytic cell line, into osteoclasts, and dasatinib inhibited this differentiation. 	 RESULTS
In addition, conditioned medium from PC-3 cell cultures was able to differentiate RAW 264.7 cells into osteoclasts and this too, was inhibited by dasatinib. 	 RESULTS
Even the lowest concentration of dasatinib, 1.25 nmol, inhibited osteoclast differentiation by 29%. 	 RESULTS
Moreover, dasatinib inhibited osteoclast activity by 58% as measured by collagen 1 release. 	 RESULTS
We performed in vitro experiments utilizing the Src family kinase inhibitor dasatinib to target osteoclast activation as a means of inhibiting prostate cancer bone metastases. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Dasatinib inhibits osteoclast differentiation of mouse primary bone marrow-derived monocytes and PC-3 cell-induced osteoclast differentiation. 	 CONCLUSION
Dasatinib also inhibits osteoclast degradation activity. 	 CONCLUSION
Inhibiting osteoclast differentiation and activity may be an effective targeted therapy in patients with prostate cancer bone metastases. 	 CONCLUSION
Melanocortin receptor 4 (MC4R) deficiency is characterized by increased linear growth greater than expected for the degree of obesity. 	 CONTEXT
The objective of the investigation was to study the somatotroph axis in obese MC4R-deficient patients and equally obese controls. 	 OBJECTIVE
We obtained anthropometric measurements and insulin concentrations in 153 MC4R-deficient subjects and 1392 controls matched for age and severity of obesity. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
We measured fasting IGF-I, IGF-II, IGF binding protein (IGFBP)-1, IGFBP-3, and acid-labile subunit levels in a subset of 33 MC4R-deficient patients and 36 control subjects. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
We examined pulsatile GH secretion in six adult MC4R-deficient subjects and six obese controls. 	 PATIENTS AND METHODS
Height sd score was significantly greater in MC4R-deficient children under 5 yr of age compared with controls (mean ± SEM: 2.3 ± 0.06 vs. 1.8 ± 0.04, P < 0.001), an effect that persisted throughout childhood. 	 RESULTS
Final height (cm) was greater in MC4R-deficient men (mean ± SEM 173 ± 2.5 vs. 168 ± 2.1, P < 0.001) and women (mean 165 ± 2.1 vs. 158 ± 1.9, P < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Fasting IGF-I, IGF-II, acid-labile subunit, and IGFBP-3 concentrations were similar in the two groups. 	 RESULTS
