Twelve-month mortality rates were compared in patients taking antipsychotics and those taking other psychiatric medications. 	 METHOD
The authors controlled for confounding by using multivariate models and propensity-scoring methods. 	 METHOD
Secondary analyses included a no-medication group and examination of mortality causes. 	 METHOD
All groups taking antipsychotics had significantly higher mortality rates (22.6%-29.1%) than patients taking nonantipsychotic medications (14.6%). 	 RESULTS
Adjusted mortality risks for atypicals and for combined atypical and conventional antipsychotics were similar to those for conventional antipsychotics. 	 RESULTS
The mortality risk was significantly lower for nonantipsychotic medications than conventional antipsychotics. 	 RESULTS
Except for anticonvulsants, the adjusted risks for all individual classes of nonantipsychotics were significantly lower than the risk for antipsychotics. 	 RESULTS
Mortality risks did not change over 12 months. 	 RESULTS
The proportions of patients taking antipsychotics who died from cerebrovascular, cardiovascular, or infectious causes were not higher than rates for those taking nonantipsychotic psychiatric medications. 	 RESULTS
Antipsychotic medications taken by patients with dementia were associated with higher mortality rates than were most other medications used for neuropsychiatric symptoms. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The association between mortality and antipsychotics is not well understood and may be due to a direct medication effect or the pathophysiology underlying neuropsychiatric symptoms that prompt antipsychotic use. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The purpose of this project was to educate inpatients with psychotic disorders, many of whom were taking second-generation antipsychotics, about lifestyle changes they can make to combat weight gain. 	 OBJECTIVE
All inpatients on a Veterans Affairs acute inpatient schizophrenia treatment unit were invited to a 30-minute, didactic presentation given by a medical student and a psychology student under the supervision of the primary investigator. 	 METHOD
The topics covered included the health benefits of maintaining an ideal body weight by selecting foods according to the USDA Food Pyramid, determining adequate food portions, choosing healthy meals outside the home, and beginning and adhering to an exercise program. 	 METHOD
Subjects completed a 13-item quiz concerning their knowledge of food and nutrition before and after the presentation to determine its efficacy in teaching patients the material. 	 METHOD
Fifty patients completed both the pre- and post-presentation tests. 	 RESULTS
The mean percentage of correct answers on the pre-test was 85.6%, which rose to 89.3% on the post-test. 	 RESULTS
This difference of 3.7% was statistically significant (t = 2.43, df = 49, p < 0.02), and the mean percent of improvement was 6.1%. 	 RESULTS
This study demonstrates that psychotic individuals are able to benefit from educational presentations about nutrition and a healthy lifestyle. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A statistically significant improvement in test scores suggests that subjects gained an understanding of basic concepts related to food choices and fitness. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Gene expression profiling may be useful in examining differences underlying age- and sex-specific outcomes in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). 	 CONTEXT
To describe clinically relevant differences in the underlying biology of NSCLC based on patient age and sex. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Retrospective analysis of 787 patients with predominantly early stage NSCLC performed at Duke University, Durham, North Carolina, from July 2008 to June 2009. 	 OBJECTIVE
Lung tumor samples with corresponding microarray and clinical data were used. 	 OBJECTIVE
All patients were divided into subgroups based on age (< 70 vs > or = 70 years old) or sex. 	 OBJECTIVE
Gene expression signatures representing oncogenic pathway activation and tumor biology/microenvironment status were applied to these samples to obtain patterns of activation/deregulation. 	 OBJECTIVE
Patterns of oncogenic and molecular signaling pathway activation that are reproducible and correlate with 5-year recurrence-free patient survival. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Low- and high-risk patient clusters/cohorts were identified with the longest and shortest 5-year recurrence-free survival, respectively, within the age and sex NSCLC subgroups. 	 RESULTS
These cohorts of NSCLC demonstrate similar patterns of pathway activation. 	 RESULTS
In patients younger than 70 years, high-risk patients, with the shortest recurrence-free survival, demonstrated increased activation of the Src (25% vs 6%; P<.001) and tumor necrosis factor (76% vs 42%; P<.001) pathways compared with low-risk patients. 	 RESULTS
High-risk patients aged 70 years or older demonstrated increased activation of the wound healing (40% vs 24%; P = .02) and invasiveness (64% vs 20%; P<.001) pathways compared with low-risk patients. 	 RESULTS
In women, high-risk patients demonstrated increased activation of the invasiveness (99% vs 2%; P<.001) and STAT3 (72% vs 35%; P<.001) pathways while high-risk men demonstrated increased activation of the STAT3 (87% vs 18%; P<.001), tumor necrosis factor (90% vs 46%; P<.001), EGFR (13% vs 2%; P = .003), and wound healing (50% vs 22%; P<.001) pathways. 	 RESULTS
Multivariate analyses confirmed the independent clinical relevance of the pathway-based subphenotypes in women (hazard ratio [HR], 2.02; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.34-3.03; P<.001) and patients younger than 70 years (HR, 1.83; 95% CI, 1.24-2.71; P = .003). 	 RESULTS
All observations were reproducible in split sample analyses. 	 RESULTS
Among a cohort of patients with NSCLC, subgroups defined by oncogenic pathway activation profiles were associated with recurrence-free survival. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These findings require validation in independent patient data sets. 	 CONCLUSIONS
& AIMS The therapeutic application of regulatory T cells (Tregs) for the treatment of inflammatory diseases is limited by the scarcity of antigen-specific Tregs. 	 BACKGROUND
A preferred approach to endow effector T cells (Teff) with a desired specificity uses chimeric immune receptors with antibody-type specificity. 	 BACKGROUND
Accordingly, employing such chimeric immune receptors to redirect Tregs to sites of inflammation may be a useful therapeutic approach to alleviate a broad scope of diseases in which an uncontrolled inflammatory response plays a major role. 	 BACKGROUND
To enable application of the approach in clinical setting, which requires the genetic modification of the patient's own Tregs, we describe here a novel protocol that allows the efficient retroviral transduction and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol-specific expansion of murine naturally occurring regulatory T cells (nTregs), with a 2,4,6-trinitrophenol-specific tripartite chimeric receptor. 	 METHODS
Transduced Tregs maintained their Foxp3 level, could undergo repeated expansion upon ex vivo encounter with their cognate antigen in a major histocompatibility complex-independent, costimulation-independent, and contact-dependent manner and specifically suppressed Teff cells. 	 RESULTS
Adoptive transfer of small numbers of the transduced nTregs was associated with antigen-specific, dose-dependent amelioration of trinitrobenzenesulphonic acid colitis. 	 RESULTS
This study demonstrates that nTregs can be efficiently transduced to express functional, antigen-specific chimeric receptors that enable the specific suppression of effector T cells both in vitro and in vivo. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This approach may enable future cell-based therapeutic application in inflammatory bowel disease, as well as other inflammatory disorders. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The effects of hydroxyethyl starch on bleeding after cardiopulmonary bypass were determined. 	 OBJECTIVE
A meta-analysis was performed of postoperative blood loss in randomized clinical trials of hydroxyethyl starch versus albumin for fluid management in adult cardiopulmonary bypass surgery. 	 METHODS
Impacts of hydroxyethyl starch molecular weight and molar substitution were assessed. 	 METHODS
Randomized trials directly comparing different hydroxyethyl starch solutions were also included. 	 METHODS
Eighteen trials with 970 total patients were included. 	 RESULTS
Compared with albumin, hydroxyethyl starch increased postoperative blood loss by 33.3% of a pooled SD (95% confidence interval, 18.2%-48.3%; P < .001). 	 RESULTS
Risk of reoperation for bleeding was more than doubled by hydroxyethyl starch (relative risk, 2.24; 95% confidence interval, 1.14-4.40; P = .020). 	 RESULTS
Hydroxyethyl starch increased transfusion of red blood cells by 28.4% of a pooled SD (95% confidence interval, 12.2%-44.6%; P < .001), of fresh-frozen plasma by 30.6% (95% confidence interval, 8.0%-53.1%; P = .008), and of platelets by 29.8% (95% confidence interval, 3.4%-56.2%; P = .027). 	 RESULTS
None of these effects differed significantly between hydroxyethyl starch 450/0.7 and 200/0.5. 	 RESULTS
Insufficient data were available for hydroxyethyl starch 130/0.4 versus albumin; however, no significant differences were detected in head-to-head comparisons of hydroxyethyl starch 130/0.4 with 200/0.5. 	 RESULTS
Albumin improved hemodynamics. 	 RESULTS
There were no differences in fluid balance, ventilator time, intensive care unit stay, or mortality. 	 RESULTS
Hydroxyethyl starch increased blood loss, reoperation for bleeding, and blood product transfusion after cardiopulmonary bypass. 	 CONCLUSIONS
There was no evidence that these risks could be mitigated by lower molecular weight and substitution. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To describe the efficacy of the Finnish mass screening program for cervical squamous carcinoma and adenocarcinoma, as reflected by changes of incidence and mortality rate. 	 OBJECTIVE
Cervical cancer incidence and mortality data were obtained from the Finnish Cancer Registry. 	 METHODS
Data were available from the year 1953, when the registry was established. 	 METHODS
The nationwide mass screening program in Finland was started in the mid-1960s. 	 METHODS
A centralized organization administers this program. 	 METHODS
Women age 30-60 years are notified for screening every 5 years. 	 METHODS
The mean incidence of cervical carcinoma in the early 1960s was 15.4 per 10(5) woman-years. 	 RESULTS
In 1991, it was only 2.7 per 10(5) woman-years. 	 RESULTS
The mortality rate has decreased in the same proportion since the mass screening program. 	 RESULTS
In the early 1960s, the mortality was 6.6 and in 1991 1.4 per 10(5) woman-years. 	 RESULTS
However, the decrease of the incidence is seen almost exclusively in squamous cell carcinomas. 	 RESULTS
The mortality caused by adenocarcinoma has decreased in screened birth cohorts, but the incidence rate has remained the same. 	 RESULTS
The Finnish mass screening program has been effective and its continuation is of utmost importance. 	 CONCLUSIONS
In the future more attention should be given to glandular cell atypias in cervical smears. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Thus, it might be possible to decrease the incidence of cervical adenocarcinoma. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To explore the different characteristics of high and low fat consumers, in particular their macronutrient intake and body mass index. 	 OBJECTIVES
Reanalysis of data from the Dietary and Nutritional Survey of British Adults. 	 DESIGN
Comparisons were made between groups defined as high and low fat consumers on the basis of 7-day weighed food records considered to be valid for energy intake. 	 DESIGN
Individuals were classified in two ways according to the percentage energy from fat (FAT%) and the absolute amount of fat consumed (FATg). 	 DESIGN
The criteria for classification of the high FAT% being > 45% (high fat) and < or = 35% (low fat). 	 DESIGN
For the FATg group the threshold for the high fat group was > 138 g/day (men) and > 102 g/day (women), and for the low fat group < 85 g/day (men) and < 70 g/day (women). 	 DESIGN
Dietary data was collected from private households in Great Britain between 1986 and 1987. 	 SETTING
From the total population of 2197, individuals who were slimming, ill or had an EI: BMR of < 1.2 were excluded in order to use data which was most likely to represent habitual energy intakes. 	 SUBJECTS
From the remaining 1240 subjects, 10.8% of this sample (6.1% of the total population) were classified as low fat consumers (76 men and 58 women) and 15.4% high fat (8.7% of the total population, 93 men and 98 women). 	 SUBJECTS
Macronutrient consumption and body mass index (BMI). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
30% of the subjects changed fat group classification when the criteria of defining high and low fat groups altered from FAT% to FATg. 	 RESULTS
Nutrient intakes differed according to definition of the groups. 	 RESULTS
The high fat FATg group ate significantly more of all nutrients than the low fat FATg group. 	 RESULTS
However, this was not seen for the FAT% analysis, with the high fat group eating more fat and less carbohydrate. 	 RESULTS
The average BMI tended to be higher in the high fat than the low fat groups, particularly in the FATg analysis. 	 RESULTS
However, the high fat group contained a wide range of BMIs. 	 RESULTS
Further exploration of BMI in the high fat groups, showed that age (an 11-year difference) was the only variable to distinguish individuals in the top and bottom quartiles of BMI. 	 RESULTS
High and low fat consumers differ according to a number of variables, and this is affected by how these groups are defined (FAT% or FATg). 	 CONCLUSIONS
High fat consumers tend to have a higher BMI than low fat consumers, but not all high fat consumers are overweight or obese. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Type 1 diabetes mellitus is a chronic autoimmune disease caused by the pathogenic action of T lymphocytes on insulin-producing beta cells. 	 BACKGROUND
Previous clinical studies have shown that continuous immune suppression temporarily slows the loss of insulin production. 	 BACKGROUND
Preclinical studies suggested that a monoclonal antibody against CD3 could reverse hyperglycemia at presentation and induce tolerance to recurrent disease. 	 BACKGROUND
We studied the effects of a nonactivating humanized monoclonal antibody against CD3--hOKT3gamma1(Ala-Ala)--on the loss of insulin production in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus. 	 METHODS
Within 6 weeks after diagnosis, 24 patients were randomly assigned to receive either a single 14-day course of treatment with the monoclonal antibody or no antibody and were studied during the first year of disease. 	 METHODS
Treatment with the monoclonal antibody maintained or improved insulin production after one year in 9 of the 12 patients in the treatment group, whereas only 2 of the 12 controls had a sustained response (P=0.01). 	 RESULTS
The treatment effect on insulin responses lasted for at least 12 months after diagnosis. 	 RESULTS
Glycosylated hemoglobin levels and insulin doses were also reduced in the monoclonal-antibody group. 	 RESULTS
No severe side effects occurred, and the most common side effects were fever, rash, and anemia. 	 RESULTS
Clinical responses were associated with a change in the ratio of CD4+ T cells to CD8+ T cells 30 and 90 days after treatment. 	 RESULTS
Treatment with hOKT3gamma1(Ala-Ala) mitigates the deterioration in insulin production and improves metabolic control during the first year of type 1 diabetes mellitus in the majority of patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The mechanism of action of the anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody may involve direct effects on pathogenic T cells, the induction of populations of regulatory cells, or both. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Nociceptive and neuropathic components both contribute to pain. 	 OBJECTIVE
Since these components require different pain management strategies, correct pain diagnosis before and during treatment is highly desirable. 	 OBJECTIVE
As low back pain (LBP) patients constitute an important subgroup of chronic pain patients, we addressed the following issues: (i) to establish a simple, validated screening tool to detect neuropathic pain (NeP) components in chronic LBP patients, (ii) to determine the prevalence of neuropathic pain components in LBP in a large-scale survey, and (iii) to determine whether LBP patients with an NeP component suffer from worse, or different, co-morbidities. 	 OBJECTIVE
In co-operation with the German Research Network on Neuropathic Pain we developed and validated the painDETECT questionnaire (PD-Q) in a prospective, multicentre study and subsequently applied it to approximately 8000 LBP patients. 	 METHODS
The PD-Q is a reliable screening tool with high sensitivity, specificity and positive predictive accuracy; these were 84% in a palm-top computerised version and 85%, 80% and 83%, respectively, in a corresponding pencil-and-paper questionnaire. 	 RESULTS
In an unselected cohort of chronic LBP patients, 37% were found to have predominantly neuropathic pain. 	 RESULTS
Patients with NeP showed higher ratings of pain intensity, with more (and more severe) co-morbidities such as depression, panic/anxiety and sleep disorders. 	 RESULTS
This also affected functionality and use of health-care resources. 	 RESULTS
On the basis of given prevalence of LBP in the general population, we calculated that 14.5% of all female and 11.4% of all male Germans suffer from LBP with a predominant neuropathic pain component. 	 RESULTS
Simple, patient-based, easy-to-use screening questionnaires can determine the prevalence of neuropathic pain components both in individual LBP patients and in heterogeneous cohorts of such patients. 	 CONCLUSION
Since NeP correlates with more intense pain, more severe co-morbidity and poorer quality of life, accurate diagnosis is a milestone in choosing appropriate therapy. 	 CONCLUSION
Knowledge gaps have contributed to considerable variation among international dietary recommendations for vitamin D.   OBJECTIVE We aimed to establish the distribution of dietary vitamin D required to maintain serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] concentrations above several proposed cutoffs (ie, 25, 37.5, 50, and 80 nmol/L) during wintertime after adjustment for the effect of summer sunshine exposure and diet. 	 BACKGROUND
A randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind 22-wk intervention study was conducted in men and women aged 20-40 y (n = 238) by using different supplemental doses (0, 5, 10, and 15 microg/d) of vitamin D(3) throughout the winter. 	 DESIGN
Serum 25(OH)D concentrations were measured by using enzyme-linked immunoassay at baseline (October 2006) and endpoint (March 2007). 	 DESIGN
There were clear dose-related increments (P < 0.0001) in serum 25(OH)D with increasing supplemental vitamin D(3). 	 RESULTS
The slope of the relation between vitamin D intake and serum 25(OH)D was 1.96 nmol x L(-1) x microg(-1) intake. 	 RESULTS
The vitamin D intake that maintained serum 25(OH)D concentrations of >25 nmol/L in 97.5% of the sample was 8.7 microg/d. 	 RESULTS
This intake ranged from 7.2 microg/d in those who enjoyed sunshine exposure, 8.8 microg/d in those who sometimes had sun exposure, and 12.3 microg/d in those who avoided sunshine. 	 RESULTS
Vitamin D intakes required to maintain serum 25(OH)D concentrations of >37.5, >50, and >80 nmol/L in 97.5% of the sample were 19.9, 28.0, and 41.1 microg/d, respectively. 	 RESULTS
The range of vitamin D intakes required to ensure maintenance of wintertime vitamin D status [as defined by incremental cutoffs of serum 25(OH)D] in the vast majority (>97.5%) of 20-40-y-old adults, considering a variety of sun exposure preferences, is between 7.2 and 41.1 microg/d. 	 CONCLUSION
Soluble corin was decreased in coronary heart disease. 	 BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
Given the connections between cardiac dysfunction and stroke, circulating corin might be a candidate marker of stroke risk. 	 BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
However, the association between circulating corin and stroke has not yet been studied in humans. 	 BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
Here, we aimed to examine the association in patients wtith stroke and community-based healthy controls. 	 BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
Four hundred eighty-one patients with ischemic stroke, 116 patients with hemorrhagic stroke, and 2498 healthy controls were studied. 	 METHODS
Serum soluble corin and some conventional risk factors of stroke were examined. 	 METHODS
Because circulating corin was reported to be varied between men and women, the association between serum soluble corin and stroke was evaluated in men and women, respectively. 	 METHODS
Patients with ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke had a significantly lower level of serum soluble corin than healthy controls in men and women (all P values, <0.05). 	 RESULTS
In multivariate analysis, men in the lowest quartile of serum soluble corin were more likely to have ischemic (odds ratio [OR], 4.90; 95% confidence interval, 2.99-8.03) and hemorrhagic (OR, 17.57; 95% confidence interval, 4.85-63.71) stroke than men in the highest quartile. 	 RESULTS
Women in the lowest quartile of serum soluble corin were also more likely to have ischemic (OR, 3.10; 95% confidence interval, 1.76-5.44) and hemorrhagic (OR, 8.54; 95% confidence interval, 2.35-31.02) stroke than women in the highest quartile. 	 RESULTS
ORs of ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke were significantly increased with the decreasing levels of serum soluble corin in men and women (all P values for trend, <0.001). 	 RESULTS
Serum soluble corin was decreased in patients with stroke compared with healthy controls. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Our findings raise the possibility that serum soluble corin may have a pathogenic role in stroke. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Umbilical cord infection (omphalitis) is a risk factor for neonatal sepsis and mortality in low-resource settings where home deliveries are common. 	 BACKGROUND
We aimed to assess the effect of umbilical-cord cleansing with 4% chlorhexidine (CHX) solution, with or without handwashing with antiseptic soap, on the incidence of omphalitis and neonatal mortality. 	 BACKGROUND
We did a two-by-two factorial, cluster-randomised trial in Dadu, a rural area of Sindh province, Pakistan. 	 METHODS
Clusters were defined as the population covered by a functional traditional birth attendant (TBA), and were randomly allocated to one of four groups (groups A to D) with a computer-generated random number sequence. 	 METHODS
Implementation and data collection teams were masked to allocation. 	 METHODS
Liveborn infants delivered by participating TBAs who received birth kits were eligible for enrolment in the study. 	 METHODS
One intervention comprised birth kits containing 4% CHX solution for application to the cord at birth by TBAs and once daily by family members for up to 14 days along with soap and educational messages promoting handwashing. 	 METHODS
One intervention was CHX solution only and another was handwashing only. 	 METHODS
Standard dry cord care was promoted in the control group. 	 METHODS
The primary outcomes were incidence of neonatal omphalitis and neonatal mortality. 	 METHODS
The trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00682006. 	 METHODS
187 clusters were randomly allocated to one of the four study groups. 	 FINDINGS
Of 9741 newborn babies delivered by participating TBAs, factorial analysis indicated a reduction in risk of omphalitis with CHX application (risk ratio [RR]=0·58, 95% CI 0·41-0·82; p=0·002) but no evidence of an effect of handwashing (RR=0·83, 0·61-1·13; p=0·24). 	 FINDINGS
We recorded strong evidence of a reduction in neonatal mortality in neonates who received CHX cleansing (RR=0·62, 95 % CI 0·45-0·85; p=0·003) but no evidence of an effect of handwashing promotion on neonatal mortality (RR=1·08, 0·79-1·48; p=0·62). 	 FINDINGS
We recorded no serious adverse events. 	 FINDINGS
Application of 4% CHX to the umbilical cord was effective in reducing the risk of omphalitis and neonatal mortality in rural Pakistan. 	 INTERPRETATION
Provision of CHX in birth kits might be a useful strategy for the prevention of neonatal mortality in high-mortality settings. 	 INTERPRETATION
FUNDING 	 INTERPRETATION
The United States Agency for International Development. 	 INTERPRETATION
We assessed the nephroprotective effects of montelukast sodium and N-acetylcysteine on secondary renal damage due to unilateral ureteral obstruction in a rat model. 	 PURPOSE
In this study 30 Wistar albino male rats were randomized into 3 groups, including placebo, N-acetylcysteine and montelukast sodium. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
Three rats served as the control group. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
The left ureter of the rats was sutured with 4-zero polyglactin sutures. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
Medications were given 3 days before obstruction and continued for 15 days. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
Dimercaptosuccinic acid renal scintigraphy was performed before obstruction and on day 15. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
Rats were sacrificed on day 15 and histopathological examinations were done. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
We biochemically assessed oxidative stress markers (myeloperoxidase and malondialdehyde), sulfhydryl and total nitrite for lipid peroxidation, oxidative protein damage and antioxidant levels, respectively. 	 MATERIALS AND METHODS
On pathological examination inflammation and tubular epithelial damage in the N-acetylcysteine and montelukast sodium groups were less than in the placebo group (p <0.05). 	 RESULTS
No difference was seen in normal kidneys. 	 RESULTS
Myeloperoxidase, malondialdehyde and total nitrite levels in the N-acetylcysteine group, and myeloperoxidase and malondialdehyde levels in the montelukast sodium group were lower than in the placebo group (p <0.05). 	 RESULTS
No statistical difference was seen in sulfhydryl levels (p >0.05) or among the N-acetylcysteine, montelukast sodium and placebo groups on scintigraphy (p >0.05). 	 RESULTS
No pathological, chemical and scintigraphic differences were seen among the N-acetylcysteine, montelukast sodium and sham treated groups (p >0.05). 	 RESULTS
N-acetylcysteine and montelukast sodium have a protective effect against obstructive damage of the kidney. 	 CONCLUSIONS
However, further investigations are needed. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Folate and vitamin B12 are two vital regulators in the metabolic process of homocysteine, which is a risk factor of atherothrombotic events. 	 OBJECTIVE
Low folate intake or low plasma folate concentration is associated with increased stroke risk. 	 OBJECTIVE
Previous randomized controlled trials presented discordant findings in the effect of folic acid supplementation-based homocysteine lowering on stroke risk. 	 OBJECTIVE
The aim of the present review was to perform a meta-analysis of relevant randomized controlled trials to check the how different folate fortification status might affect the effects of folic acid supplementation in lowering homocysteine and reducing stroke risk. 	 OBJECTIVE
Relevant randomized controlled trials were identified through formal literature search. 	 DESIGN
Homocysteine reduction was compared in subgroups stratified by folate fortification status. 	 DESIGN
Relative risks with 95 % confidence intervals were used as a measure to assess the association between folic acid supplementation and stroke risk. 	 DESIGN
The meta-analysis included fourteen randomized controlled trials,   SUBJECTS A total of 39 420 patients. 	 SETTING
Homocysteine reductions were 26·99 (sd 1·91) %, 18·38 (sd 3·82) % and 21·30 (sd 1·98) %, respectively, in the subgroups without folate fortification, with folate fortification and with partial folate fortification. 	 RESULTS
Significant difference was observed between the subgroups with folate fortification and without folate fortification (P=0·05). 	 RESULTS
The relative risk of stroke was 0·88 (95 % CI 0·77, 1·00, P=0·05) in the subgroup without folate fortification, 0·94 (95 % CI 0·58, 1·54, P=0·82) in the subgroup with folate fortification and 0·91 (95 % CI 0·82, 1·01, P=0·09) in the subgroup with partial folate fortification. 	 RESULTS
Folic acid supplementation might have a modest benefit on stroke prevention in regions without folate fortification. 	 CONCLUSIONS
During pregnancy, serum levels of estrogen, progesterone, and other hormones are markedly higher than during other periods of life. 	 CONTEXT
Pregnancy hormones primarily are produced in the placenta, and signs of placental impairment may serve as indirect markers of hormone exposures during pregnancy. 	 CONTEXT
During pregnancy, these markers have been inconsistently associated with subsequent risk of breast cancer in the mother. 	 CONTEXT
To examine associations between indirect markers of hormonal exposures, such as placental weight and other pregnancy characteristics, and maternal risk of developing breast cancer. 	 OBJECTIVE
Population-based cohort study using data from the Swedish Birth Register, the Swedish Cancer Register, the Swedish Cause of Death Register, and the Swedish Register of Population and Population Changes. 	 DESIGN AND SETTING
Women included in the Sweden Birth Register who delivered singletons between 1982 and 1989, with complete information on date of birth and gestational age. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Women were followed up until the occurrence of breast cancer, death, or end of follow-up (December 31, 2001). 	 PARTICIPANTS
Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate associations between hormone exposures and risks of breast cancer. 	 PARTICIPANTS
Incidence of invasive breast cancer. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE
Of 314,019 women in the cohort, 2216 (0.7%) developed breast cancer during the follow-up through 2001, of whom 2100 (95%) were diagnosed before age 50 years. 	 RESULTS
Compared with women who had placentas weighing less than 500 g in 2 consecutive pregnancies, the risk of breast cancer was increased among women whose placentas weighed between 500 and 699 g in their first pregnancy and at least 700 g in their second pregnancy (or vice versa) (adjusted hazard ratio, 1.82; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.07-3.08), and the corresponding risk was doubled among women whose placentas weighed at least 700 g in both pregnancies (adjusted hazard ratio, 2.05; 95% CI, 1.15-3.64). 	 RESULTS
A high birth weight (> or =4000 g) in 2 successive births was associated with an increased risk of breast cancer before but not after adjusting for placental weight and other covariates (adjusted hazard ratio, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.76-1.59). 	 RESULTS
Placental weight is positively associated with maternal risk of breast cancer. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These results further support the hypothesis that pregnancy hormones are important modifiers of subsequent maternal breast cancer risk. 	 CONCLUSIONS
To investigate heritability and continuum versus categorical approaches to attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), using a large-scale twin sample. 	 OBJECTIVE
A cohort of 1,938 families with twins and siblings aged 4 to 12 years, recruited from the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council Twin Registry, was assessed for ADHD using a DSM-III-R-based maternal rating scale. 	 METHOD
Probandwise concordance rates and correlations in monozygotic and dizygotic twins and siblings were calculated, and heritability was examined using the De Fries and Fulker regression technique. 	 METHOD
There was a narrow (additive) heritability of 0.75 to 0.91 which was robust across familial relationships (twin, sibling, and twin-sibling) and across definitions of ADHD as part of a continuum or as a disorder with various symptom cutoffs. 	 RESULTS
There was no evidence for nonadditive genetic variation or for shared family environmental effects. 	 RESULTS
These findings suggest that ADHD is best viewed as the extreme of a behavior that varies genetically throughout the entire population rather than as a disorder with discrete determinants. 	 CONCLUSIONS
This has implications for the classification of ADHD and for the identification of genes for this behavior, as well as implications for diagnosis and treatment. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The infrapatellar fat pad (IPFP) has been identified as a source of anterior knee pain. 	 OBJECTIVE
Fibrosis and marked inflammatory infiltrate in the IPFP of patients with arthritis of the knee and reduction in pain post knee replacement in patients following resection of the IPFP have been observed. 	 OBJECTIVE
We have investigated changes in the IPFP of rats undergoing the monoiodoacetate (MIA) model of degenerative joint disease, a model that exhibits some histopathological similarities to osteoarthritis (OA). 	 OBJECTIVE
Rats were injected intra-articularly with MIA and the development of weight bearing asymmetry was followed for 21 days as compared to vehicle-injected animals. 	 METHODS
In addition, IPFPs were removed from both ipsilateral and contralateral joints. 	 METHODS
Both inflammatory infiltrate and histopathological changes were analysed. 	 METHODS
injection caused marked weight bearing asymmetry. 	 RESULTS MIA
Ipsilateral IPFP wet weights were significantly increased on days 1 and 3 in MIA-treated animals. 	 RESULTS MIA
treatment also resulted in significant increases in IPFP total white blood cells and monocytes on days 1, 3, and 7 and neutrophils on days 1 and 3. 	 MIA
This was supported by histopathological findings at early time points which progressed to adipocyte necrosis, IPFP fibrosis, patellar cartilage and subchondral bone necrosis with synovial hyperplasia at later timepoints. 	 MIA
The current study clearly demonstrated that marked inflammatory changes in the IPFP occur during the early stage of the MIA model of OA which may contribute to the pain observed at this early stage. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The role of the IPFP in later stages of the model needs to be further explored. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Obesity and being overweight during adulthood have been consistently linked to increased risk for development of dementia later in life, especially Alzheimer's disease. 	 OBJECTIVE
They have also been associated with cognitive dysfunction and brain structural alterations in otherwise healthy adults. 	 OBJECTIVE
Although proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy may distinguish between neuronal and glial components of the brain and may point to neurobiological mechanisms underlying brain atrophy and cognitive changes, no spectroscopic studies have yet assessed the relationships between adiposity and brain metabolites. 	 OBJECTIVE
We have utilized magnetic resonance imaging and proton magnetic resonance spectroscopic imaging data from 50 healthy middle-aged participants (mean age, 41.7 +/- 	 METHODS
8.5 years; 17 women), who were scanned as control subjects for another study. 	 METHODS
After adjustment for age and sex, greater body mass indices (BMIs) correlated with: (1) lower concentrations of N-acetylaspartate (spectroscopic marker of neuronal viability) in frontal (p = 0.001), parietal (p = 0.006), and temporal (p = 0.008) white matter; (2) lower N-acetylaspartate in frontal gray matter (p = 0.01); and (3) lower concentrations of choline-containing metabolites (associated with membrane metabolism) in frontal white matter (p = 0.05). 	 RESULTS
These results suggest that increased BMI at midlife is associated with neuronal and/or myelin abnormalities, primarily in the frontal lobe. 	 INTERPRETATION
Because white matter in the frontal lobes is more prone to the effects of aging than in other lobes, our results may reflect accelerated aging in individuals with high levels of adiposity. 	 INTERPRETATION
Thus, greater BMI may increase the odds of developing an age-related disease, such as Alzheimer's disease. 	 INTERPRETATION
Phenylpropanolamine is commonly found in appetite suppressants and cough or cold remedies. 	 BACKGROUND
Case reports have linked the use of products containing phenylpropanolamine to hemorrhagic stroke, often after the first use of these products. 	 BACKGROUND
To study the association, we designed a case-control study. 	 BACKGROUND
Men and women 18 to 49 years of age were recruited from 43 U.S. hospitals. 	 METHODS
Eligibility criteria included the occurrence of a subarachnoid or intracerebral hemorrhage within 30 days before enrollment and the absence of a previously diagnosed brain lesion. 	 METHODS
Random-digit dialing identified two matched control subjects per patient. 	 METHODS
There were 702 patients and 1376 control subjects. 	 RESULTS
For women, the adjusted odds ratio was 16.58 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.51 to 182.21; P=0.02) for the association between the use of appetite suppressants containing phenylpropanolamine and the risk of a hemorrhagic stroke and 3.13 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.86 to 11.46; P=0.08) for the association with the first use of a product containing phenylpropanolamine. 	 RESULTS
All first uses of phenylpropanolamine involved cough or cold remedies. 	 RESULTS
For men and women combined, the adjusted odds ratio was 1.49 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.84 to 2.64; P=0.17) for the association between the use of a product containing phenylpropanolamine and the risk of a hemorrhagic stroke, 1.23 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.68 to 2.24; P=0.49) for the association with the use of cough or cold remedies that contained phenylpropanolamine, and 15.92 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.38 to 184.13; P=0.03) for the association with the use of appetite suppressants that contained phenylpropanolamine. 	 RESULTS
An analysis in men showed no increased risk of a hemorrhagic stroke in association with the use of cough or cold remedies containing phenylpropanolamine. 	 RESULTS
No men reported the use of appetite suppressants. 	 RESULTS
The results suggest that phenylpropanolamine in appetite suppressants, and possibly in cough and cold remedies, is an independent risk factor for hemorrhagic stroke in women. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Confocal laser endomicroscopy (CLE) is rapidly emerging as a valuable tool for gastrointestinal endoscopic imaging. 	 BACKGROUND
Fluorescent contrast agents are used to optimize imaging with CLE, and intravenous fluorescein is the most widely used contrast agent. 	 BACKGROUND
Fluorescein is FDA-cleared for diagnostic angiography of the retina. 	 BACKGROUND
For these indications, the safety profile of fluorescein has been well-documented; however, to date, fluorescein is not cleared for use with CLE. 	 BACKGROUND
To estimate the rate of serious and total adverse events attributable to intravenous fluorescein when used for gastrointestinal CLE. 	 AIMS
We performed a cross sectional survey of 16 International Academic Medical Centres with active research protocols in CLE that involved intravenous fluorescein. 	 METHODS
Centres using i.v. 	 METHODS
fluorescein for CLE who were actively monitored for adverse events were included. 	 METHODS
Sixteen centres performed 2272 gastrointestinal CLE procedures. 	 RESULTS
The most common dose of contrast agent was 2.5-5 mL of 10% sodium fluorescein. 	 RESULTS
No serious adverse events were reported. 	 RESULTS
Mild adverse events occurred in 1.4% of individuals, including nausea/vomiting, transient hypotension without shock, injection site erythema, diffuse rash and mild epigastric pain. 	 RESULTS
The limitation is that only immediate post procedure events were actively monitored. 	 RESULTS
Use of intravenous fluorescein for gastrointestinal CLE appears to be safe with few acute complications. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The study of soluble corin in the circulation before hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) has been limited. 	 OBJECTIVE
Here we aimed to study serum soluble corin in mid pregnancy in patients with HDP and their age- and gestational weeks-matched controls. 	 OBJECTIVE
Sixty-eight pairs of cases of HDP and controls were studied. 	 METHODS
Blood samples were obtained in mid pregnancy between 16 and 20 gestational weeks. 	 METHODS
Serum soluble corin was examined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay methods. 	 METHODS
The relationship between serum soluble corin and HDP was examined using conditional logistic regression models. 	 METHODS
Serum soluble corin in mid pregnancy was increased in cases with HDP compared with controls (median [interquartile range]: 1968 [1644-2332] pg/mL vs. 1700 [1446-2056] pg/mL, p=0.002). 	 RESULTS
Participants were categorized into quartiles of serum soluble corin distributed in controls. 	 RESULTS
Compared with the lowest quartile, participants in the highest quartile had a significantly increased risk for HDP (odds ratio [OR], 4.21; 95% confidence interval [95% CI], 1.31-13.53) after multivariate adjustment. 	 RESULTS
Nevertheless, we did not find a significantly increased risk for participants in the second (OR, 1.75; 95% CI, 0.44-7.02) and third (OR, 2.80; 95% CI, 0.70-11.18) quartiles. 	 RESULTS
Then the first three quartiles were merged as a reference group to calculate the OR of HDP for participants in the highest quartile and we found a significantly increased risk for HDP in individuals in the highest quartile (OR, 2.28, 95% CI, 1.02-5.06). 	 RESULTS
Increased serum soluble corin in mid pregnancy was associated with an increased risk for HDP. 	 CONCLUSION
Our findings suggest that increased serum soluble corin in mid pregnancy could be an indicator for HDP. 	 CONCLUSION
The goal of this study was to evaluate prospectively the engraftment rate, factors influencing engraftment, and predictability of clinical outcome of low-passage xenografts from patients with resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) and to establish a bank of PDA xenografts. 	 PURPOSE
Patients with resectable PDA scheduled for resection at the Johns Hopkins Hospital were eligible. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Representative pieces of tumor were implanted in nude mice. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
The status of the SMAD4 gene and content of tumor-generating cells were determined by immunohistochemistry. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Gene expression was carried out by using a U133 Plus 2.0 array. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
Patients were followed for progression and survival. 	 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN
A total of 94 patients with PDA were resected, 69 tumors implanted in nude mice, and 42 (61%) engrafted. 	 RESULTS
Engrafted carcinomas were more often SMAD4 mutant, and had a metastatic gene expression signature and worse prognosis. 	 RESULTS
Tumors from patients resistant to gemcitabine were enriched in stroma-related gene pathways. 	 RESULTS
Tumors sensitive to gemcitabine were enriched in cell cycle and pyrimidine gene pathways. 	 RESULTS
The time to progression for patients who received treatment with gemcitabine for metastatic disease (n = 7) was double in patients with xenografts sensitive to gemcitabine. 	 RESULTS
A successful xenograft was generated in 61% of patients attempted, generating a pool of 42 PDA xenografts with significant biological information and annotated clinical data. 	 CONCLUSION
Patients with PDA and SMAD4 inactivation have a better engraftment rate. 	 CONCLUSION
Engraftment is a poor prognosis factor, and engrafted tumors have a metastatic gene expression signature. 	 CONCLUSION
Tumors from gemcitabine-resistant patients were enriched in stromal pathways. 	 CONCLUSION
A20 is a TNF-inducible primary response gene, which has been found to have antiapoptotic function in several cancer cells. 	 OBJECTIVE
This study investigates A20 expression in human glioma tissues and four glioma cell lines, and its effect on tumorigenesis of glioma cells and a mouse tumor model. 	 OBJECTIVE
Human glioma tissue samples and cells were subject to reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR), western blotting and immunohistochemistry. 	 METHODS
Glioma cells was tested by flow cytometry. 	 METHODS
A xenograft tumor model in mice was utilized to examine the knock-down effect of specific A20 siRNAs on tumorigenesis. 	 METHODS
A20 was overexpressed in clinical glioma tissue samples (63.9%) and correlated with clinical staging. 	 RESULTS
All four human glioma cell lines expressed A20, among which U87 displayed the strongest expression signals. 	 RESULTS
Inhibiting A20 expression by siRNAs in vitro reduced the growth rates of glioma cells and resulted in G1/S arrest and increased apoptosis. 	 RESULTS
In a mouse tumor model, local administration of siRNA significantly suppressed solid tumor growth. 	 RESULTS
A20 was overexpressed both in human glioma tissues and cell lines, and inhibiting A20 expression greatly slowed tumor cell growth in culture and in mice. 	 CONCLUSIONS
These findings indicated that A20 is involved in tumorigenesis of human glioma, and may serve as a future therapeutic target. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Transcranial contrast Doppler studies have shown an increased prevalence of right-to-left shunts in patients with migraine with aura compared with controls. 	 BACKGROUND
The anatomy and size of these right-to-left shunts have never been directly assessed. 	 BACKGROUND
In a cross-sectional case-control study, the authors performed transesophageal contrast echocardiography in 93 consecutive patients with migraine with aura and 93 healthy controls. 	 METHODS
A patent foramen ovale was present in 44 (47% [95% CI 37 to 58%]) patients with migraine with aura and 16 (17% [95% CI 10 to 26%]) control subjects (OR 4.56 [95% CI 1.97 to 10.57]; p < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
A small shunt was equally prevalent in migraineurs (10% [95% CI 5 to 18%]) and controls (10% [95% CI 5 to 18%]), but a moderate-sized or large shunt was found more often in the migraine group (38% [95% CI 28 to 48%] vs 8% [95% CI 2 to 13%] in controls; p < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
The presence of more than a small shunt increased the odds of having migraine with aura 7.78-fold (95% CI 2.53 to 29.30; p < 0.001). 	 RESULTS
Besides patent foramen ovale prevalence and shunt size, no other echocardiographic differences were found between the study groups. 	 RESULTS
Headache and baseline characteristics did not differ in migraine patients with and without shunt. 	 RESULTS
Nearly half of all patients with migraine with aura have a right-to-left shunt due to a patent foramen ovale. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Shunt size is larger in migraineurs than controls. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The clinical presentation of migraine is identical in patients with and without a patent foramen ovale. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The aim of the study was to provide data on the relative frequency of reported symptoms in travelers using chloroquine, chloroquine plus proguanil, and mefloquine. 	 BACKGROUND
The study was an open, nonrandomized study recording self-reported events in travelers recruited consecutively from two travel clinics in Copenhagen, Denmark. 	 METHOD
The main outcome measures were the relative proportion of travelers reporting particular symptoms in the three prophylaxis groups, compliance, hospitalization and premature termination of the travel. 	 METHOD
From May 1996 to April 1998 5, 446 travelers were included and 4,158 questionnaires (76.3%) returned. 	 RESULTS
Compliance was significantly better in mefloquine users with 83.3% of short term travelers compared to 76.3% in chloroquine plus proguanil users. 	 RESULTS
Also, 84.8%, 59.3% and 69.5% using chloroquine, chloroquine plus proguanil, and mefloquine respectively reported no symptoms and 0.6%, 1.1% and 2.8% reported "unacceptable" symptoms. 	 RESULTS
Compared to chloroquine, mefloquine users had a significantly higher risk of reporting depression, RR 5.06 (95% CI 2.71 - 9.45), "strange thoughts," RR 6.36 (95% CI 2.52 - 16.05) and altered spatial perception, RR 3.00 (95% CI 1.41 - 6.41). 	 RESULTS
Overall mefloquine is tolerated at least as well as chloroquine plus proguanil and shows better compliance, however, symptoms related to the central nervous system are more prevalent in mefloquine users and when symptoms develop, they are perceived as more severe. 	 CONCLUSION
While many treatments, including corticosteroid injections in and around the shoulder, are advocated to be of benefit for shoulder pain, few are of proven efficacy. 	 BACKGROUND
This review of corticosteroid injections for shoulder pain is one in a series of reviews of varying interventions for shoulder disorders. 	 BACKGROUND
To determine the efficacy and safety of corticosteroid injections in the treatment of adults with shoulder pain. 	 OBJECTIVES
MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, Central and Science Citation Index were searched up to and including June 2002. 	 SEARCH STRATEGY
Randomised and pseudo-randomised trials in all languages of corticosteroid injections compared to placebo or another intervention, or of varying types and dosages of steroid injection in adults with shoulder pain. 	 SELECTION CRITERIA
Specific exclusions were duration of shoulder pain less than three weeks, rheumatoid arthritis, polymyalgia rheumatica and fracture. 	 SELECTION CRITERIA
Trial inclusion and methodological quality was assessed by two independent reviewers according to predetermined criteria. 	 DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS
Results are presented separately for rotator cuff disease, adhesive capsulitis, full thickness rotator cuff tear and mixed diagnoses, and, where possible, combined in meta-analysis. 	 DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS
Twenty-six trials met inclusion criteria. 	 MAIN RESULTS
The number, site and dosage of injections varied widely between studies. 	 MAIN RESULTS
The number of participants per trial ranged from 20 to 114 (median 52 participants). 	 MAIN RESULTS
Methodological quality was variable. 	 MAIN RESULTS
For rotator cuff disease, subacromial steroid injection was demonstrated to have a small benefit over placebo in some trials however no benefit of subacromial steroid injection over NSAID was demonstrated based upon the pooled results of three trials. 	 MAIN RESULTS
For adhesive capsulitis, two trials suggested a possible early benefit of intra-articular steroid injection over placebo but there was insufficient data for pooling of any of the trials. 	 MAIN RESULTS
One trial suggested short-term benefit of intra-articular corticosteroid injection over physiotherapy in the short-term (success at seven weeks RR=1.66 (1.21, 2.28). 	 MAIN RESULTS
REVIEWER'S CONCLUSIONS Despite many RCTs of corticosteroid injections for shoulder pain, their small sample sizes, variable methodological quality and heterogeneity means that there is little overall evidence to guide treatment. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Subacromial corticosteroid injection for rotator cuff disease and intra-articular injection for adhesive capsulitis may be beneficial although their effect may be small and not well-maintained. 	 MAIN RESULTS
There is a need for further trials investigating the efficacy of corticosteroid injections for shoulder pain. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Other important issues that remain to be clarified include whether the accuracy of needle placement, anatomical site, frequency, dose and type of corticosteroid influences efficacy. 	 MAIN RESULTS
Atherosclerotic plaques that lead to acute coronary syndromes often occur at sites of angiographically mild coronary-artery stenosis. 	 BACKGROUND
Lesion-related risk factors for such events are poorly understood. 	 BACKGROUND
In a prospective study, 697 patients with acute coronary syndromes underwent three-vessel coronary angiography and gray-scale and radiofrequency intravascular ultrasonographic imaging after percutaneous coronary intervention. 	 METHODS
Subsequent major adverse cardiovascular events (death from cardiac causes, cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, or rehospitalization due to unstable or progressive angina) were adjudicated to be related to either originally treated (culprit) lesions or untreated (nonculprit) lesions. 	 METHODS
The median follow-up period was 3.4 years. 	 METHODS
The 3-year cumulative rate of major adverse cardiovascular events was 20.4%. 	 RESULTS
Events were adjudicated to be related to culprit lesions in 12.9% of patients and to nonculprit lesions in 11.6%. 	 RESULTS
Most nonculprit lesions responsible for follow-up events were angiographically mild at baseline (mean [±SD] diameter stenosis, 32.3±20.6%). 	 RESULTS
However, on multivariate analysis, nonculprit lesions associated with recurrent events were more likely than those not associated with recurrent events to be characterized by a plaque burden of 70% or greater (hazard ratio, 5.03; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.51 to 10.11; P<0.001) or a minimal luminal area of 4.0 mm(2) or less (hazard ratio, 3.21; 95% CI, 1.61 to 6.42; P=0.001) or to be classified on the basis of radiofrequency intravascular ultrasonography as thin-cap fibroatheromas (hazard ratio, 3.35; 95% CI, 1.77 to 6.36; P<0.001). 	 RESULTS
In patients who presented with an acute coronary syndrome and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention, major adverse cardiovascular events occurring during follow-up were equally attributable to recurrence at the site of culprit lesions and to nonculprit lesions. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Although nonculprit lesions that were responsible for unanticipated events were frequently angiographically mild, most were thin-cap fibroatheromas or were characterized by a large plaque burden, a small luminal area, or some combination of these characteristics, as determined by gray-scale and radiofrequency intravascular ultrasonography. 	 CONCLUSIONS
(Funded by Abbott Vascular and Volcano; ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00180466.). 	 CONCLUSIONS
To examine the curricula of U.S. medical schools to assess the inclusion of women's health and gender-specific information and identify institutional characteristics associated with this content. 	 PURPOSE
Using data from the Association of American Medical Colleges' Curriculum Management and Information Tool (CurrMIT), in November 2003 to February 2004 the authors performed a curriculum search of schools that entered course/clerkships in CurrMIT to identify interdisciplinary women's health or gender-specific courses/clerkships. 	 METHOD
A subset of schools that entered comprehensive information in CurrMIT was searched for a specified list of women's health topics and or gender-specific content on any topic. 	 METHOD
Statistical analyses were performed to assess the relationship between frequency of topics and school characteristics. 	 METHOD
The authors identified 95 schools that entered related courses/clerkships. 	 RESULTS
Ten courses/clerkships at nine schools met criteria for an interdisciplinary women's health course/clerkship. 	 RESULTS
In the subset of 60 schools with comprehensive CurrMIT information, 18 specified women's health topics were identified, as well as 24 topics on gender-specific content, for a total of 42 topics. 	 RESULTS
The number of topics taught ranged from zero to 26 (mean = 11). 	 RESULTS
More than 50% of these schools taught 11 of the 18 specified topics, while fewer than 30% included gender-specific topics. 	 RESULTS
There was no association in bivariate analysis between the mean number of topics taught and schools' characteristics; however, a women's health program (p= .01) and female dean (p= .06) were positively associated in a regression model. 	 RESULTS
Few schools offer interdisciplinary women's health courses/clerkships or include gender-specific information in their curricula. 	 CONCLUSIONS
A designated women's health program may increase this content in schools' curricula. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The purpose of this study was to compare a laboratory based exercise challenge (LBC) to a field based exercise challenge (FBC) for pulmonary function test (PFT) exercise-induced asthma (EIA) screening of elite athletes. 	 PURPOSE
Twenty-three elite cold weather athletes (14 men, 9 women) PFT positive for EIA (FBC screened) served as subjects. 	 METHODS
Twenty-three gender and sport matched controls (nonasthmatics) were randomly selected to establish PFT reference values for normal elite athletes. 	 METHODS
Before FBC, athletes completed a medical history questionnaire for EIA symptoms. 	 METHODS
evaluations consisted of baseline spirometry, actual or simulated competition, and 5, 10, and 15 min postexercise spirometry. 	 FBC
positive athletes were evaluated in the laboratory using an exercise challenge simulating race intensity (ambient conditions: 21 degrees C, 60% relative humidity). 	 PFT
procedures were identical to FBC. 	 PFT
91% of PFT positive and 48% of PFT normal athletes reported at least one symptom of EIA, with postrace cough most frequent. 	 RESULTS
Baseline spirometry was the same for PFT positives and normal controls. 	 RESULTS
Lower limit reference range (MN - 2 SD) of FEV1 for controls suggests that postexercise decrements of greater than approximately -7% indicate abnormal airway response in this population. 	 RESULTS
Exercise time duration did not effect bronchial reactivity; 78% of FBC PFT positives were PFT normal post-LBC. 	 RESULTS
Self-reported symptoms by elite athletes are not reliable in identifying EIA. 	 CONCLUSION
Reference range criterion for FEV1 decrement in the elite athlete postexercise contrasts current recommended guidelines. 	 CONCLUSION
Moreover, a large number of false negatives may occur in this population if EIA screening is performed with inadequate exercise and environmental stress. 	 CONCLUSION
JX-594 is a targeted oncolytic poxvirus designed to selectively replicate in and destroy cancer cells with cell-cycle abnormalities and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-ras pathway activation. 	 BACKGROUND
Direct oncolysis plus granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) expression also stimulates shutdown of tumour vasculature and antitumoral immunity. 	 BACKGROUND
We aimed to assess intratumoral injection of JX-594 in patients with refractory primary or metastatic liver cancer. 	 BACKGROUND
Between Jan 4, 2006, and July 4, 2007, 14 patients with histologically confirmed refractory primary or metastatic liver tumours (up to 10.9 cm total diameter) that were amenable to image-guided intratumoral injections were enrolled into this non-comparative, open-label, phase I dose-escalation trial (standard 3x3 design; two to six patients for each dose with 12-18 estimated total patients). 	 METHODS
Patients received one of four doses of intratumoral JX-594 (10(8) plaque-forming units [pfu], 3x10(8) pfu, 10(9) pfu, or 3x10(9) pfu) every 3 weeks at Dong-A University Hospital (Busan, South Korea). 	 METHODS
Patients were monitored after treatment for at least 48 h in hospital and for at least 4 weeks as out-patients. 	 METHODS
Adverse event-monitoring according to the National Cancer Institute Common Toxicity Criteria (version 3) and standard laboratory toxicity grading for haematology, liver and renal function, coagulation studies, serum chemistry, and urinalysis were done. 	 METHODS
The primary aims were to ascertain the maximum-tolerated dose (MTD) and safety of JX-594 treatment. 	 METHODS
Data were also collected on pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy. 	 METHODS
Analysis was per protocol. 	 METHODS
This study is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT00629759. 	 METHODS
Of 22 patients with liver tumours who were assessed for eligibility, eight patients did not meet inclusion criteria. 	 FINDINGS
Therefore, 14 patients, including those with hepatocellular, colorectal, melanoma, and lung cancer, were enrolled. 	 FINDINGS
Patients were heavily pretreated (5.6 previous treatments, SD 2.8, range 2.0-12.0) and had large tumours (7.0 cm diameter, SD 2.7, range 1.8-10.9). 	 FINDINGS
Patients received a mean of 3.4 (SD 2.2, range 1.0-8.0) cycles of JX-594. 	 FINDINGS
All patients were evaluable for toxicity. 	 FINDINGS
All patients experienced grade I-III flu-like symptoms, and four had transient grade I-III dose-related thrombocytopenia. 	 FINDINGS
Grade III hyperbilirubinaemia was dose-limiting in both patients at the highest dose; the MTD was therefore 1x10(9) pfu. 	 FINDINGS
JX-594 replication-dependent dissemination in blood was shown, with resultant infection of non-injected tumour sites. 	 FINDINGS
GM-CSF expression resulted in grade I-III increases in neutrophil counts in four of six patients at the MTD. 	 FINDINGS
Tumour responses were shown in injected and non-injected tumours. 	 FINDINGS
Ten patients were radiographically evaluable for objective responses; non-evaluable patients had contraindications to contrast medium (n=2) or no post-treatment scans (n=2). 	 FINDINGS
According to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST), three patients had partial response, six had stable disease, and one had progressive disease. 	 FINDINGS
Intratumoral injection of JX-594 into primary or metastatic liver tumours was generally well-tolerated. 	 INTERPRETATION
Direct hyperbilirubinaemia was the dose-limiting toxicity. 	 INTERPRETATION
Safety was acceptable in the context of JX-594 replication, GM-CSF expression, systemic dissemination, and JX-594 had anti-tumoral effects against several refractory carcinomas. 	 INTERPRETATION
Phase II trials are now underway. 	 INTERPRETATION
The association of an adult tele-intensive care unit (ICU) intervention with hospital mortality, length of stay, best practice adherence, and preventable complications for an academic medical center has not been reported. 	 CONTEXT
To quantify the association of a tele-ICU intervention with hospital mortality, length of stay, and complications that are preventable by adherence to best practices. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Prospective stepped-wedge clinical practice study of 6290 adults admitted to any of 7 ICUs (3 medical, 3 surgical, and 1 mixed cardiovascular) on 2 campuses of an 834-bed academic medical center that was performed from April 26, 2005, through September 30, 2007. 	 OBJECTIVE
Electronically supported and monitored processes for best practice adherence, care plan creation, and clinician response times to alarms were evaluated. 	 OBJECTIVE
Case-mix and severity-adjusted hospital mortality. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Other outcomes included hospital and ICU length of stay, best practice adherence, and complication rates. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
The hospital mortality rate was 13.6% (95% confidence interval [CI], 11.9%-15.4%) during the preintervention period compared with 11.8% (95% CI, 10.9%-12.8%) during the tele-ICU intervention period (adjusted odds ratio [OR], 0.40 [95% CI, 0.31-0.52]). 	 RESULTS
The tele-ICU intervention period compared with the preintervention period was associated with higher rates of best clinical practice adherence for the prevention of deep vein thrombosis (99% vs 85%, respectively; OR, 15.4 [95% CI, 11.3-21.1]) and prevention of stress ulcers (96% vs 83%, respectively; OR, 4.57 [95% CI, 3.91-5.77], best practice adherence for cardiovascular protection (99% vs 80%, respectively; OR, 30.7 [95% CI, 19.3-49.2]), prevention of ventilator-associated pneumonia (52% vs 33%, respectively; OR, 2.20 [95% CI, 1.79-2.70]), lower rates of preventable complications (1.6% vs 13%, respectively, for ventilator-associated pneumonia [OR, 0.15; 95% CI, 0.09-0.23] and 0.6% vs 1.0%, respectively, for catheter-related bloodstream infection [OR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.27-0.93]), and shorter hospital length of stay (9.8 vs 13.3 days, respectively; hazard ratio for discharge, 1.44 [95% CI, 1.33-1.56]). 	 RESULTS
The results for medical, surgical, and cardiovascular ICUs were similar. 	 RESULTS
In a single academic medical center study, implementation of a tele-ICU intervention was associated with reduced adjusted odds of mortality and reduced hospital length of stay, as well as with changes in best practice adherence and lower rates of preventable complications. 	 CONCLUSION
We investigated the role of cytokines tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) in cachexia development in newly diagnosed nonsmall cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. 	 OBJECTIVES
: We evaluated 44 (M/F:41/3) NSCLC patients and 12 (M/F:10/2) age matched healthy smokers. 	 METHODS
cases with a weight loss of > or =10% consisted the cachectic group (n:23, M/F:21/2) and the ones with <10% weight loss consisted the noncachectic group (n:21, M/F:19/2). 	 NSCLC
Body mass index (BMI) of cachectics was significantly lower than that of noncachectics (21.0 +/- 2.9 versus 24.5 +/- 	 RESULTS
3.6, P = 0.02) and controls (21.0 +/- 2.9 versus 25.5 +/- 2.6, P = 0.01). 	 RESULTS
Serum TNF-alpha level did not differ between cachectic and noncachectics (37.3 +/- 	 RESULTS
39.1 and 51.6 +/- 	 RESULTS
84.2 pg/mL, respectively). 	 RESULTS
However, it was significantly higher in NSCLC patients compared with controls (44.1 +/- 64.3 and 15.1 +/- 	 RESULTS
14.3 pg/mL, P = 0.03). 	 RESULTS
Serum IL-6 level was not different between 3 groups (6.4 +/- 4.1, 8.9 +/- 	 RESULTS
16.3, and 4.1 +/- 	 RESULTS
3.5 pg/mL, respectively) 	 RESULTS
but it correlated significantly with TNF-alpha (r = 0.4, P = 0.006) and BMI (r = -0.3, P = 0.03). 	 RESULTS
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) correlated significantly with TNF-alpha (r = 0.4, P = 0.003) and BMI (r = -0.3, P = 0.03). 	 RESULTS
Among 44 cases, survival of 12 and 17 patients was recorded in cachectics and noncachectics, with no statistical difference (12.2 +/- 3.7 and 11.2 +/- 	 RESULTS
1.0 months, respectively). 	 RESULTS
TNF-alpha and IL-6 levels did not differ significantly between cachectics and noncachectics. 	 CONCLUSIONS
However, significant correlations between IL-6, BMI, and TNF-alpha suggested that these cytokines acted as cofactors in weight loss. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Survival was neither influenced by BMI, nor the cytokine levels in the present study. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The significant correlation of ESR with TNF-alpha suggested that ESR could provide valuable clue for considerable weight loss in the follow-up of NSCLC patients. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Sexual dysfunction is a common adverse effect of antidepressants that frequently results in treatment noncompliance. 	 CONTEXT
To assess the efficacy of sildenafil citrate in men with sexual dysfunction associated with the use of selective and nonselective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) antidepressants. 	 OBJECTIVE
DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Prospective, parallel-group, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted between November 1, 2000, and January 1, 2001, at 3 US university medical centers among 90 male outpatients (mean [SD] age, 45 [8] years) with major depression in remission and sexual dysfunction associated with SRI antidepressant treatment. 	 OBJECTIVE
Patients were randomly assigned to take sildenafil (n = 45) or placebo (n = 45) at a flexible dose starting at 50 mg and adjustable to 100 mg before sexual activity for 6 weeks. 	 INTERVENTION
The primary outcome measure was score on the Clinical Global Impression-Sexual Function (CGI-SF); secondary measures were scores on the International Index of Erectile Function, Arizona Sexual Experience Scale, Massachusetts General Hospital-Sexual Functioning Questionnaire, and Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D). 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Among the 90 randomized patients, 93% (83/89) of patients treated per protocol took at least 1 dose of study drug and 85% (76/89) completed week 6 end-point assessments with last observation carried forward analyses. 	 RESULTS
At a CGI-SF score of 2 or lower, 54.5% (24/44) of sildenafil compared with 4.4% (2/45) of placebo patients were much or very much improved (P<.001). 	 RESULTS
Erectile function, arousal, ejaculation, orgasm, and overall satisfaction domain measures improved significantly in sildenafil compared with placebo patients. 	 RESULTS
Mean depression scores remained consistent with remission (HAM-D score < or =10) in both groups for the study duration. 	 RESULTS
In our study, sildenafil effectively improved erectile function and other aspects of sexual function in men with sexual dysfunction associated with the use of SRI antidepressants. 	 CONCLUSION
These improvements may allow patients to maintain adherence with effective antidepressant treatment. 	 CONCLUSION
to investigate the role of glucose tolerance in the development of hypertension. 	 OBJECTIVE
Retrospective analysis of the results of a health check up in a group of clinically healthy middle aged men in the late 1960s (median year 1968). 	 DESIGN
The subjects were invited to enter into a primary prevention trial for cardiovascular disease in 1974, when they underwent clinical examination for risk factors. 	 DESIGN
The trial was completed in 1979, when the men were re-examined. 	 DESIGN
Follow up was in 1986. 	 DESIGN
Institute of Occupational Health, Helsinki, Finland and second department of medicine, University of Helsinki. 	 SETTING
In all, 3490 men born during 1919-34 participated in a health check up in the late 1960s. 	 SUBJECTS
In 1974, 1815 of these men who were clinically healthy were entered into a primary prevention trial for cardiovascular disease. 	 SUBJECTS
On clinical examination 1222 of the men were considered at high risk of cardiovascular disease. 	 SUBJECTS
Of these, 612 received an intervention and were excluded from the study. 	 SUBJECTS
A total of 593 men were without risk factors. 	 SUBJECTS
The study comprised all of the men who did not have an intervention (n = 1203). 	 SUBJECTS
In 1979, 1120 men were re-examined, and in 1986 945 men attended follow up. 	 SUBJECTS
There were two groups for analysis: one comprising all subjects and the other comprising only men who were normotensive in 1968 and for whom complete information was available. 	 SUBJECTS
By 1979, 103 men were taking antihypertensive drugs, and by 1986, 131 were taking antihypertensive drugs and 12 were taking drugs for hyperglycaemia. 	 INTERVENTIONS
Blood glucose concentration one hour after a glucose load, blood pressure, and body weight were measured in 1968, 1974, and 1979. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
In 1986 blood pressure and body weight were recorded. 	 MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
Men who were hypertensive in 1986 had significantly higher blood pressures (p less than 0.0001) and (after adjustment for body mass index and alcohol intake) significantly higher blood glucose concentrations one hour after a glucose load at all examinations than those who were normotensive in 1986. 	 RESULTS
Regression analysis showed that the higher the blood glucose concentration after a glucose load in 1968 the higher the blood pressure during the following years. 	 RESULTS
Those men between the second and third tertiles of blood glucose concentration in 1968 had a significantly higher risk of developing hypertension (odds ratio 1.71, 95% confidence interval 1.05 to 2.77) compared with those below the first tertile. 	 RESULTS
In this study men who developed hypertension tended to have shown an increased intolerance to glucose up to 18 years before the clinical manifestation of their disorder. 	 CONCLUSION
Blood glucose concentration one hour after a glucose load was an independent predictor of future hypertension. 	 CONCLUSION
To measure in vivo, using diffusion tensor magnetic resonance imaging (DT-MRI) the extent of pathological damage of normal appearing brain tissue (NABT) from patients with migraine. 	 OBJECTIVE
Dual echo and DT-MRI scans of the brain were acquired from 34 patients with migraine and 17 sex and age matched healthy volunteers. 	 METHODS
Mean diffusivity (MD) and fractional anisotropy (FA) histograms of the NABT were obtained from all subjects and the histograms' peak heights and average NABT MD and FA measured. 	 METHODS
When present, average MD and FA values of T2 visible lesions were also measured. 	 METHODS
In comparison with healthy volunteers, patients with migraine had lower MD histogram peak height (p=0.02) of the NABT. 	 RESULTS
No differences were found in FA histogram derived metrics between migraine patients and healthy subjects. 	 RESULTS
No difference was found for any MD and FA histogram derived metrics between migraine patients with and without brain MRI lesions, and between patients with and without aura. 	 RESULTS
This study shows that, although brain damage may extend beyond T2 weighted abnormalities in patients with migraine, the severity of these "occult" changes is mild compared with that found in other diseases associated with white matter abnormality. 	 CONCLUSIONS
OF REVIEW Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disease with limited treatment options and extensive gene expression changes identified in the lung parenchyma. 	 PURPOSE
Multiple lines of evidence suggest that epigenetic factors contribute to dysregulation of gene expression in IPF lung. 	 PURPOSE
Most importantly, risk factors that predispose to IPF - age, sex, cigarette smoke, and genetic variants - all influence epigenetic marks. 	 PURPOSE
This review summarizes recent findings of association of DNA methylation and histone modifications with the presence of disease and fibroproliferation. 	 PURPOSE
In addition to targeted studies focused on specific gene loci, genome-wide profiles of DNA methylation demonstrate widespread DNA methylation changes in IPF lung tissue and a substantial effect of these methylation changes on gene expression. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Genetic loci that have been recently associated with IPF also contain differentially methylated regions, suggesting that genetic and epigenetic factors act in concert to dysregulate gene expression in IPF lung. 	 RECENT FINDINGS
Although we are in very early stages of understanding the role of epigenetics in IPF, the potential for the use of epigenetic marks as biomarkers and therapeutic targets is high and discoveries made in this field will likely bring us closer to better prognosticating and treating this fatal disease. 	 SUMMARY
The hostile environment after spinal cord injury (SCI) can compromise effects of regenerative therapies. 	 INTRODUCTION
We hypothesized that optimizing the post-traumatic environment with QL6 self-assembling peptides (SAPs) before neural precursor cell (NPC) transplantation would improve cell survival, differentiation and functional recovery. 	 INTRODUCTION
A total of 90 Wistar rats received a clip-compression SCI at C7. 	 METHODS
Within each of two study arms, animals were randomized into 5 groups (NPC, SAP, NPC+SAP, vehicle, and sham). 	 METHODS
SAPs and NPCs were injected into the spinal cord 1day and 14days post-injury, respectively. 	 METHODS
Animals received growth factors over 7days and were immunosuppressed. 	 METHODS
Rats were sacrificed at 4weeks and sections of the cervical spinal cord prepared for immunohistochemistry (first study arm). 	 METHODS
Neurological function was assessed weekly for 8weeks using a battery of behavioral tests. 	 METHODS
Nine weeks post-SCI, the corticospinal tract was assessed using fiber-tracking (second arm). 	 METHODS
SAP-treated animals had significantly more surviving NPCs which showed increased differentiation to neurons and oligodendrocytes compared to controls. 	 RESULTS
SAPs alone or in combination with NPCs resulted in smaller intramedullary cysts and larger volume of preserved tissue compared to other groups. 	 RESULTS
The combined treatment group showed reduced astrogliosis and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan deposition. 	 RESULTS
Synaptic connectivity was increased in the NPC and combined treatment groups. 	 RESULTS
Corticospinal tract preservation and behavioral outcomes improved with combinatorial treatment. 	 RESULTS
Injecting SAPs after SCI enhances subsequent NPC survival, integration and differentiation and improves functional recovery. 	 CONCLUSION
OF SIGNIFICANCE The hostile environment after spinal cord injury (SCI) can compromise effects of regenerative therapies. 	 STATEMENT
We hypothesized that improving this environment with self-assembling peptides (SAPs) before neural precursor cell (NPC) transplantation would support their beneficial effects. 	 STATEMENT
SAPs assemble once injected, providing a supportive scaffold for repair and regeneration. 	 STATEMENT
We investigated this in a rat model of spinal cord injury. 	 STATEMENT
More NPCs survived in SAP-treated animals and these showed increased differentiation compared to controls. 	 STATEMENT
alone or in combination with NPCs resulted in smaller cysts and larger volume of preserved tissue with the combined treatment also reducing scarring and improving behavioral outcomes. 	 SAPS
Overall, injection of SAPs was shown to improve the efficacy of NPC treatment, a promising finding for those with SCIs. 	 SAPS
& AIMS Chronic infection with the bacterial pathogen Helicobacter pylori causes gastric disorders, ranging from chronic gastritis to gastric adenocarcinoma. 	 BACKGROUND
Only a subset of infected persons will develop overt disease; most remains asymptomatic despite lifelong colonization. 	 BACKGROUND
This study aims to elucidate the differential susceptibility to H pylori that is found both across and within populations. 	 BACKGROUND
We have established a C57BL/6 mouse model of H pylori infection with a strain that is capable of delivering the virulence factor cytotoxin-associated gene A (CagA) into host cells through the activity of a Cag-pathogenicity island-encoded type IV secretion system. 	 METHODS
Mice infected at 5-6 weeks of age with CagA(+)H pylori rapidly develop gastritis, gastric atrophy, epithelial hyperplasia, and metaplasia in a type IV secretion system-dependent manner. 	 RESULTS
In contrast, mice infected during the neonatal period with the same strain are protected from preneoplastic lesions. 	 RESULTS
Their protection results from the development of H pylori-specific peripheral immunologic tolerance, which requires transforming growth factor-β signaling and is mediated by long-lived, inducible regulatory T cells, and which controls the local CD4(+) T-cell responses that trigger premalignant transformation. 	 RESULTS
Tolerance to H pylori develops in the neonatal period because of a biased ratio of T-regulatory to T-effector cells and is favored by prolonged low-dose exposure to antigen. 	 RESULTS
Using a novel CagA(+)H pylori infection model, we report here that the development of tolerance to H pylori protects from gastric cancer precursor lesions. 	 CONCLUSIONS
The age at initial infection may thus account for the differential susceptibility of infected persons to H pylori-associated disease manifestations. 	 CONCLUSIONS
Several miRNAs are aberrantly expressed in cancer. 	 OBJECTIVES
miR-24-3p is involved in cancer-related cellular processes, including cell cycle control, cell growth, proliferation, and apoptosis. 	 OBJECTIVES
In this study, we examined the potential diagnostic and prognostic significance of miR-24-3p expression in colorectal adenocarcinoma. 	 OBJECTIVES
Total RNA was isolated from 182 colorectal adenocarcinoma specimens and 86 paired non-cancerous colorectal mucosae. 	 DESIGN AND METHODS
After polyadenylation of 2μg total RNA and reverse transcription into first-strand cDNA using an oligo-dT-adapter primer, miR-24-3p expression was quantified using an in-house-developed reverse-transcription real-time quantitative PCR method, based on the SYBR Green chemistry. 	 DESIGN AND METHODS
SNORD43 (RNU43) was used as a reference gene. 	 DESIGN AND METHODS
miR-24-3p levels do not significantly differ between colorectal adenocarcinoma and non-cancerous colorectal mucosae. 	 RESULTS
Thus, miR-24-3p expression cannot be used for diagnostic purposes. 	 RESULTS
However, high miR-24-3p expression predicts poor disease-free survival (DFS) and overall survival (OS) of colorectal adenocarcinoma patients. 	 RESULTS
Multivariate Cox regression analysis confirmed that miR-24-3p overexpression is a significant predictor of relapse in colorectal adenocarcinoma and that its prognostic significance is independent of other established prognostic factors and treatment of patients. 	 RESULTS
Of note, miR-24-3p overexpression retains its rather unfavorable prognostic value in the subgroup of patients with advanced yet locally restricted colorectal adenocarcinoma (T3) and in those without distant metastasis (M0). 	 RESULTS
